Staff are all friendly and helpful not a lot of attitude from the staff. Lovely front desk staff.Although pricey because its by the main strip, it was a nice atmosphere. It had modern amenities and decorating..the upstairs bar was very chic and a great place to congregate before or after events. I would stay there again!Commerce Street Grille - I took my fiance here for his birthday this past weekend and was a little concerned when there weren't many guests there but all turned around when we sat down. Service was amazing!!! James our waiter was very helpful and friendly and so was the manager that night. The food - Best filet I've ever had. I was pleasantly surprised. Not only was it amazing but the portion were big and have to have help from fiance to finish it. To finish our night off we had cheesecake and pecan pie :) so so good. We will definetely be eating here again next time we are in town.My friends and I decided to go to Nashville for the day but didnt want to spend much on a room so I used my points. Best decision! Got to Nashville and checked in early. Upon checkin they provided me with a free movie rental (didnt use - wanted to see Nashville, not a movie), 25% off the restaurants in the hotel and 50% off breakfast in the morning if you got there by 7:30am (definitely didnt use since we got in at 1am). The room was A LOT smaller than I expected but it had two beds and a bathroom so that's all we needed. After a night of fun, we headed back to the hotel. We all still wanted one more beer so we went downstairs to the bar but it closed at 9:30?!? However the janitor told us that their lounge was still open so we went there. Got a beer and ordered some food - nachos and the flatbread - amazing! Definitely hit the spot!! Beds were comfortable as always. Great stay.I loved this place. Has Starbucks in the lobby, staff is super friendly, nice bar area and conveniently located a block away from all the great spots on Broadway - the only negative is the super slow elevators.Worst hotel that I have stayed in.  My bathroom tub did not drain properly while I was taking a shower so I had to hold the drain open while showering.  The Disney Jr channel that my kids wanted to watch did not show properly even though all the other channels worked fine. Lastly, the continental breakfast is only for guests on the 25th floor and can only be accessed with a room key and you cannot upgrade your room key to give you access. But you can always order their expensive room service. I am very disappointed. I have stayed at Holiday Inn's that cost 25% of the price I paid and gotten better service and a free breakfast!Planning an event here and I just want to commend the customer service! Caroline has been my event planner and she is great!Second time here, and while I still think the rooms are to small for what we paid and the elevators are pain.... I am adding a star for one reason.The food is good! Finally a hotel that gets how to do food and not leave the customer feeling cheated. On the Saturday of MTAC my fiancee and I went down to The Bridge for drinks and dinner. We ordered some calamari, which was as I expected, expensive for what it was (almost $10) and an appetizer. What we got though was tasted far better than I expected (really good actually) and was far more than an appetizer portion. There must have been at least enough for four people in that one bowl of calamari we got. And it was very good.The following night after the convention was over, as a member of the MTAC staff, I was invited to the staff after party at the hotel restaurant. The con big-wigs had paid for a fully catered meal of fried squid, wings, pizza, pies and drinks. I stuck with the wings, a slice of apple pie (leaving the crust) and more calamari. The food was amazingly good for hotel food and actually quite filling.I might have considered raising my rating to five stars if not for the fact that the hotel did not give my friend the fridge she requested for our room when she reserved it. Other than that it was a consistent experience from last year.This review is for the "Bridge Bar" only in the Renaissance. I came on Memorial Day weekend and NO restaurants were open past 2 pm. NOTHING! Which is why we went out of our way to go to another hotel a few blocks away for something to nibble on. First off, this bar is BEAUTIFUL. Probably one of the only restaurants with a ton of natural light - most other restaurants in the area are in windowless rooms and pitch black. It was nice to have some light for once. Unfortunately, despite the friendly service and AWESOME fried green tomatoes, I have to dock a few stars because they were just out of everything. So I'm exaggerating but the soda was all flat b/c they were out of CO2, they were out of certain juices and other drinks...it seemed like their already limited menu was limited even more.However, the fried green tomatoes were AWESOME here. They had rice, black eyed peas, and were very crispy without being too greasy. I had never had them so I don't have much to compare them to but I was very happy with my choice.If you're craving some sun, this is the place to come. You're welcome for the obnoxious rhyme.Overall just meh as far as Renaissances are concerned. Good location as Broadway is a very close walk. Staff was friendly, room service was more reasonable than most hotels, and the concierge lounge put on a decent offering. Downsides- dated, though the furniture is newer. Also, beware of the elevators- I had a room facing one of the outside elevators and it was quite loud, I had to move. In general, the sound proofing is pretty subpar.Compared to other medium sized cities with a hotel connected to the conference center, Nashville lacks a bit in a quality hotel.  I stayed here for the first time 23 years ago when I was a high school student in town for All-State Choir and then again 23 years later as a convention chair and Nashville resident.Since the late 1980s, the hotel has certainly changed for the better.  The lobby decor and amenities have great improved.  The views from every elevator shaft could possibly be some of the very best of the city landscape and beyond.  The Skybar which used to connect the hotel to Church Street Station Mall is now a sleek vibey lounge with great views east and west.While the rooms have been updated, you'll still see the remnants of an aged hotel (stained tile grout, brass door hinges with layers of paint colors, cloudy window panes).  The joy is, even through the cloudy windows you still get a spectacular view from almost any room and vantage.Second time we have stayed here and I couldn't be happier. I've stayed in a few downtown Nashville hotels and this is the best!  Rooms are clean, staff is friendly, location is excellent, what more could you want? Oh and there's a Starbucks in the lobby! No disappointments here, we'll be back.Nice hotel. Not the biggest lobby but enough place to meet with friends. Bar upstairs on 3td floor towards Patkade is a nice chic place to hang out. Rooms are modern and clean. There is no safes in the room. Staff are efficient and friendly.The bar at the Renaissance Nashville Hotel is quite a hidden gem. A great place to gather before a Titans or Predators game, offering Wine Wednesdays, affordable bar food and multiple TVs. The parking makes it an easy place to begin the evening.Bad experience!!  The shower didn't work at all. After traveling for hours, I was hoping for a nice hot shower. The shower's faucet was broken so we had to wait an hour for the building engineer.  That proved to be a temporary fix because the hot water didn't work at all the following morning. The guest services staff was rude and acted as if a cold shower was no big deal for a $225 room.This is a beautiful hotel in downtown Nashville. Clean, modern and friendly staff. Starbucks is within the hotel, on the second floor you will find a beautiful pool and fitness center. Our family enjoyed our stay here and we will return again.Over all not bad,  staff friendly, and helpful.   We just had a few issues.   Elevators made no sense,  five of them but it took no kidding 5 minutes to go to the first floor after we started keeping track.   Friends went from the fourth floor to the first but the doors didn't open and went to the fourteenth and got stuck.   Plumbing was incredibly loud.   You are going to know when your neighbors pee and definitely when they shower. We also didn't have a bottom sheet on the bed.   But my wife is sexy as hell.I stayed here for a conference, due to lack of parking around the city and with three conferences going on at the same time it was worth it. I also got a room discount because of the conference. It was in waking distance of the conference, and downtown Broadway ave.  The beds were comfortable and the bellhops were very nice and friendly. However the hall an room were very dated and over priced. But as it turns out they were renovating the floor below me. Hopefully the rooms will be better the next time I visit Nashville.I've stayed in Marriott's across the county and this one was "ok".  Nothing bad to report, but I also felt that it was a bit expensive compared to what you get.  Only glitch is that the lady at the front desk said they would call when my room was ready but she never did so I waited an extra hour.  Front Desk  B-Restaurant BRooms B+Doormen and Lobby Staff  A- Location A- [right around the corner from Broadway]This is an older hotel. The rooms were smaller than I expected and compared to the other Renaissances I've stayed in, it seems like it could be due for a remodel.  So keep this all in mind before you get here and you're disappointed.  The location is great. I used points so I can't comment on price.  The beds were insanely comfortable. Probably one of the most comfortable hotel beds I've stayed in and I travel a lot.The staff was super friendly! I was very very pleased about this.  Also, I left a dress in my room, realizing it after we were on the road for an hour heading home. I contacted the hotel and they sent me back my dress. I was so glad.The concierge lounge is small but well stocked.Really my only complete was that housekeeping came by ~3 times the morning we were scheduled to check out. If we're going to check out at noon, wouldn't it make sense to come by after that? Idk I'm not an expert on this.I saw some people complained about the parking situation.  Seriously? If you're in a city of a decent size, most notably in it's downtown area, it's unlikely that there will be an attached parking lot, people!  The parking garage is across the street from the hotel. You have do drive down the street and turn the corner to enter the parking garage.  Park on the 4th floor. There's a pedway connecting the parking garage to the hotel. Just take that and you'll be on the hotel's 4th floor.  Not too complicated. Minimal time spent "outside". The garage is covered. The weekend price is very reasonable ($5-$7/day).Overall, I recommend this based on the staff friendliness and location.

review_content: What a fun place for those that want to get to their step goal while taking in the sites!  I love new places and I love walking so when friends of ours were staying there for a baseball convention the weekend of Jan. 9th, I jumped at the chance to finally check this place out. My fiance and I met up w/ my best friend and wandered around for at least an hour. I loved the waterfalls and foliage.  The place is clean and I couldn't help but think if you were to get married here, you wouldn't have to leave to get pics anywhere else b/c the the scenery is so serene.  I didn't find any of the employees to be overly friendly or friendly for that matter...  We saw their room which had a king bed and she said a small fridge- it was typical of other Marriotts.  There are a lot of places to eat but from what I gathered, you'll pay way more than what the food is worth- my suggestion would be go somewhere else for a plethora of dining options in the Donelson area.  Parking was easy in and out- we didn't have to pay as we had a guest w/ us BUT if you just want to check it out w/o paying, park close by and walk over.Ugh...I hope to never stay at this hotel again. Had to come here for a work convention...As soon as I checked in, I wanted to jump in the shower, but the previous guest's used soap and shampoo was still in the soap rack. Disgusting!The hotel itself was nice enough, but it was so huge!  TOO huge...There was no rhyme or reason to the layout, you couldn't really cut across the gardens totes to get to the meeting rooms.The food was subpar, the few shops were all very cookie cutter...nothing unique to any of them.I don't know if anyone else provided the same feedback from my company, but I hope to never stay here again.I call this hotel the Complex Complex. I have stayed here twice for a work convention and have to say that I still got lost at this place. It is quite expansive and for some reason I was always looking for a central lobby or landmark but got lost in the tunnels and hallways looking for my room. The room was average and you can get a view of the interior biodome or if you are lucky, a window to the outside.  I would have liked thicker comforters and felt like I just had a sheet on the bed. The water in the shower was never really hot. The hotel is split into three areas (Cascades, Delta and Magnolia). Even with a map, I feel like you need to ask for directions because it all feels like a maze. The conservatory feels like a rain forest with all kinds of tropical fauna and waterfalls. It was 25 degrees Fahrenheit outside and snowing and inside the biodome, you don't even notice it. I wish I had some more positive reviews but I was just not impressed with my stay at this massive hotel. I really could not wait to go back home.Room Tip: Get a map and good luck finding your room.The Gaylord "biodome" format isn't new to me, I've also been to the Gaylord Texan. Having said that I liked the layout of this one a lot, it had a nice variety of spaces under four separate domes. There was a big selection of restaurants, I only hit two (most of my meals were part of the convention) but food was good if not overpriced. I however found a lot not to love with the rooms. At least in the delta wing the rooms were consistently cold and oddly the HVAC rans run constantly instead of as needed. Beds oddly didn't have a proper blanket or quilt - in January. Fortunately a call to the front desk got me a couple blankets. The pillow covers were threadbare along with falling apart headboards. The towels were the quality of a cheap motel. The rooms were simply subpar for half the price. If you can, skip this place.This review is just for walking around, and not for actually staying here.This place is a fun labyrinth. My friend brought me here during the holiday season and we walked around to admire all of the decorations they had up. It was a good mode of exercise without involving the cold outdoors. They have cutesy little shops inside that make for good souvenirs. I'm sure you have to pay extra for the pretty rooms that have balconies facing inside the main area (the outdoor balconies face... the mall?)We stayed at this resort for four nights last week while my husband attended a conference there. The resort is grand, beautiful and well kept. All of the employees that I came into contact with (from restaurant servers, to the lady at the spa who did my pedicure, to the lady who gave us our Delta riverboat tour) were attentive, friendly, and full of suggestions on things to do and see while at the resort, and also the easiest ways to navigate around the resort. One of the bellmen in the Magnolia lobby actually helped us pinpoint our Uber GPS pickup location.Every atrium / neighborhood is unique in its own way and has something to see (walk the gardens, ride the river boat, sit by the falls). The fitness center is HUGE and has tons of cardio equipment (and the individual cardio TVs actually worked) and tons of nice weight lifting equipment. The outdoor pools were closed for the winter but the indoor pool was large and tranquil.My spa pedicure was to die for. I enjoyed hanging out in the spa lounge before and after my appointment.Our room was in the Cascades neighborhood which is the last neighborhood to be remodeled (we learned this from a tour boat guide). Even though it was not remodeled, the room was kept up well and clean. The TVs have this cool feature that allows you to login to your Netflix account and various other apps. The maid came at decent time each day and did an excellent job cleaning. We were very pleased with the room portion of our stay (although there is SOOO much more to this hotel than just your room!).One day I needed out of the hotel so I walked to the Opry Mills mall next-door. It was about a 10-15 minute walk. There is a complimentary hotel shuttle on the half hour of each hour though.Two complaints (minus 1 star so really just fair warnings): #1 - the lines: mid week the lines for everything were almost unbearable (coffee shop, breakfast places, etc). they really cram a whole lot of conferences in and the place gets crazy#2 - the prices: food is very expensive for what you get (my two egg, hash brown plus biscuit breakfast @ Cascades was $22 before tip! Two rolls of sushi and a non alcoholic mocktail @ Wasabi was $44 before tip!)MUST DO'S:- relax by the falls in Cascades in the AM with your coffee or in the PM with a beverage of your choice- ride the Delta river boat AT NIGHT (we highly enjoyed hearing the history of the hotel and seeing the view at night...bring a beverage along with you)- watch the Delta fountain shows from the balcony outside of the pizza place on Delta island (we loved the "Aqua" show @ 8PM)- go up the the Delta mezzanine for a beautiful view of almost the entire Delta atrium- splurge with dinner at Old Hickory (you will get the most bang for your buck here... be sure to make reservations in advance)Also note that an Uber ride to downtown (Honky Tonks / Broadway) was $16-$18 (so if you are planning on eating elsewhere figure that into the cost you will save over the expensive resort restaurants).OVERALL: this is something to do and show around out of towners. I've been here at least 3 times, but twice was more than enough for me. A OK rating for me. I'm not a big plant person but I think if you are then you'll love this place. WHAT: Inside is basically a jungle garden forrest with a man made river running through it. You can take a boat ride on it during business hours and they take a photo of you that you can purchase. I think it's better to see inside during the day. But better to see outside at night especially during the holidays when they have all the Christmas lights decorating the trees outside. KIDS: Every time I've been here they have some kind of children's exhibit fun activity for them. It's usually during a range of hours though. EAT: Restaurants are definitely over priced but it is a hotel so that's expected. Ice cream place was yummy. Nice bathrooms. I thought this would be a more happening place at night with the bars, but they were empty. PARKING: $21 for self parking. Free if up to 20 minutes but I swear their clock tacks on an extra 10 min so you have to pay the fee.Dreadful stay at the Gaylord Opryland. Check-In: Aggressive check-in woman.  I simply expected a King room that I had reserved.  She stated that bed type reservations were simply "requests." She proved her point by sending me to the farthest room in the 2200+ room hotel basement (I'm not kidding...I had to find the only elevator that went "down" from the lobby level and then walk past the hotel laundry department to get to my room).Pillows:  Three postage stamp sized pillows for the king bed were not enough for one person because they were so flimsy.  While on the subject of the bed, the sheets were so thin they were see-through - kinda gross.The room-service Eggs Benedict were atrocious. A rather anemic looking plate (see photo) with a ramekin of the most horrendous tasting hollandaise sauce I have ever experienced. Do they buy this powdered sauce mix from an army surplus store? Nothing else on the plate - no hash browns or potatoes of any kind were included with this eggs Benedict... Cheap kitchen, not so cheap price. The rooms are dated and certainly very dark and dreary. The windows have been locked shut (see photo) so don't expect any fresh airDead battery in the in-room safe (see Photo). Oh joy!!! What a process to get a battery:  Called to explain that the battery in the safe was dead. They sent security to confirm that yes, the battery was dead (the flashing "BATT" was a giveaway I guess. The security person then authorized a maintenance person to come and change the battery. Maintenance arrived and replaced the battery. So glad I had an hour to kill in my dreary room for this lovely experience.$30 (one way) Gaylord Resort shuttle to the airport was just one of many outrageous charges at this hotel.  A cab is a $25 flat rate for up to 4 people.  Housekeeping arrived at 5:50PM to clean the room.  I had called hosuekeeping at around 3:30 simply to make sure they hadn't overlooked the room.  The snippy person on the phone said: "Because this is such a large hotel, we have until 6PM to clean your room."  Well OK then.  I guess she was exactly right.  I've never experienced anything like it and I practically live in hotels. On a positive note, the bellman that carted our luggage (for miles and miles) to our room was a delight.  I think his name was Nick? or Victor?  He said that he started at the hotel in 2001, took a break, and came back to work there.  He was charming and pleasant.  Also, the ballroom dinner was very good with attentive service during the reception and the dinner.Nashville is a likable city but my stay at the Gaylord Nashville has made me dislike Nashville immensely.  It's one thing to have a tired convention hotel but I did not expect the surly staff to go with it.Note: This is not a review of the accommodationsI met up with some friends here because we wanted to stroll around the holiday displays. First, this place is a freakin' maze. It took us about 20 minutes to find each other. There are walkways at all different elevations, walkways that dead end and no real landmarks to tell someone where you are. Very confusing and the maps are not helpful. Second, the decorations and displays are pretty lame. Definitely not worth the time, which brings me to the next point: more than $20 for parking? What a joke. This isn't Disney World. Not worth the money.We had lunch at the Jack Daniel's Saloon, and it was one of the worst meals I've had in recent memory. My burger had such a gross flavor that I ended up throwing away nearly all of it. The waitress didn't even think to ask about it when she took away my full plate.Skip this place!So far 45 minutes in valet line to check in and still 2 cars back. So, not worth a dime in my book.Update, very slow morning... Still waited over 20 minutes to get car so we could leave for town. Did enjoy watching the valet guys stand around and play shadow basketball. Good timesHow did I not know about this winter wonderland? We did a great holiday getaway, took in the Gatlin Brothers dinner shoe at the hotel and toured the Christmas displays.  If you have mobility issues and have a scooter...you will need it..so bring it along...the place is the size of Delaware.  Using a cane or walker?...They rent scooters at the front desk area for $50 a day.  Retail shops are great...your biggest problem will be picking one of the over 20 restaurants.  We ordered eggs over easy from room service on a busy weekend and they arrived in perfect shape...WOW!But the thing I was the most endeared by were the thousands of families from all over the world that have made family reunions at this property a holiday tradition.  We saw hundreds of families lining everyone up on holiday decorated staircases, in front of poinsettia Christmas trees, and other displays for family group selfies...I came to tears when I saw a middle aged Jewish man offer to take the family photo of a group speaking Arabic...this hotel is a great holiday stop.(Two tips for management:  1.  I had a great spa experience..and recommend you put together some end princess packages..ala Disney...for the mom's and girl's of these families to get group mani pedis...  (ala Disney's spa traditions for younger girls...stock some tiaras..).  2.  Put up some Christmas backdrops in some of the extra space in the Tennesee wing..or elsewhere ...and let families get professionals to take some holidays family photos just in case the selfies fail..perhaps you do and I missed it..but it would be easy for you and would turn  profit...)The grounds at Opryland Resort is nothing short of stunning. All the landscaping is well maintained, and it's a mini-town under a giant dome (think Jim Carrey's movie The Truman Show) full of shops, restaurants, bars, a spa, and even a indoor riverboat tour (think gondola ride at the Venetian Hotel in Las Vegas). Every room as a view of the courtyard/town, and it's so convenient that it's connected to the Convention Center. The rooms were clean and modern. The bed was comfortable. I loved having the blackout curtains and the balcony that you can sit out on and enjoy the view. My only complaint of the room would have to be the temperature control. It was impossible to get the room to a comfortable temperature. Honestly, with the hotel being as big as it is, I'm surprised it doesn't have some sort of internal transportation system, i.e. golf carts, stops on the riverboat, etc. I, of course, was given a room on the farthest opposite end from the convention center as possible, and I was schlepping a heavy backpack for the 3 days I was there, so needless to say, my currently pregnant self was not happy with how much I had to walk just to get to and from my room and the work conference I was attending. There is an airport shuttle which runs every half hour as well as a shuttle that can take you to downtown Nashville (you can buy a day pass).It really is a cool place to stay if you've never stayed there before. Even if you don't stay there, make a stop there just to see the place and walk around. It's an experience to remember.This hotel is one egregious mistake. While the atriums are certainly stunning, the dated hotel rooms, poorly managed food services and overly rude staff work against the few niceties that the hotel failingly attempts to offer. I had to move hotel rooms due to a sewage problem in mine, asked about wifi and was told I had to be a hotel guest (which I obviously was), and not one restaurant has over a 3 star rating on yelp...but they certainly have 5 star prices.I stayed here for a conference way back in 2007. It was gorgeous, the hotel was clean, there was a lot of southern hospitality. Everywhere I went I told people this was amongst one of the best hotels I've been to. I've always wanted to come back because my first time was such a great experience.Fast forward 8 years and I'm finally back. On this trip, my connecting flight in Washington, D.C. was cancelled and I wasn't be able to catch another flight until the following day. I called the hotel to inform them I was still coming and not to give my room away. The guy I spoke to said that would be fine, but he thinks I should also talk to the customer service manager. He transferred me and I got a recorded message asking me to call back during business hours.The following day when I arrived, I was assisted by Kimberly. She had nasty fake red hair and a stank face. She didn't even return my greeting!!   She informed me there weren't any rooms available since I didn't check-in on the right date. Instead, she could put me in a room with a sofa. She told me that they'd provide a foam mattress topper for the pull out sofa bed. I was appalled!! Why would they have rooms without beds?!! I told her I called and a guy told me my situation would be okay. Even though he transferred me, I didn't get a hold of anyone. I demanded to talk to a manager. After several minutes of her making a stank face and several huffs and puffs later, Kimberly decided not to call her manager but magically "found" a room for me. This just goes to show she was lying and trying to cheat me since they overbooked! Baiting me with a room and switching me for a substandard room!I was assigned to a room in the delta section of the hotel. The beds were lumpy, the pillows are super thin and worn. I was not impressed.On top of the poor service and lumpy beds, this already expensive hotel also charges an $18/day resort fee: fitness room, two bottles of water per day, slow internet, etc. The hotel/airport shuttle also costs more than a taxi so don't use it!Also, our conference brought over 4,000 attendees. Why the hell would the restaurants NOT be opened for lunch?!!! Only a handful (Cascades, Stax) were open on a Monday?!! The lines were long and pretty ridiculous.Once again, when I checked out of the hotel at 3 AM (I had a 5:35 AM flight out of Nashville), I found two unfriendly woman at the front desk. Their hair was thrown up in a gross looking, loosey goosey, half ways pulled through ponytails and stank faces. They looked like shit and sounded grumpy. WHY would they employ such unprofessional people to represent the face of such a beautiful resort?!!Lastly, if you plan on visiting Nashville, this hotel is rather far from the hustle and bustle. A taxi ride or uber ride is about 20 minutes each way. This is very inconvenient. If you plan on never leaving the resort, and it's completely possible to never leave the resort during your stay, then the distance to civilization won't be a big deal. But what's a trip to Music City without enjoying the music scene in The District?It's the most ginormous resort I have ever seen. The reception was a mad house with hundreds and hundreds of people checking in for New Year's eve. You would have to see it to believe it. We walked from one themed area to another, and another and another, you could lose a few pounds walking around, improving your memory as you get lost from the turns and corners while navigating around and spend lots of money. There was a ice sculpture event going on also which we didnt go to. However in one of the atrium there was a water fountain show which was spectacular. There were many convenient store where one could find bath salts or lotion or souvenir, many F&B outlets to hang out. It's quite a place to check out....Huge hotel in terms of atrium space and where the rooms are placed. So big, in fact, that you have to obtain a map at the front desk to see which wing of the hotel that your room is located at. I wound up staying within the Cascades wing, and even getting to the elevator was challenging both to myself & other guests, even through the use of the map.Steeped in prestige within the Nashville area, the Gaylord Opryland hotel is somewhat reasonable in price in terms of what is offered. I paid roughly $129 for a one night stay while on business, and the most memorable feature of the hotel wasn't even the room. It was most certainly the majestic atrium areas that contained fish and waterfalls, and fountains, as well as other amenities expected for a resort-style hotel. The eateries, such as the coffee cafe, had prices that were expected for any hotel comparable with a Marriott Courtyard cafe, and the quality was good. You have the choice of having valet parking, or parking your car in the adjacent lot (quite massive) that you'll have to walk a little more than two city blocks to get to the hotel. Upon entering, you'll encounter two massive front desk areas on both sides of the lobby. Considering that this hotel is always busy, the process was somewhat efficient, even with 10 people in front of you. The rooms itself was okay and up to my standards. The furniture, particularly the bed, desk and bureau, was somewhat unique yet possibly common to how furniture was made in Tennessee fashion. Hard to explain. Although the furniture was updated, it had an old, classic feeling to it. Nonetheless, staying at the Gaylord Opry is like walking through a massive work of art with Luciano Pavarotti singing "Nessun Dorma" in your ear as you walk to your room with a glass of scotch. Truly memorable.The Opryland Resort is nothing if not spectacular! Delta Island with its fountain and boat rides is bustling with shopping. The Garden Conservatory is relaxing and serene. The Cascades Atrium has many waterfalls.There are many restaurants to choose from. The food is pricey; but, it is very convenient to have all of those options available without having to go out.  Stay away from Jack Daniels Saloon though, it was by far the worst service and food Ive had in a long time and super pricey.This is quite a spectacular hotel, with the rooms facing huge (as in HUGE) atriums filled with plants, waterfalls, rockwork and rivers. There are many restaurants scattered about, and the theming is really well done. Having been to the Gaylord in Orlando, I was surprised to be reminded how much larger and nicer this Nashville one is.As with any giant hotel, there are hordes of guests, so part of the trick of staying here is to try to avoid the rush. That means not arriving right at check in, when there can be 100 people in line at the front desk, particularly on a Saturday night. And if your room includes breakfast, go early before the lines form.Staff is very friendly, so as long as you can avoid the crowds it's a good place to stop in Nashville (note that it is nowhere near downtown, though).While I have not yet had the experience of stay in one of the rooms yet, I will say the atrium is stunning. It doesn't feel like you are in Nashville once inside. There is a man made river with a gondolier and beautiful garden grounds. Do not visit if you don't have some extra cash to spend. Everything from the food, to the shopping, even a simple ice cream cone is outrageously expensive - so keep that in mind.This is definitely something everyone should experience however when visiting Nashville. I do plan to stay in a suite soon, and will update my review accordingly.I was there for a professional convention.  It was horrible.  There is zero customer service.  The blow dryer in the room was from 1987 and did not blow hot air.  The air conditioning system is also outdated.  The ice machine didn't work on many floors.  It was very large and I had trouble navigating, but if they had friendly, knowledgeable customer service agents easily accessible, it wouldn't have been a problem.  When we got to the check-in line, there was maybe two agents there.  1300 people were registered for the conference. I've had to call a couple of times and when they couldn't help me, they just asked me to call back (not taking my name and number and offering to return my call).  This is supposed to be a swanky hotel, but my experience was unpleasant. They need an overall customer service training session ASAP.
review_content_20: The gardens are really the most amazing thing about this place. The fact that something like this place is under one roof is amazing. I was in the area and just happened to walk in. The parking is expensive but we found a dirt lot near the freeway. So it was about a one block walk to the hotel. This place caters to large meeting places and conferences. All I did was walk around when we were visiting the Country Music Hall of Fame.Stopped off here on the way to Nashville. 20 mins free parking will get you a whistle stop power walk through the gardens. Really impressive!This property is beautiful, big spacious, great greenery, the atrium gardens and river with the boat are a site to see and explore. The room was a descent size and had a great cute patio, the bathroom i wished would have had two sinks but it was good nonetheless and fridge. the only thing was the room did take a bit to get to the temp I wanted it at, and also was a little humid, but the door open to the patio would clear it. Otherwise this was a good spot to stay, lots of shuttles, nearby places to eat, pools and workout rooms were awesome.A giant convention center hotel that is totally cold, impersonal, uncaring, and lacking basic signage and help once you are trapped within the bowels of the facility.The rooms are nice, and despite many complaints to the contrary, I found the internet service to be passable.As a Marriott Rewards level at the Platinum Premier status, I can tell you that you would never know it here.  There is no attempt made to offer any special amenities or benefits for a Platinum level guest.  So you may as well be John Doe to these guys.The property is so massive and the directions inside are so convoluted, missing, and misleading that you can easily get lost.  It is NOT fun.Honestly, if you have a choice, stay elsewhere.Never for the rest of my existence will I voluntarily stay at this Gaylord property. Upon check-in, we had to wait two and a half hours for the room to be ready. Thankfully we had rented a car so we didn't have to sip overpriced cocktails at the hotel bars. When we did finally get the room keys, we had to navigate this maze monstrosity - the directional signage leaves much to be desired. I once asked a member of the staff if he could direct me to the ballroom I was looking for, and he looked at me blankly before saying, "I work mostly in the lobby area, sorry."The billing was a nightmare, too. My company had paid for all of our employee rooms, so we only had to provide a card for incidentals. But for most of us, not only did the company get charged, our credit cards were charged, too.I came along for the ride to hubby's 5 day convention and was engulfed into a giant bubble city. Here are most of the ups and the downs of my stay.THE GOOD:It is a beautiful property. There are streams and bridges and fountains and ponds all laced with gorgeous flowers and plantings. Sort of like being in Oz. I kept looking for the Munchkins to no avail.Most of the resort employees are wonderful. At my request, I received extra bottled water every morning and at no charge. The Wasabi restaurant rocks! I enjoyed delicious Sushi that tasted like it was flown in from Japan.Every meal I ordered, by the pool or at one of the resort restaurants, came quickly and was delicious.The Spa! If you are having a treatment you are able to utilize everything in the Spa that day. Sauna, steam, shower, lockers, teas, fruit and nuts, coconut water, shampoo, conditioner, a plush comfy robe, relaxation room, plus everything you need to dry and style your hair before you leave...AND, the fantastic pool adorned with cute cabana boys.A Starbucks with lots of gluten free selections. (Shocking, really.)There are several great retail shops that include a Johnston Murphy and Cowgirls and Angels.Free Wi-Fi because we are Marriott repeaters. THE BAD:It's freakin' HUGE and it takes days to learn directions! Leaving a trail of breadcrumbs doesn't work as the staff sweeps them up quickly. And, some employees don't exactly know their way around. (Um...'scuse me but this should be on the final exam before hiring.)Only a few restaurants are open during the day. Food is extra costly at the hotel restaurants. For example, my "large" bowl of tortilla soup, although tasty, was a cereal size bowl and cost $9.00.You are living in a creepy bubble. The environment, temperature, music and smiling employees are completely controlled. Hunger Games, anyone?I don't even know where to start with these guys. Disclaimer: I got a $50 credit from them after complaining.I compiled a list of things wrong with this place.  There are too many to make this a fluid post, so I'm just going to post them as I wrote them.  Keep in mind this is for a place that portrays itself as a high end resort.- Only 3 pillows for a king bed- Tears on headboard (see pic)- No ottoman for the old, worn chair- $23 to park plus a "resort fee" of $18- Beat up furniture long overdue for replacing.  One nightstand was missing knob- Carpet worn and was separating from wall- Dirty walls throughout room and bathroom- Said I had FedEx package when we checked in.  Told me where FedEx office was.  After walking forever and making many wrong turns, it turns out FedEx office was closed.  Also, I actually had no package.  It was for another person with same name, picked up days earlier.- Fridge was leaking and not working- No signage anywhere in the hotel with directions to Opry Mills- This place should have phones everywhere for people who are lost- Many employees did not speak English- Operators there have this annoying routine they do.  They answer the phone and say, "To better serve you, could you please state your name?"  So I say, "Bill."  "How can I help you?"  I'm like, why did you ask for my name?- Very long waits on hold to speak to operators- We had a birthday cake and needed something to light candles.  They had nothing!- Pot of coffee from room service:  $14 for small and $17 for large- There is no contact information for the hotel GM. In most quality hotels, that info is at the front desk in form of the GM's personal business card.- Bill was screwed up when we checked out and we had to have it fixed.- They slap a $50 charge for incidentals even when you have a credit card on file, which is BS.Bottom line is that this is not worth what you pay.  Very stressful staying here.  Hard to get around and no one there to help you.  But believe me, they couldn't care less about negative comments when they are raking it in.The hotel itself is massive and quite impressive when you first walk in and the landscape throughout with the many fountains makes for a very nice setting. Lines can be long for checking, they are a Marriott partner which helped us by pass or would have been 20-30 minute wait. Pros- beautiful hotel with a lot of waterfalls, koi ponds, and  running water.Beds imo are very comfortableA lot of shopping and restaurant options.Cons- service at restaurants and quality of food is below average. Although there are many different places to dine only half were open. If you are going to stay you would be best served eating elsewhere.Do not come here unless it is on the company dime. Seriously.We are halfway through our vacation and are already itching to leave. 1) The "extra" costs (including water) are Manhattan prices or higher. Literally every time we turn around we are astonished at the high price or the hidden fee. We are on vacation and expect to pay a higher price at a resort, and yet are still floored at what is happening. 2) They should take the word "resort" out of their name. It is 100% a conference center. Sure the gardens are pretty and well manicured, but there isn't any place to relax and be comfortable. I cannot stress this enough. Unless you are coming here for a conference, don't. 3) All those restaurants they boast having... 9/10 are closed all day. They are either completely closed, or closed for a private event (remember, it is 100% a conference center...). So, if you want to eat here, you have to go to one of 2(?) that they have open. 4) Think this is a nice resort to stay at while you visit Nashville? Look back at my #1. The shuttle that takes you downtown is $20/person. Lol. Thanks for nothing Opryland.This place is the worst marriott I have ever stayed in, and I am a Platinum member. Total rip off every-time you turn around. It should not be called resort, because there is nothing to do. Only one or two of the restaurants are open each night and they are all atrociously overpriced. And they charge you 20$ per person for a shuttle to go into town. 25$ a day in parking, and 4$ for a coffee. Its like a bad joke. Trust me look elsewhere. Id rather be at the courtyard. At least there I can get a reasonable breakfast for under 20$.The atmosphere is superb.  The rooms are adequate.  The staff is very friendly and helpful.  Now for the negatives:  there are over 2,800 rooms and only one sit-down restaurant in the entire place to get breakfast.  It is beautifully set, but not that large.  There are a couple of coffee areas in the Conservatory area with a total of 16-20 seats in  a very dimly lit, grungy corner. Yuk!All other restaurants open much later in the day and some not until dinner time.   There are no seating alcoves or hallway seating areas anywhere that I have found.  There are two gigantic fireplaces in the Magnolia lobby.  Each have seating for six people.  All in all, you will be able to walk miles and miles in here, but good luck finding a place to land.  Is this really southern hospitality at its finest?  For that, I'd give it only one star.Visiting Nashville you have to come here right? Right. So I did. The idea was to come in and look at the gardens and walk around.  First red flag: $23 for parking? You've got to be out if your mind. Madness! There was no way we were doing that. My friend and I are from NYC, we're walkers. We decided to park across the street and hoof it. We entered the lobby and just started to look around. The signage is not the best. Perhaps they don't wish to have obtrusive signs, but it's confusing as hell. The employees actively avoid eye contact with you so you don't ask them anything and when you do, it's clear they only know about the section they work in. Which I get, but it's not helpful to a visitor. I was impressed at the scope of the jungle/lobby area. That took a lot of planning and takes a ton of maintenance. The plants are beautiful and lush. I can imagine that it's more colorful in summer, assuming they plant flowers as well.  Water features were also nice. The rest of it seems really contrived to me. Beautiful in that Disney way, which is perhaps what they were looking for. Im glad I went and visited. It was something to see in Nashville, that I had heard about forever.So, four stars. Wasn't blown away and we often found ourselves drunk and confused wandering around. It's really easy to get lost here and it's frustrating the people who work there aren't always capable of helping you find your way. Also, the restaurants open and close without warning. That's kind of annoying - planning to go somewhere for dinner walking what seems like 5 miles to get there and they are closed. The Valet was weird.. We pulled up and instead of coming to open the door for us, the group of kids working in the valet just stood there. Maybe this is a Bible Belt slow thing : ) haha in LA the valet open your door before your car is in park sheesh. I would stay here if you are visiting Nashville for the full country music and experience. If not, stay downtown!We came here for the express purpose of checking out the multiple lobbies of this expansive resort! I can see why it is a convention center because there is a TON of space to accommodate large groups. The lobbies are absolutely beautiful and it was a nice break from the TN mugginess that we had been experiencing during our visit! My mom, kiddo and I did a huge lap around the place and were not disappointed for a DIY free walking tour. Lol. There is a boat tour that you can take, but we skipped out on it since we were in a hurry to get to dinner. It puts you in mind of a lot of the Las Vegas lobbies, without the flair. To my disappointment, the majority of the staff there is not very friendly, as compared as to the majority of the people we had met in Nashville. Often staff would pass us and not speak or even make eye contact with us! We were tourists just like any others wandering around and this was definitely not a "tony" property, so I do not know what that was all about. I am not sure if I would bother with staying in the hotel, just because it is SO large and feels disconnected, community-wise. I saw guests at check-in but I do not envy those who have to make the trek from one side of the hotel to the other. Again, it is worth your time to look and walk around as a "to-do" in Nashville!I booked a stay at the Gaylord Opryland Resort on Priceline for a Friday-Sunday in the beginning of August. I'm going to start with the negatives:We got a good rate for the room but were surprised by the resort fee. When checking out and paying for parking, I was charged this resort fee again despite having already paid Priceline for it. I fought it but the desk worker wasn't having it. We were not given a print out of charges underneath our door like a message on our phone the previous evening told us we would. Because of this, I was unprepared to fight an incorrect charge. The line was long, the worker didn't believe me, and I didn't want to make everyone wait while I looked through my email to prove I had already paid this $18/night charge. The second huge negative of our trip was the maid service. We had a wake up call scheduled for 9 but a little after 8 we hear banging on our door. I thought it must be next door because who the heck is knocking on our door that loudly at 8? They knocked again and I opened to find a maid. She gave me some towels. I was half asleep still so I honestly don't remember telling her to not come back but maybe I did. No one ever came back to clean our room. Thank god we had gotten more towels or that would have sucked. After we left for the day around 10, we removed the do not disturb sign I had put on the door when the maid showed up. According to the hotel people are cleaning until 6 PM. And still no one cleaned our room. I can understand why a lot of people might be up and at 'em on a weekday as this hotel is attached to the convention center. But it was Saturday. We checked in at 1 AM the night before. We had a wake up call for an hour later. I know the maid couldn't have known that, but I really wish she could have. And dang it I just wanted to not be the one to make the bed. Another not great surprise was believing valet parking was $23. When we saw self parking we figured it had to be cheaper. Wrong. Self was $23 and valet was $31. Just a mix up but disappointing. For the positives of this hotel:The main reason I would consider staying at this hotel again was the downtown shuttle. It was fantastic. For $20/day or $30/3 days you could ride the shuttle back and forth as many times as you wanted. Someone else in the hotel told me that uber was $20 one way. We rode it around 11 and then came back during the hottest part of the day. We got cleaned up and rode it back for dinner/going out. It was great to not worry about drinking and driving. The beds were soft but not crazy soft. It was interesting walking around the hotel lobby and looking at all the water falls and such. One great thing about our room was outside the bathroom was an additional sink and vanity. It made it a lot easier for two girls to get ready. Next time I might consider rebooking if only for the shuttle. It was the hotels saving grace. If not I would just stay downtown since we already had to pay an arm and a leg to park any how.This is my second night here and I will start with the good stuff. This hotel is magical, I have never seen anything like this place. The restaurants are good. The steakhouse food was amazing but we waited 1.1/2 for our steaks, Alan was our server and he was a sweetheart. The breakfast buffet had a lot of selections and all the staff where very friendly and helpful.  Now, please stay somewhere else to sleep!! When we checked in, we first walked in to see hair, mud, and blood on the floors. With little kids, I just cleaned it up and called the front to let them know. The front was very helpful and made sure the room was cleaned, even calling me to make sure it was to my standards.  But my reason for the 2 stars is the noise. Our room (g1009) faced the parking lot. They had busses lined up throughout the day and night. The noise was unheard of.  Waking my 1 year old from naps and sleep. I called the front and they said it would be removed, but it wasn't. They still stayed this morning and loaded people up. When I tell you how load it was! You would not believe me. If you like your sleep, stay elsewhere and come here for the day. Not worth the money and daily fees. I'm booked to stay till Sunday and I'm waiting to speak to a manager this morning. I will be posting more pictures and comments of the rest of our stay.For the price, I expect more. It's very noisy in the rooms and pillows are so flat - my neck hurt the whole trip. I called room service and asked for synthetic pillows instead of down and they were just as deflated. Zero blankets in the room, just sheets which were in pretty bad shape.There are barely any plugs in the room for your electronics and a previous guest unplugged the iHome, probably to charge their phone. I called the "consider it done" front desk and asked them to reset my clock radio and she says, "what time does it say now?" It's wrong, does it really matter?Nothing is free with your stay. The resort fee is $15 plus tax, which includes wiFi and 2 water bottles. Wow! Parking and shuttles are extra.Was here for a conference, but stayed in the Cascades area which is almost a mile to the convention center. If you're staying for a conference, book in the Delta area unless you want to hike over every morning.The shops are all overpriced cheap and tacky souvenirs. Many of the restaurants are closed a few days a week and nothing is open late.I think my expectations might have been a little too high. From everything I had read or heard about the Opryland resort, I was set on a week of awesome amenities and plenty of relaxation and pampering. However, I was met by fairly unhelpful signage (it will tell you to take elevator "R1" to access the pool area from the spa, but not actually how to find the spa), rooms keys that were continuously deactivated (causing many 0.5 mile hikes up and down stairs and over bridges to get to the front desk and back), and amenities that were open...sporadically (I know, I know. The first week in November is probably not peak season. Tell that to my $300/night rate.). It's a great place to visit once, but I don't think I'll be back!My husband eloquently described our stay this way: "it's a beautiful place. Not sure what all the hype is about though."To give a couple of examples of what I consider to be sub-par service for a place so obviously vying for an upper class clientele:-Waiters/Waitresses not saying anything after you are seated, just standing and assuming you will speak first to give a drink order-Restaurant staff placing the bread basket in front of just one seat (instead of mid-table) and not describing the contents-Sparkling wine, ordered by the bottle, not being chilled at the table and having to refill glasses on our own-Having to pay for parking with a credit card, because the room key wouldn't work to allow us out of the self parking lot, and the gate employee coming over to tell us that is what we had to do if our key didn't work (it's not...more inquiries at the front desk led to the discovery that we would have been double-charged for parking that day had we not inquired further)-Restaurants being closed with a generic sign asking us to visit another option (without stating what or where those options were)-Restaurants and shops closing at 8pm. Acceptable on a weekday. Completely unacceptable for what is sold as an "inclusive" resort on a Saturday night.Maybe my stay was out of the ordinary.  Maybe.Just finished a 3 day stay at the Nashville Gaylord hotel.  The place is ginamous. The layout leads you to many long walks getting to and from your room. Here is the lowdown as we saw it.Rooms were typical fare. We had to get reassigned to get a king even though we had requested it. The king room had a nice view of the loading dock, dumpsters and standby generators.  Not a real issue as we did not come to sit and look out the window. The staff was mostly friendly though the English was a struggle for some.  We got lost one evening trying to find the ice cream shop and one of the staff dropped what she was doing and insisted in personally escorting us over there. When we left we got lost and came back to the ice cream shop and the same lady then took us all the way across the facility to our rooms.  She got a nice tip for her helpfulness. I did get yelled at by a staffer protecting a table of box lunches. Told me his table was closed and to go to the other table. I gave him a look and complied. Walked 30 ft to next table and got box, turned to leave and his table had been swarmed. Stupid. They were all the same lunches.  He did not get a tip. The hotel is convenient to surrounding shopping and Opry, but the traffic is very congested.    The shear size and the atrium would dazzle kids. They were decorating for Christmas and it looked like it would be a wonderland when lite. We were with a corporate group so I don't know what the rates were. Looking online I'm guessing $250 plus taxes and such. Parking showed to be $24 a night.  We had quite a long wait for valet parking and calling ahead did not help. I would note that my 3 stars are pretty good. I rarely give a 5 as that would mean there was nothing left to possibly improve.  But this facility did lack the edge of some of the better Marriott properties we have visited.I love this hotel! I've stayed here once but have been here multiple times during Christmastime. The hotel is massive so if you're with family, make sure you keep an eye on the kiddos - it's easy to get lost in (I've done it more times than I care to admit). The room I stayed in was clean, really pretty, and had a nice view. Hotel staff are friendly and willing to help you if you need it. I HIGHLY recommend coming at Christmastime, it is simply gorgeous. It is close to the Grand Ole Opry and Opry Mills mall (literally walking distance) and about 10-15 minutes from downtown. Also close to the airport. Definitely one of my favorite hotels in Nashville!
review_content_40: horrible housekeeping, concierge, restaurant service!! do not stay here if you value respect or customer service!If you want to see Nashville - stay downtown.  If you want a resort - go elsewhere!  Pools - a joke.  2 very small pools.  Don't open until 9am, and even at 9:30 on Saturday morning the 'Pool Closed' signs were still up and there were no towels!  The Cascade pool was packed because the only other tiny pool was closed due to dirty water.  Then within an hour they made everybody get out of this pool because of a "chemical imbalance" in the water.  If you can't keep 2 tiny pools clean, you are not a resort.  Housekeeping - on day one we left early, and returned to our rooms around 5pm to relax and get ready for dinner.  Rooms were still dirty, no clean towels.  Called down and was told housekeeping has until 6pm to clean.  WHAT?!?!?  I have never stayed at a hotel where you sat in a dirty room all day!  Despite request for early service, our rooms were never cleaned before 5pm.  Unacceptable.  WiFi - free wifi, generally slow.  I was constantly knocked off, had to login several times a day.    Restaurants - $4.50 for a cup of fake starbucks.  Whatever.  I guess if you call yourself a "resort" you can do that.  Restaurants were overpriced and always seemed to be closed, even when they were scheduled to be open. There are tons of great local eats if you have a car - The Pharmacy, Arnold's, Puckett's (Best fried chicken & waffles!).  I wouldn't waste your money here.  Also, they boast live music every night.  All we found was 2 guys singing Margaritaville in Jack Daniel's bar, which smelled so bad we walked out immediately :)  Parking - In a word...Extortion.  $30/day + tips for valet (where people complained of having to wait 30 minutes to get their car) or $25/day for the pleasure of parking in a lot a mile away.    Keep in mind you're already paying a daily "resort fee."  I guess that's to keep up the 2 dirty pools...  The atriums are beautiful, waterfalls and foliage - but that's about the only compliment I can give.  The only thing that makes this a resort is the $18 a day resort fee they charge.  If you really want to experience Nashville - stay downtown!Came here to walk around and enjoy the lushness of the plants. Wow this place is amazing. So many types of trees, plants and flowers. I can't imagine how much work goes into maintaining it. Thumbs up Opryland.We stayed here for one night only due to it's proximity to the Grand Ole Opry. As you can see by the photo's, the place is gorgeous. And enormous. Did I mention expensive? And I don't mean just the room charge, I paid in advance so I knew the price. Everything there is expensive with lot's of hidden fees. For instance, when you pay $318 for a room wouldn't you think the parking lot would be included in the price? Um, no, you pay an additional 24.00 for the parking lot. And what exactly is the $18.00 "resort fee" which is added to the bill? I'm not certain but I think it was for the wifi. I never did quite figure that one out. The $38.00 meal from room service is actually a $52.00 meal....somehow. The room itself was clean and comfortable with the furnishings being a cut above most hotels in quality. But that apparently  doesn't mean you won't be awakened at 3:00 am by drunken hillbillies screaming in the hallways and beer bottles left in the elevator.Still, I enjoyed my stay there and it was nice to catch their shuttle to the Opry instead of having to mess around with the traffic.I plan to attend the Opry once each year but it is unlikely that I will stay here again. I will either deal with the traffic or see if I can find another hotel with a shuttle. Not trying to discourage anyone from staying here though. It really is beautifulAre we sure that the Great Wall is the only man-made structure visible from outer space? You'll excuse me for wondering whether the Gaylord should be included on that list. Driving up I wondered if those astronauts up on the ISS weren't also gawking at this monstrosity. When I learned that an up-coming conference I had to attend would be held at Opryland, there were a lot of expectations conjured up surrounding this piece of Americana. What I wasn't expecting was an edifice with its own biosphere. Good grief. Rivers, rainforest, waterfalls, and a complete plantation-like village all under an expansive, glistening, plexiglass sky. The one thing I'll remember from my time at the Gaylord Opryland is the labyrinth of lobbies, corridors, and gardens. I think I spent a third of my time just trying to figure out how to get where I was supposed to be. And, those large, randomly-placed floor plans with the mocking "You Are Here" red dots were rarely helpful. After about 2 hours here, all I could think was: Overkill. But, this is America, ain't it? And, $20 a day parking. Yikes! They entrap you in their consumer maze and leech you dry of your life savings. In all fairness, my experience wasn't entirely negative. All of the conference facilities were top notch and we had nothing but pleasant interactions with hotel staff. My biggest complaint in this area was that our main meeting hall was FREEZING! If you're there for a conference, just bring your coat with you. Besides that once we did stumble upon our desired corner of this behemoth, we generally had a positive impression.Well, I can definitely say it was an experience. But, I don't even want to think about what the carbon footprint of this monster is.I'm here for a conference so I did not pay for the room but it certainly is quite roomy.  I wish the peep hole on the door were a little lower as my size 5' 2" body could not look out and see who was (mistakenly) trying to get in my room at 10:30 pm.I will say the property is just beautiful but a bit confusing, I had to be at the governers room for a session and struggled with the map.  I found a staff member (collecting room service trays) and he was kind enough to walk me over there.Food from room service was not very good and I knew it would be costly but after the day I had yesterday trying to get here I felt I deserved it.  I ordered the all American and it was here withing 30 minutes delivered after they call you back to let you know it's ready and on its way.Bed is comfy enough and the room is clean which is all I ask for so 5 stars for that.Checking in took a little while but again with multiple conferences going on it didn't surprise me, you were kept entertained with a guitar playing singing cowboy who was quite amazing.Overall I probably wouldn't stay here if I were paying for it, too expensive and too noisy for my taste.This place is breathtakingly beautiful!!  I am simply in awe of the size, beauty, friendly staff and amazing ambience. We were given our rooms as a complimentary gift. We thought we would get a regular room, which would have been 100% fine with us. However, we were given an Atrium view room with a King size bed. We were shocked and surprised at the hospitality at the front desk. Our rooms are bigger than average size and perfect. Perfect beds, firm and comfortable. Extremely clean rooms with modern decor. Bathrooms are small but really how big does it need to be?  We have walked around most of the hotel. It's HUGE!  There is so much to offer. Arcade, dining, drinking, family fun, golf, river tours, shuttles, and so on. There is a "small" shopping Main Street area that is super cute. Live music all over the place!!! The hotel is so big you need a map to get around. It's like Disney for adults and kids too. If this isn't enough the Grande Ole Opry is 15 min by complimentary shuttle, the Opey Mills mall is close. Downtown music row and the museum is about 19 min away. Such an awesome experience all the way around...This hotel is amazing!! It is huge!!! The convention center is perfect for your business needs.  There are awesome places to dine. There's a gondola running through the hotel that is a must see .    It's close to downtown Nashville. The grand old Opry is right next door. The mills are around the corner as well . It has great shopping. You'll definitely do a lot of walking.  You can't get around that because of the size of the hotel. You can catch s can to get downtown . It's around $20.  There's enough to to do in the surrounding area if you don't want to venture out.  I would stay here in a sec on my return. Friendly staff , very helpful.  The prices are the same in the area. $$$I'm going with a 1 star rating. It is a beautiful hotel and the gardens are amazing. Other than that the overall experience is not good and left us feeling raped and abused. Long lines, slow service and high fees and prices on everything. Such as $30 for parking - one night. $18 resort fee - big rip off. Slow check in desk. All the time anytime of day or night. Mediocre food. $50 breakfast for 2. Hard to get around the hotel. The staff seems worn out and not really interested in providing good service. Overpriced rooms. We were there and most rooms were empty and yet they gave us a room with an outside view of a parking lot. Don't even attempt to discuss with them the outrageous fees or other issues. They are so tired of hearing it they will not entertain your issues. I'm sure this place was built on great service but wow they have lost it.Oh yeah, there was black mold in the shower area.This place is not for families. Be prepared to spend 450-500 dollars in food for three days. 24 dollar milk and cookies. No food from outside is allowed.  Restaurants in the hotel are more expensive than anywhere else in Nashville.  Ordered a pizza from outside restaurant staff was very hostile to me when I brought it in to hotel.This was such a beautiful convention center. We were told to walk the gardens and have lunch here. We do not expect it to be so large!  The streets reminded us of a "clean" New Orleans with the amazing ironwork outside the stores and the river running through it was stunning !  We sat at a bistro table enjoying the waterfall and watching the tourist in the little boat. If you have a few days in Nashville this place is a MUST SEE!I have mixed feelings about the Gaylord Opryland. For background, my family is from Florida and we stay at the Gaylord Palms (Orlando) about twice a year. That said, the physical plant here during our Christmas stay is nothing short of spectacular. I cannot imagine what the landscaping requires but they should make a reality TV show about it. The hotel is made up of four large hotels connected with giant glass ceilinged atriums filled with plants, waterfalls, walkways, boats in lazy rivers, fountains, and more. You have the feeling of being outdoors even though you are inside the whole time. The attention to detail is mind-boggling. Unlike other reviewers I found the Christmas decorations to be breathtaking and more than adequate; I just can't see how even the most picky guest could feel that the holiday was overlooked. The fountain light show is a must-see and the true Christmas holiday music was welcome. I could go on and on about more details (the outdoor Nativity, the giant Christmas tree, the beautiful lights on the grounds etc). Now for the not so great. First, perhaps not surprisingly, the GOH charges for *everything* and everything is pretty expensive in the GOH, from valet or even self-parking ($24/day). Worse, and I hate to say this, the service was well below expectations. The staff seemed harried and unhappy. Because you can't pull into the breezeway without a "ticket" you are required to queue to enter the hotel. Last night the valet staff was possibly on strike. There was a double line of 40+ cars and nothing at all happening in the breezeway but we were all held up by a single hotel manager who wasn't letting anyone in except for whenever a single valet appeared. After 20 minutes my wife got out, walked up and asked the poor guy what was going on. He said he had no idea why but the valets didn't come in to work. All of them. We abandoned the entryway and self-parked and entered on the other side of the hotel. We had an incident of late delivery of luggage when we checked in, which required multiple calls to the front desk and eventually a tense exchange where we were told that during a four-hour period our luggage had "probably" been attempted to have been delivered but because we didn't stay in the room (for four hours at dinnertime) the luggage wasn't delivered. I complained to the general manager who comped us four (4) breakfasts (even though there are five in our party and he confirmed that twice). I suspect that the service problems are a result of Marriott's acquisition of the property, but I'm just guessing.Finally, the room was meh. On check in, we asked for an upgrade and were provided one at a $65/night up charge; only problem was the view was of the trash handling facility for the hotel. I'm not kidding. Even though we were here in winter, the beds only offered a thin sheet --there were no comforters or blankets anywhere in the room! Fortunately we all brought sweats to sleep in (plus doubled socks).Now I understand the low ratings. The people were friendly, grounds were beautiful and beds comfy. What ranks it low and makes it so frustrating is lack of staff/service and overpricing. Everything we did took twice the time it should of for this caliber resort- Parking valet:  20 min. ($23 to self park even for just an hour) Room service for coffee and 2 oatmeals (55$): 50 minTrying to get someone on the phone: 10-15 min! Waiting in line to Check in at midnight: 25 min I'm writing this review hoping the management reads it and thinks about makings change and adding staff. If the service was up to par the costs wouldn't seem so ridiculous.Marriott Executive Platinum and so far this hotel has not lived up to its overhyped websites, it has under-delivered to say the least. We have experienced not having been greeted at the door on arrival, to having to get my own language cart at check-in, trying to track down someone to valet our car and even the unpleasant hostess staff at the restaurant for lunch right after check-in. The only person that was nice to us the entire stay was the bellhop that finally helped us with our bags.At $300 a night, I expected much more. I've been treated better at $80 per night courtyards and had better rooms in much better conditions. The rooms are old and outdated, lack plugs for today's electronics. Lights, Mirror's and bathroom are old, rusted and showing lots of wear; this hotel needs a major update or lower prices to reflect the condition. We had stains on the bedlinens, the throw pillows and even the blankets themselves. This was very gross and no one at the hotel cared about it one bit.Not having a Concierge Lounge is a big setback, if you don't have a lounge then at least provide a credit or coupon for breakfast for the loyal customers and elite members. This hotel is all about charging you to death, they charge and overcharge for everything that you need. Wi-Fi is poor only had one bar the entire time in my room and this at $12.99 per day. I think you can do much better and stay at a different hotel for the money. They even charged $9.95 for a 15 minute boat ride on a fake river.We just about went broke after eating inside the resort for one day. We shared meals most of the time and still didn't even come close to having an affordable meal. The various resort taxes and fees just complicate the pricing and add to the overall bills. $32.00 to valet park or $24.00 to self-park! That just does not add up, maybe $12 to self-park would be better.So for three night stay, 2 people in a standard room, parking and three meals (1 each Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner) $1,687.27 was the total price, all this along with having a dirty room, unclean linens.GO SOMEWHERE ELSE, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNEDGO SOMEWHERE ELSE, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNEDGO SOMEWHERE ELSE, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNEDGO SOMEWHERE ELSE, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNEDWe are here for our 30th wedding anniversary. This place is amazing: Easy to relax, easy to have fun.... With a wonderful staff. Some reviews complain about prices and crowds. Considering the quality and what must be maintained here, this place is a great value, even in comparison to other four and five star hotels I've stayed at. If you can't afford it, stay and dine elsewhere. Also try and get an atrium room, the balcony is worth it.Excellent pools and fitness center.The crowds are cyclical, and not an issue.... You can also plan on staying during the week to avoid them.In each restaurant we enjoyed good that was consistently very good to excellent... With excellent wait staff always.Things to do: the Opry is great, and I'm not much of a country music fan. The mall is nice if you're a shopper.We love to walk, and this is an excellent place to do it... Garden paths, waterfalls, fountains, bridges... Very nice.... Plan to get lost in a good way.Check-in was great, WiFi a bit weak at times, and room carpeting is getting a bit worn... But the rooms were very clean with comfortable beds and gray a.c. It's a unique venue, with amazing people who operate it. We will be back!This place is unreal. It's like a little city and botanical garden inside a biome. Hard to believe this place exists. The gardens are beautiful, the set up is wild. There's restaurants and coffee shops and retail shops located inside. You really have to see this to believe it. Only drawback: it costs $21 to park in the lot unless you go through it all in under 20 minutes, then its free. So either book it through the place or go park about 10 minutes away at the mall for free. Side note, when the zombie apocalypse occurs, I'm coming here. It has everything.My second visit to the Gaylord Opryland Resort and Convention center occurred about two weekends ago. The bad news is that this place is pricy and they charged about $23 for daily parking - which I think is ridiculous considering how much you put out for the room. The good news is that they give discounts to military and professors - not significant enough not to put a dent in your pocketbook but anything is better than nothing. The special they ran for teachers included two complimentary breakfasts and two shuttle rides which was a great deal. We enjoyed the breakfast buffets and the scrambled eggs but didn't use the shuttle because we did other things in the area. I do love that the wifi is free in all the rooms and throughout the hotel and that the outdoor pool had a DJ in the afternoon. Another great thing about the Gaylord is that it is adjacent to the Grand Ole Opry and mall. It's also conveniently located to downtown. It's a large space so if you walk around you will get your daily exercise.Today we spent the day in Nashville so we decided to stop in at Opryland after hearing so much about it from friends and family. This hotel, convention center and resort is incredible. The indoor gardens and delta are breathtaking while the staff here is pleasant and helpful.This complex has a little bit for everyone. They have a great selection of restaurants and they also have some great shops. We enjoyed sitting at their Falls restaurant overlooking the waterfalls. In the end we thoroughly enjoyed our experience and have made a promise to ourselves that we will return during their Christmas celebrations.The Opryland hotel in Nashville Tennessee has to be the second biggest hotel I've ever stayed at.  I have been to Vegas a bunch of times and this hotel reminds me of being in Vegas. The only difference is that the Opryland hotel is in the middle of nowhere there are no hotels comparable to what size in the area. When I arrived I had no idea how big this hotel was. The person who does travel frequently and stays in a lot of different hotels I was amazed at the sheer size for a non Las Vegas hotel. When I walked into the main lobby I went to the check-in area and it was decently crowded. I waited about five minutes and then I had a employee carry my stuff to the front desk. Everything went great with the checkin except for when the employee took out a map of the hotel. He explained me this is where I was and he took a sharpie and he draw where I had to go. On the map it looks like it wasn't that far and I felt fairly confident that I could get there. I left the front desk and went from the main lobby into the first planetarium dome. That's when it hit me how big this hotel was that it was going to be in adventure trying to find my room. I kept following the signs and looking at the map that said where my room was. All I ended up doing was getting myself more confused. Finally after about 15 minutes of trying to figure out what hallway I had to go down I ended up just asking an employee for help. The gentleman was extremely nice he took my stuff and he assisted me right to my room with no problem. The room itself was nice it was a double room I had three sinks in my bathroom I had a walk-in shower and the room was a regular hotel room there was nothing special about it. The room that we did have did not have an outdoor balcony. In the hotel itself there are three different conservatory domes. Each has their own name the one I stayed in was the mezzanine. In the entire hotel there is over 3000 hotel rooms. There are three pools. 16 to 18 restaurants and bars. There is also three convention centers well as the grand old Opry center. There is a full-size movie theater attached to the place to that had all the current movies. Just a huge FYI. This place is big and you will be walking a long time to get wherever you have to go inside of this hotel. I did go out to eat at one of the restaurants and I asked the waiter how long it would take to walk from one end to the hotel to the other.
