He told me that one day him and another employee actually wore the step counters around work. The employee told me that he walked over 3.2 miles in A six hour shift. The restaurants and bars in this hotel are okay. I did not like the old hickory steakhouse at all. I did spend a lot of my time at the fuse bar just be prepared that the drinks are expensive. The Jack Daniels restaurant was okay nothing special. They do have a bar by the main lobby called the falls. I did enjoy that bar they had tables where you could sit out and there's a waterfall that runs down through the bar I thought it was really cool. Another really cool feature of this hotel is they have a gondola ride that goes around the entire hotel. The whole entire river in this place has fish inside of it pretty big size fish to Coy's bass carp. When you stay here you do get charged an $18 amenities fee. Basically it covers a list of things I am posting a photo that shows all the amenities that you get. The price of the rooms are pretty expensive you're basically paying for the view of each conservatory room and all the amenities at the hotel offers. Overall I will definitely be back here I think it's a really cool place to visit especially if you have little kids. The price of the rooms are expensive but I feel that you do get a lot. The biggest tip that I could give anyone coming to this hotel is bring comfortable walking shoes you will be walking a lot. Another tip that I have is they specify this when you check-in but make sure that you keep your hotel keys in a separate pocket from your phone or your credit cards. You do have to take a cab ride about 20 minutes to get to downtown Nashville. PROS:- beautiful scenery- gondola ride through the hotel- staff is helpful with directions - friendly staff CONS:- pricy- you walk a lot. It takes forever to get from point a to point b - you need a map to get anywhereThe ambiance of the hotel is nothing but extraordinary. It's like nothing else I've ever seen in a city. It's like a city in a city. There is plenty to do if you're staying as a guest and if you have a deep wallet. This is probably my 12th or so stay here at this hotel. There are plenty of restaurants to fit your taste buds or cravings, there are plenty places to walk, plenty places to shop and much to see in general. This hotel is absolutely gorgeous. But lately they seem to be offering less and less. The prices of the restaurants have doubled, the quality of the food has went down, there is less of a wait staff everywhere, and the valets did not even pick up the car when making the phone call we had to go physically hand them the tickets and wait over 20 minutes for them to pick up our car with maybe 4 cars or so under the awning, and numerous valets standing around. I would recommend visiting this hotel as a casual walkthrough, but as to staying here and paying the outrageous rates and getting so little in return now, I find it hard to justify the stay.The staff used to go above and beyond to make sure you have an exceptional stay, but now you hear valets screaming at taxi cab drivers, valets not wanting to pick up your car, and staff that is tired and complaining of no breaks and management seeming to be non existent, and waiting 10 to 15 minutes to even get the initial drink order . This used to be my number one choice when coming to Nashville but now with the higher rates and not getting the resort style feel, I can't even say it's in my top five now.I truly hope that they turn this resort around and get back to their roots. I would love to continue to make memories here, but for now its just a place I will walk through.
review_content_60: Quick check in.  This visit I had a great view with a balcony.  Prices are still on the high end but the service was great.Amazing resort!! It's huge so get a map. Luckily there is a shuttle to take you everywhere. There is even a shuttle to take you to the grand ole opryI'm glad that this is a Marriott property (elite!!) and the price is not that much different than the other options in the area.I'll start by saying this place is HUGE and is a destination within itself.  You don't even have to leave!  And the face that it was during a monster snowstorm, and everything inside was kept at an ambient temperature was awesome... I could still wear the shorts I packed, and didn't have to go buy and emergency winter wardrobe!There are a lot of nice shopping opportunities, but the prices were a little higher than I prefer to pay... however, not out of line for a convenience markup.The hotel itself looks great!  It's in good shape, and clean.  All of the staff we encountered were wonderful.  They even have a Marriott Elite check-in line.  However, the one lady working it was busy with one guest while myself and 15-16 other guests waited for over 1/2 an hour (while watching regulars check right in)... they should've moved someone to help weed-eat the line!  If you are going to be that busy at check-in,  you should have let me check in early as I had requested (and you denied).The restaurant we ate in Sunday afternoon was a bit blah (and when I send back 2 meals because they are inedible, you really should send a manager to talk to me!).Not a bad hotel... but management seems either overworked, or insensitive... either way... what should be a 5 star experience is now 3 STARS.However, for the money I would still recommend this place of the competition!So it appears I'm the black sheep of reviews on the Gaylord Opryland Resort.  Our company flew us out to Nashville for a FY15 Sales Kickoff Conference. I had a room here for 3 nights.Check in was interesting....They had 3 people checking in about 80 new arrivals. Luckily for me, I was only 10 people deep and so my wait was pretty decent. Something like that wont ruin my impression of this place.Gaylord Opryland is a beautiful resort. I spent most of my time in the atrium, listening to the waterfalls and looking at all the palm trees, architecture, koi in the river, etc...I understand why many people bitch about the layout and how far it is going from one section to the other, however.....have you ever been to Vegas?? If so, this place is a cake walk. I'm pretty sure if this was small, and compact...it wouldn't be a convention center.My room was just fine for what it was. It felt a little dated, but it had every amenity that I needed. The bathroom had a spacious shower, and enough counter space for me to lay out toiletries for my stay. House keeping did a great job of cleaning my room daily. Lots of hotels have a habit of picking up all your personal stuff and either puting it in piles, or moving it around enough that it leaves you with a really insecure feeling.  What I appreciated was that they simply straightened out my stuff and left it where it was.They have many places to eat and drink here.  I didn't eat at any of the restaurants that were housed within Gaylord, so I can't speak to that. I would suggest taking a cab downtown and hitting up some good ol' Tennessee BBQ. Cab's from Gaylord to downtown are $25 and $1 per head after that. So make sure you plan for that one.Service was great all around. Even when having breakfast and lunch in the convention area, I was impressed with the food they brought out. It was no culinary master piece, but it was a hell of a lot better than i've had in the past at Ceasar's Palace in Vegas. Would I spend my own $$ at this place?? Ehhhhh, I dont know....I think I would look for a hotel that's more centrally located. However as far as business is concerned, I think it's great for business meetings, conferences, and events.This resort is absolutely wonderful, I enjoyed the scenery that occupies much of the inner layers. Stayed here for a conference and have to say that most of the staff was friendly from the maids to the front desk workers. They also have a nice number of restaurants within that cater to many palets such as Italian and Asian. The little street near the center of the resort gives people more a bar scene with a pub and wing bar that both have decent portions for food without outrageous prices. The bedding and sleeping experience was very nice. Decor was fairly modern but didn't express any particular flair that would set it vastly apart from any other mid grade hotel chain. Very positive experience overall.What a mistake staying here.  First off, I know it is a giant place and all that, which was neat to see and experience.  You have to travel a bit to get to your room, which involves waiting for very slow elevators each time.  The rooms were ok, but the walls were paper thin, you could hear doors opening and closing and talking in the hallways all night.  I also had to listen to the people in the room next to me "making love" - that was very loud as well.  Oh joy.  Tried to get out of the parking lot the next day took about $20 min, card was not coded and had to pay $21 for parking.So, per Wikipedia, This hotel is the largest non-casino hotel in the Continental United States outside of Las Vegas and also ranks as the 29th in the List of largest hotels in the world.  So, with that said, prepare to walk... A lot.... Especially if you are attending a conference.  My room was in the Delta section, and it was a good 10-minute walk from my room to the Magnolia section of the convention center.  But, I do recommend you find time to walk around and explore, and try some of the different restaurants... The gardens are beautiful!  You can even take a boat ride around Delta Island.Room was old and worn.  Carpet stained badly.  Thermostat didn't work.  Bed very uncomfortable.  Shower head sprayed in all directions at the same time.  Nice view of giant garbage crusher. ;)Too expensive despite the nice atriums.  Food way too expensive.  Extra charges for parking, internet, and even more for fast internet.  You will do a lot of walking and easy to get turned around.Best for convention stay, but not for a one or two night business stay.  You can do much better at one of the nearby hotels.I probably will not stay here again.I just didn't love it.Let me start by saying that I do travel for work quite a bit and I like nice hotels.PROS: Huge and cute looking.Tons of restaurants/barsBeds were comfyCONS: Staff didn't seem to know what they were doing at any pointHotel is a mazeBreakfast was weak.Hot spots and wifi were blocked.It is far from downtown Nashville, so just keep it in mind.I stayed at the hotel for 4 days and 3 nights to celebrate my engagement and also my fiance's birthday.. Checkin was a long wait and we were sent to the wrong room with all our luggage so we had to come back down and get that sorted out.We tried to dine at several of the restaurants in the hotel over the couple of days we stayed there, but I'm not kidding every single host was extremely off putting and rude.After all the failed attempts of eating with in the hotel.. We finally decided to try out the falls bar very beautiful. We sat down for probably 15 minutes and no one would serve us.. I went to the bar to grab out drinks and that took like 10 minutes. So I bring the drinks back to the table (2 drinks for 27) and I taste my drink and it is awful. I proceed to stop a server walking by and tell her that I didn't like the drink and was hoping she could switch it out... She says yes and comes back with another drink. Sits it on the table and says I'm sorry but your going to have to pay for this drink and I said I'm not paying for another drink I already bought a drink and didn't drink it. So she shrugs her shoulders grabs the drink and leaves.The real kicker to the whole thing was I want to management and spoke to the food and beverage manager. She really didn't even apologize for the horrible service she just offered me to go back into the restaurants and sit where I was just treated with bad service! I was outraged and said no that I would not like to go back in there so her next best was to get me the drink that I had paid for!!!! I literally have never been so disappointed in hotel management! There saving grace is the beautiful scenery. Absolutely horrible staff.Extremely overrated and overpriced! You are paying for a name! This place is confusing to navigate and the employees at the restaurants were kind of rude. The room was not bad but for the price I paid it could have been better. The spa is overrated as well.If I could give this place 0 stars, I would.  The Gaylord clearly valued bringing in big groups, like the Beta Club National Convention, over providing the Country Christmas experience they heavily promoted.  I had hoped to begin a new holiday tradition, and begin a low-stress all-inclusive option this holiday, but navigating thousands of some of the most poorly-behaved and disrespectful middle-schoolers was not what I had in mind.  I witnessed more pushing, swearing, and running through crowds than I have ever seen at a family event (and that includes the St. Patrick's Day parade in Chicago).  Gaylord missed the mark. They could have managed this situation better. They could have had the student group together in one of the 4 hotel areas, rather that dispersed among the families trying to have a relaxing holiday. The food lines are ridiculously long. They don't have enough staff to manage the demand. And the staff are clearly stressed as well -- they, too, have gotten increasingly rude in the last 24 hours.  Total Fail, Galylord!The Opryland Resort is nothing if not spectacular!  Delta Island with its fountain and boat rides is bustling with shopping. The Garden Conservatory is relaxing and serene. The Cascades Atrium has many waterfalls.The hotel is huge with over 2,700 rooms and 3 lobbies. We ended up at the Magnolia lobby for check-in only to find that our room was in the Delta section at the opposite end of the hotel. If I had known ahead of time, I would have gone to a closer lobby to check-in.Our room was nicely appointed as you would expect in a Marriott managed hotel. My reason for withholding the fifth star is the high cost. The room cost is high enough but then you tack on an $18 resort fee for the two bottles of water in the room, WiFi access, and boat rides, and $24/$32 for self- or valet parking. Then there's the prices in the restaurant; the breakfast buffet is $24 per person. Prices in restaurants is high, too.  Buffet breakfast is $24 per person!Bottom line: Spectacular resort, but pricey, all-in. The amenities are not cheap and their costs have to be picked up somewhere. Forewarned is forearmed. Enjoy a wonderful stay, but don't be shocked when you get the bill.DO NOT STAY HERE. We are on a company trip so it's hard to grip about a free trip right?  Wrong. To start with parking is 23 dollars. So you have to pay for the hotel plus the privilege to park there. The hotel staff is rude by most counts and treat you like you don't know where your at. We haven't made it twenty feet in the lobby and they are telling us we are lost (after checking in). The rooms while nice have very stiff and uncomfortable beds. We did enjoy our view. The pool closes at 5pm so if you like to swim you only have a few hours to do it.Restaurants. Where do you start? If you are lucky enough for them to be open you will be disappointed by the prices, quality and service. All of which are subpar. Tried several restaurants over four days and they were always closed or not honoring their advertised hours. Best recommendation here is to eat out.BRING YOUR OWN DRINKS. A mountain dew is 3.50 and a beer is 5.99 (ONE BEER). Did I mention the mountain dew has expired four months ago?PARENTS AND DISABLED. This is not a stroller/wheelchair friendly hotel. Yes there are walkways etc but they are inconvenient and out of the way. Be prepared to drag strollers up and down steps. Last night can't wait to leave. Wait we can't get into our room because our keys have been deactivated. Don't have to check out until the next day. After waiting almost fifteen minutes In the hall we finally got our news keys to get in.This is not a well managed hotel. It has a beautiful environment but it is overshadowed by high prices, poor service and bad quality. If you are coming to Nashville do yourself a favor and look for other Hotels. You can save a lot of headache and MONEY that you can use on other fun stuff.Gave two stars because of the appearance of the hotel.. It is amazing. But that is where it stops. I judge a hotel on the helpfulness and the friendly and welcoming attitude of the staff and this staff has none of those qualities mentioned here.. Boarder line rude and nonchalant attitude with no desire to make you feel welcome.. All that I met so far is non caring  and wanting a big tip. Got no help in unloading my bags from the taxi, the gal who check us in had no clue what she was doing because when I asked her a question she said "whatever".. Great response.. I hope I didn't make a mistake and could have saved money, time and been welcomed somewhere else..This place is way to big and unorganized.. If you like to wait a long time and talk standing outside I. The cold by all means valet your car.. You will wait 20-30 minutes to get your car!!! When Marriott took over quality took a vacation!!!Visitors Beware: Our flight was cancelled so my husband and I decided to visit the hotel and check it out for our next trip to Nashville. Their parking is not well explained. It looked like 20 minutes free and then $5 per hour. We enjoyed waking around and when we left 26 minutes later they charged us $26! Ridiculous. We won't be staying there in the future. Lots of options in Nashville that don't do business like this. They need clearer signage and a reasonable parking fee.This place is huge with a lot to see. We didn't stay here, but I would like to in the future. The rooms looked nice. We walked around and took the boat ride. The boat ride wasn't worth $10, but it made a few in the group happy to do it. They had all the lights up for the holidays already. It was very pretty on the inside. The place offered shopping and restaurants. Unless I plan on booking a hotel room there, I probably won't be back for a while. In my opinion, it's good to see it once.Came here for a business trip. So far it's amazing! The place is huge, I walked around and definitely got lost. There are also multiple stores, gift shops and bars in this one hotel resort. The staff is so amazing, every single waiter or waitress greets me when I walk into a dining hall or conference. They are cheerful and kind. They also are very helpful when I get lost in this place which is very often. It's a great place for business conferences but I've been seeing a lot of families too and people on vacation.For the price of the room we should of had better service and more perks. Free Wi-Fi would of been nice and they also blocked my hotspot from working not a good place.I am glad the FCC found this out.I booked a room a couple of months ago. We arrived there today, travelling from NJ and were turned away because they were overbooked. The clerk at the front desk summoned a manager who apologize matter of factly, telling us that "upper management" regularly screwed things up.She offered to get us a room in a downtown Radisson which we declined.We have traveled quiet extensively and this has never happened before.Very shabby way to treat people.Book somewhere else.
review_content_80: I booked a hotel room for 2 people in a double occupancy room... Instead what I got when I checked in was an atrium room with no real beds. Worst part is I'm an elite marriott member and the worst accommodation/problem solving to meet any reasonable needs. One of us forced to sleep on a pull out and the other on a couch. Awesome job marriott and I'll make sure that my negative experience is heard across the globe. Worst experience, worst customer service, might as well be a motel 6.#marriott #gaylord opryland #customer service #discrimination #negative net promoter #manipulation #trending #pissedoffconsumer #ripoff #gettingscrewed #integrity #loyalty #rewards #18007217033Do not come to this God forsaken place @ Christmas. Traffic is awful. It is not worth it.Huge hotel with shops and small restaurants ($$).  There's short indoor walking distance to the auditorium and ball room.  The hotel accommodated patrons visiting for graduations, proms, bridal parties, clubs, etc.  Many atriums for chilling out and walking.  The hotel has a community feel and at times felt like cruise ship when walking by the rooms.  Fully staffed and had a nice lobby.  My favorite was the island style restaurant with the lamps all around.  Many spots for photos.Very well located hotel! Beautiful inside! Many options of restaurants and you can easily spend your whole stay without leaving the hotel! Because this hotel is so different and beautiful, you can get a big line just to get to valet parking ($30/day) or you can pay $27/day and park yourself... With suck a big hotel, the $3 dollars difference made me use valet parking. If there is a concert in town, this hotel is craziness! The rooms are a bit outdated, like the hairdryer was the one I remember as a kid... A while ago... But overall, great hotel and stay!I have now stayed at the Gaylord Opryland Resort twice, and I have no complaints. I find that their service is great, and their employees are friendly. I traveled on my company's dime, so I can't complain about any of the costs associated with this place, but I will say that eating in the hotel is very expensive if you are paying your own way. Each of the hotel restaurants I ate at (Solario, Cascades, Fuse Sports Bar, Paesano's) served fantastic food, however. Dining at the vast food court and chain restaurants over at the Opry Mills mall is much cheaper. There are also a few stand-alone restaurants just off-property, across McGavock Pike (Cracker Barrel, Caney Fork, etc.)Let it be known that this enclosed resort is sprawling, so you should bring along some comfortable shoes, but the interior space is beautiful and lush. While the Grand 'Ol Opry and the mall are adjacent to the hotel, there isn't much to do in the immediate area, but there is a movie theater/IMAX and Dave & Buster's in the mall. The General Jackson showboat is docked along the Cumberland river, which runs right next to the hotel grounds. The conference I was here for hosted an evening dinner cruise on the General Jackson, and the experience was phenomenal. For those that want to get to downtown Nashville from the Opryland Hotel, they offer a shuttle for a cost. They also offer an airport shuttle that is available at a cost as well. The hotel provides a complimentary complex shuttle that circulates around the property, dropping off at Opry Mills mall, The Grand 'Ol Opry, the General Jackson, and the Inn at Opryland, which is across the street from the resort, and is owned by Gaylord Hotels.I stayed at this hotel while attending a conference just these past few days. I was expecting such a wonderful experience since this Hotel is very popular and I heard many good things about it. To my surprise the stay was as if I was staying at a 1 star hotel.The Room Key: First I would like to say that I understand that the hotel keys are very very sensitive, however for me to have to get a new key at least 4 times when I only stayed three days is beyond ridiculous. I kept the key away from the phones which I was told was a must and still unable to use it. The amount of time it took to get a new one as well was unacceptable.The room: For a hotel that is this beautiful from the outside and inside the rooms to have awful beds and even worse covers is yet another thing that is unacceptable. The amount of money they charge for the stay should cover for at LEAST good sheets and mattress. The restaurants: mediocre food and expensive pricing. Went to RAVELLO and the calamari was rubbery and tasted as if it was Microwaved. Disgusting. I understand this is a very highly rated hotel from most but I definitely would recommend something else for this amount of money a nightThis is not a conference friendly hotel. The food is too expensive for what it is. Vending machines cost 2.50 for a can of soda and then the resort fee doesn't even include the steam-room.  You have to pay 25 extra for it.So my stay was quoted online as $269 a night. When I checked in they said there would be a resort fee of $40 or so which included Internet. Great.On checkout: They had state tax $26. Local tax $28. and some other fees which brought the fees to about $80-100 or so. So 4 nights was around $1400. I don't mind paying but the service sucked. Housekeeping would come and offer to clean your room just about when you are read for bed! It just wasn't worth it plus the hidden fees. The room directions are confusing and everyone got lost trying to find their rooms. People talked about southern hospitality??? What southern hospitality? All the workers are from Egypt! Pros: The carpet was nice. I liked the water falls. I liked that we can walk to the mall. I liked the garden area. I liked the shoe shinning service near the magnolia lobby. The rooms service food was great. I ordered a pizza. Would be nice if they had attentive staff who is aware that almost everyone will get lost their first time and try to help guests to their rooms. Not coming back here.Beautiful place! So magical during Thanksgiving time with all Christmas decorations. This place is perfect for family stay. I took my family to a sushi dinner in the hotel but result was a little disappointing. The fish did not taste fresh.I stayed here for a conference and it is a beautiful hotel. The rooms were clean and it was great to stay at but a few things to know about before going there. First of all, it is the most confusing hotel to walk around in. After 4 days there, I finally figured out how to get to my room without getting lost. Secondly, just know that you will wait in line to check in and check out pretty much every day of the week. Thirdly, while we were there I think there were like three other conferences happening and like a bazillion groups of kids there. I get it, it's summer and groups are coming to Nashville because it's a great city but don't think you're going to you're going to have a relaxing, quiet getaway. There were kids everywhere, running around at night having fun. They do offer shuttles to places for free and one to downtown for 20 bucks which is very useful.Overly pricey rooms, but the gardens are great to explore and keep you all-inclusive for a weekend getaway. Nice hotel. Would return again.We booked an atrium view several months ago for a special occasion and we are looking at the side of a building.  See attached picture for our view. If they put you behind a shed that should not qualify as an atrium view in my opinion.Very disappointed with my room. The bathroom is disgusting ... Mildew in the grout in numerous places, bathroom wallpaper pulling away from wall. Just gross. On ground floor with a door that opens into the parking lot. I might as well be staying in a motel! So not safe! And I'm seriously let down too...I stayed here for my first anniversary and it was so great. Is it because I'm paying a groups rate for a teaching conference? Either way, very disappointed.If you are a fan of long winding walks to get around the hotel, slow food service, over priced items, then Gaylord is for you.  Where do I start? (business trip for a conference)1) Breakfast a the Cascades, at least one coffee cup or glass was dirty at the table each morning.2) Breakfast buffet, besides being over priced with limited choices, the item were usually not hot.  I am sure some people like cold biscuits and scrambled eggs.3)  Findely Irish Pub, over an hour to get sandwiches, while we watched other tables get food.4) Thermostats are limited to how cold the room can get, I know this is being picky but I like to be able to get the room cooler than 70. 5) Since it is a 'resort' type hotel, then everything is nickle and dime extra charges.  For example, I will FedEx items to myself at the hotel that I will be staying, for hold pick up when I check in.  Since FedEx has a small office near the convention section, they have an agreement with Gaylord that item will not be sent to the hotel for pick up.  Instead you have to pick up at the onsite FedEx, and FedEx gets to add a 'handling fee' for holding the package.  6) $15 / day 'resort' fee a way to make pay high mark up for limited wi-fi service, limited to your room.  I fyou want wi-fi in the hotel area that is extra.  Even for the Elite Marriott members, which is free at other Marriott's.I would not return to this hotel 'resort' again.Wow!  The concierge needs training ASAP!  Literally refused to move over behind the counter to put himself in front of the customer.  Your not working the register at McDonald's....adjust to the customer.  The lazy draw was the no look pass of the document we requested.  I even said, "really? Aren't you going to say anything? Close us out? Thank you have a great day?"  The concierge just looked down. I was too much in a rush to address it. Worst service ever.  All the staff at the hotel seem "over it" not motivated and irritated with the guests.  Lazy waitresses or loud talking waiters at the fine dining restaurant.  Like really?  Do you need to shout about my foi gras? When I say I didn't like it you ask me to be specific....  Well here's specific....it sucked.  Tell that to the chef.  Everything he said was so loud!  It could have been the blaring band music....yeah that was appropriate.  He actually said they "normally" close us when a band is here.  I also felt it to be strange that when I called for reservations earlier that morning the staff member told me there was nothing available at 8:30 or 9 but 915 was available. I came at 8:45 to have a cocktail before hand. I walked right in and proceeded to look at the restaurant empty tables. I'm not sure if the staff just don't want to work?  Avoid this say staffed hotel.Grand indeed! It's Texas sized! Huge! 10 x's bigger than the Las Vegas Bellagio Atrium. This had 3 different huge, high ceiling atriums, a boat ride like Disney's Pirate's of the Caribbean, Twin Waterfalls, tropical lush garden paths that snaked around with mini waterfalls along the way and it had a skywalk to take it all in from above.  There is fine dining throughout the property.  This place is gorgeous, grand and gosh darn awesome to take out of town guests like me! Nashville is sweet like sweet tea! Love Gaylord Opryland Hotel3 years ago had to come here for a work meeting and ended up lost and confused in the bowels of the hotel. I tripped on stairs and ended up in the ER. And my work is having another meeting here this week. I leave tomorrow and I'm dreading being back at this hotel so reminiscent of the movie the shining.Full disclosure: I've never actually stayed at the Opryland hotel, but I'm sure I'd enjoy it.  The facilities are beautiful and awe-inspiring.  The Boy Scouts of America held their national meeting in Nashville this year, so I volunteered to help out.  I was on-premises for four days, and enjoyed every minute of it.  I even ate at their burger joint one day.  Sure, it was expensive, but I enjoyed it nonetheless.I was very impressed with how efficient the staff was.    It's obvious that they are practiced in serving a lot of people in a short time, all while making everyone feel special.Tip!  Call for military rates if you can.  You'll save $$$ at a phenomenal hotel!  But definitely get your food from off-campus, otherwise, be prepared to pay.What can I say that hasn't been written already?  Nothing, it's huge.But here's the thing...I stayed here BEFORE and AFTER Marriott took it over.  Let's just say it was better and more personal BEFORE.  Yes, you can still get the same great service etc, but there was more staff around to help before.  I'll be backThe Gaylord Opry was underwhelming. The 52 (or so) acre establishment was like a maze! The layout itself was confusing and we needed a map to get from any two points in the hotel. After we located our room we found that it had not be throughly cleaned. There was still trash left from the previous occupants as well as smudges on the windows, lamps, remote controls. The room looked nice at a glance but overall just felt drab. The food I would give 2 stars-- tasteless and overpriced. Overall my stay was overpriced and unimpressive.This place is HUGE and the only reason I can think to stay here is because you're attending a conference.  Seriously, it makes no sense to vacation at a place like this because you could stay inside all day and really it wouldn't matter what town you're in.  Rooms were fine and comfortable.  If you do have to be stuck at a conference for a week, it's nice to feel like you're outside, I guess.  There are a ton of restaurants on sight.  Mexican cantina was decent, and the Library is a great place for cocktails.

review_content: This Doubletree Hotel appears nicer online, than what it ends up being in real life - isn't that always how it goes? The price was right for our quick trip to Nashville - and it's walking distance to all of the bars and music venues - so we ended up here for the night.Pro's:1. - all of the staff we encountered were super friendly. Valet, Doorman, Front Desk and the in room dining attendant.2.- The lobby bar/restaurant is nice and spacious and very well utilized by the patrons3. The cookies - you can't go wrong with Doubletree cookies - not ever!Con's:1. The hotel is old, dated and while somewhat refreshed - seems like they've put lipstick on a pig.2. The sink stopper was broken - and the top had been unscrewed. I fixed it - but there was definitely some toothpaste residue.3. Taking a shower is like being in a hot tub - it fills up with water fast and barely drains.4. The popcorn ceiling in the bathroom is coming off- so it looks really tackyOverall, the hotel is A-OK; however with some significant investment by ownership - it could be the jewel it probably once was. If you're a Hilton Honors member - then this is a good option - otherwise, I'd probably stay somewhere else.I tend to like Doubletree properties when I travel, but this one is exceptionally poor.They didn't understand how to accept a third party booking (Hotels.com for instance). They looked befuddled, and did not have a supervisor on duty.The rooms were wretched, and smelled like spilled beer. If you're looking for a discount room for a bachelor party, you could do worse. But, if you're a business traveler, have a family, or want to relax, I would really look elsewhere. It's still a bit of a hike to Broadway, uphill.After a 15 hour day of driving, we pulled off in Nashville to find a hotel to stay at. I've always heard good things about Double Tree hotels, so we decided to stop there. The front desk worker was very nice and friendly, however it didn't seem like she new what she was doing. Check in process was quick which was nice; however once we got up to the room, we were completely disgusted. After putting our bags down we had noticed several hairs on both beds, hair in the shower, poop on the toilet, dust on everything and dust ruffles that were half way hanging off of the bed on the ground. It almost looked as if nothing had been cleaned, just remade the bed with dirty sheets. After calling down to the front desk, they set us up with another room. Even though we were grossed out, we decided to give them another chance. This time, the first thing we did was strip the beds and check the bathroom. We found hairs in both beds again along with stains all over the sheets. Though the bathroom in the second room was better, the beds were not. And after a 15 hour drive and $200 price tag, we decided there was no way we were going to sleep there. We were very disappointed in the rooms and the fact that none of the workers seemed to feel bad about our terrible experience. I would never recommend this hotel to anyone.Service was honestly really rude while I was checking in...room was fine, but the bathroom door was broken. Overall, it wasn't the best experience for me with Hilton...though they do have delicious cookies!This review is for Andrew, the gentleman at the Concierge desk. After a cancelled flight, our party of 6 had to find a new location to stay overnight. We found a great deal on Hotels.com and decided to book it. Once we got to the hotel, we headed down the the Concierge desk to try to find some activities and dinner plans. We were on a bachelorette party as well. Andrew was so friendly (and hilarious) and made a couple of outstanding recommendations for us. He called a restaurant to ensure that there was live music and made reservations. He spent a lot of time chatting with us and gave us some great ideas for activities. After we got back from dinner, we found a bottle of wine and chocolate covered strawberries from Andrew in our room. Super thoughtful and it made our stay that much more enjoyable. we love you, Andrew!Greeted with a warm smile and a warm chocolate chip cookie at check-in, we knew immediately we were at the right place. We booked through Hotel Tonight and got an affordable deal for our girls' weekend in Nashville. However, you'll have to tack on a $30 PER NIGHT parking fee. I would suggest researching cheaper parking spaces prior to arrival. Our room was perfect for our needs - two double beds, plenty of mirrors for getting ready, and an spotless modern bathroom. We couldn't have asked for a better location. We never needed a taxi and were within walking distance of all our itinerary stops. No issues during our two-night stay!Easy check in, friendly staff, clean room, hot shower and within walking distance to nightlife attractions - what more could you want? A cookie when you check in? Yeah, well you get that, too!Seriously - had a great stay here while working a tradeshow at Music City Center a few weeks back and have no complaints.This hotel was great for our downtown Nashville needs. There's a convenient airport shuttle for your business travelers as well as a local downtown shuttle (tip your shuttle driver!) free from the Doubletree. I enjoy the early check in capabilities online for Hilton Honors members - I liked that I could select my rooms prior to arrival. Makes it easy when you have larger groups traveling together. The front desk folks were super hospitable - they held packages for us, make accommodations for late arrivals (extra key for that one drunk friend that got in really late) and even allowed a whole bunch of "can i have a cookie?" requests. If you're up earlier than the hotel Starbucks location (6a on weekdays, 7a on weekends), they'll hook you up with some coffee for free, just ask. Great perk after a long weekend before heading to BNA.The rooms were solid - I was under the impression that Doubletree hotels were all allergy-friendly, but that's not the case at this location. Be sure to ask for them to de-feather your room prior to arrival. I had this noted on my HH profile, but still had to ask again at check-in.Free wifi for HH members, but paid for non-HH. Overall, great stay and will happily stay here again in the future.This was conveniently located if you want to tour downtown.But I have to say downtown was a let down!!Not the hotels fault that the town desperately needs work! Always go through internet booking...we got $167 a night versus $209 through trivago before the million dollar add ons for taxes!!! Valet parking is another $30 daily.Our room was nice, clean & comfortable with the minor problem of bathtub drainage.Water pressure in the shower was wonderful. Restaurant food was average. I had the nachos made with "cheese whiz" I would not recommend. Bar was decent and live music was good both nights.A filming of the Nashville show was going on outside that made it inconvenient for us peon guest! So if you need to stay downtown this was probably a good choice. I think I saw enough in 1 trip!!My room was clean. Very nice lobby. Staff was pleasant to deal with. Breakfast was ok, but not special.First, holy cow $30 PER DAY to park?! That's ludicrous!!! I did not tip anyone and strongly advise against anyone tipping when you're forced to pay $30 a day. That's just nuts. I went and got some take out and tried to sit in the lobby (at a non-restaurant table) to eat. A snotty server at the restaurant told me I could not eat in the lobby, I needed to leave. She acid I couldn't eat Anywhere in the lobby. So I went to the desk and the manager said absolutely, have a seat. So I ate dinner, but then on the elevator back up to my room, this young guy started telling me a story about how he lost $2,500 at a strip club last night. I thought he was going to hit me up for money, but he didn't. Instead he got off on my floor and I noticed he had a gun on his hip. I am in Tennessee, I get it, I've got no problem with guns, but is just so unusual to see some redneck walking around in the hotel with one who isn't police or something. The room was fairly quiet, but the bed was rather convex, like they hadn't flipped the mattress in a few years. Free WiFI and newspapers, a plus. Expensive parking, uncomfortable beds, and some strange interactions drop this down to 2 stars.I've never seen a double bed used in a single room before. That was the start. Tried to order a pizza to the room per the advertisement downstairs- no one answered after 3 calls.Went downstairs to order it- waited 45 mins for it to come- rudely treated the entire time. The service here is horrible. Sad because they have a great location but not worth being treated poorly.Valet costs $26/night, but they're slow. Oh and if they can't fit all the cars in their lot they park you car in the lot across the street. Gym has free weights, two stationary bikes, seated bike, three elliptical machines, three treadmills (if you're over six feet, don't hit your head on the ceiling!), Precor FTS Glide, stretch trainer, and mats.The rooms are ok - I don't feel like you get what you pay form. We had a room that was at the end of the building and was in the shape of a triangle. The view was nice, but the room was meh. The toilet and shower were in one room but the sink was in the main area - no privacy. The pullout bed was like sleeping on coils. I was simply underwhelmed.This review is mostly about the restaurant at the Doubletree, Fourth and U. The hotel itself has been good, what you would expect for a Doubletree. Room is clean and nice. Service is good. Valet staff works well. The restaurant would be a big disappointment when you consider you're staying in a Doubletree. My waitress was pleasant and did a good job, but the menu itself was VERY limited. And the food quality was average at best. I ate dinner at Hotel Indigo (The District) last night and was much more impressed, to the degree I will book there vs. the Doubletree next time. Offer a good steak, a nice fish, and some chicken. Dress it up with some memorable sides. Unremarkable might be the best descriptor and when you are paying for the Doubletree in this downtown location you expect a little something more.This is your standard DoubleTree hotel, but the location is amazing. We were able to park our car and not use it the entire time. Word of advice, park in the structure across the street for only $24 a day. Hotel parking is way more expensive, you have to tip and it takes at least 30 minutes to get your car from the valet guy. Hotel itself was clean. the rooms are good sized. Ask for a room higher up. We were on the 7th floor (I think it has 9 total) and had a great view of the city and mountains. Staff members were friendly and helpful. We had no problems with our stay.I not a fan of writing bad reviews but I owe to all the yelpers to be honest. I've given 2 stars (but really wanted to give only 1) but that is for one of the gentleman bartenders, the shuttle drivers and the sweet late night security guard. The hotel room wasn't so bad but they did not have any extra sheets/blankets for the pull out couch in our suite. We left our towels hanging around the room (5 of us) but they still took them and washed them. Ugh! Aren't they only supposed to do that if they are on the floor in the bathroom? I'm from California and given the drought and my always "reduce, reuse recycle" attitude, I just find that frustrating. But the real reason I'm giving the low score? I left a pair of expensive shoes behind as we had to run out the of room very early in the morning after a late night out. I called on 2 separate occasions and was transferred both times to the lost and found department. I got their voicemail both times that asked to allow 24 hours for a return phone call. I left a detailed message each time and never received a return phone call. I then followed up with a call again to the hotel and asked to not be transferred to the lost and found but requested that they help me out to ensure I get a response. The gentleman was trying to be helpful (but not at all friendly) and eventually told me that he could not guarantee that he would be able to call me back. I asked to be transferred to a supervisor, of course who did not answer the phone. After yet another detailed message, no return phone call. All of this occurred with in a week and a half of our stay. When we booked the hotel, it was because all of the other hotels in the area were sold out. I get it. You go were you get the best of everything-location, accommodation and service. This place really misses the mark for service. They've left a very bad taste in my mouth and therefore I would NOT recommend staying here.If I could give negative stars I would. This place was horrible. So my friends and I just got back from this shack. Stayed for two nights at a ridiculous amount of 299.00 dollars a night. Valet was nice but nothing above 1-2 starsHotel was horrible. The front desk guy who greeted us was rude and very unfriendly.Room needs updating and cosmetic work done. The shower heads at midget height. Last shower I took this morning the tub wouldn't drain. Cleaning lady came in yesterday unannounced while I was sleeping and my buddy was watching tv. What we thought was a free buffet ended up being crappy food at 17.00 dollars a plate. " which by the way should be free. Pool is one step above my bathtub. It was cold and dirty. Kept on seeing hairs floating by me. Place is close the the strip but that's about it. Parking is 30 dollars a day which seems way high to me. For almost 800 dollars for two nights I will be looking to take my business elsewhere if visiting Nashville again. You've been warned....I had a horrible experience at the Doubletree Nashville Downtown during my stay 9/13-9/14.First off I took an Uber from the airport to the hotel. The Uber driver had to drop me off the block before the hotel because the valet line was back out of the drive, through an intersection and into the next block. My girlfriend, who was driving, arrived about 10 minutes after I did, and sat in that same valet line for at least 25 minutes.Upon reaching the lobby, I was greeted with a line stretching through the lobby and around the Starbucks in the back of the lobby. I stood in line for at least 30 minutes to reach the front, I say "at least" because that's from the time I decided to start keeping track of the time. It was longer, but I'm not sure the exact time. The funniest part was watching new people walk in and the look on their faces when they realize how long the line is and the colorful comments associated with that realization.I will give the staff credit. There was someone, I'm assuming the MOD, walking the line of people, offering free drinks.The hotel featured no dedicated HHonor's elite check in line, when I questioned the staff member walking the line he simply replied, no we don't.I have stayed in much larger hotels in much bigger cities (NYC, Vegas, etc.) and have never experienced a check in situation like this. In reading other reviews online this is apparently a regular occurrence. Otherwise the hotel was okay and was in a good location. However this pre-check in experience will lead me to look elsewhere when in the city again.Weekend trip to Nashville with friends. Great hotel! Location is about three blocks from Broadway. Great service! Pretty good standard rooms.Did a three star Priceline deal and were placed here. Great location-close to Broadway and music museums. The lobby and sitting areas are modern eclectic. The rooms could use a little updating but the beds were comfortable. Overall with the Priceline price it was a nice stay.
review_content_20: Typically I have no issues with Hilton hotels, but during our stay there temperatures were extremely low and our heater wasn't working. They were kind enough to offer us another room on the same floor but the heat also did not work in that room, maybe a floor issue? They did make an attempt to come up and fix it but nothing changed. A little disappointed by it!This location is in downtown Nashville and other than typical city parking challenges, it was a very nice hotel with excellent service and a very nice clean room. I would recommend parking across the street and save $10. The parking garage was easy to access and you didn't have to deal with valets. This is a great location if you want to explore downtown Nashville without dealing with parking your car. They also had city bikes which would be a great alternative to walking. During our stay, there's a Thursday night event with live music and loads of food trucks. It was crowded, noisy and wonderful!Stayed here on a Saturday night and had a great visit.  Purchased through Priceline at a bargain.  Staff was courteous, friendly and efficient.  Be sure and ask for parking prices, valet parking was $30+tax.  Free shuttle carried us to the Grand Ole Opry at the Ryman and picked us up- very convenient.Rooms were clean, beds were very comfortable.  Cookies at check-in are a real treat.Rooms were clean and the hotel smelled nice, reminded me of that Vegas hotel smell, kinda tropical.  All the staff were friendly and polite.  They have a shuttle which will pretty much take you anywhere within ten miles for free.  This was a plus because unfortunately we had to park our car and trailer with motorcycle's at the Hilton downtown because the Double Tree would not take the trailer.  The shuttle driver was very cordial and helpful.  Very good location near Printers Alley and Broadway St.My family and I try to stay here anytime we are in Nashville. We have never had a bad experience. I love the location, and the staff are ALWAYS friendly and helpful.The beds are comfortable.  The location is incredible.  The construction that starts at 8am on a Saturday is unacceptable.  When we called the front desk to complain and asked for a room change, we were told that it's on floors 2-8 and we would hear it anywhere.  It's like a jackhammer and it's insane.  When on vacation, one usually likes to sleep in a bit and relax.  Impossible to do here.  DO NOT BOOK until construction is over.Also--$30 per night valet fee?  Come on now.Typical DoubleTree hotel with an amazing location.  Stayed here on business.  A couple blocks to the nightlife and easy to get in and out of. I am a Marriott person, so I am a little biased.  The beds are nowhere near as comfortable as Marriott beds, but the room itself is nice.  I will say my room was sandwiched between a bachelorette and bachelor party.  This made for noisy neighbors, but not the hotel's fault.  It seemed like the whole hotel was overrun with "button down stripey dudes" and "bachelorettes on the loose".  This made for incredible people watching.  So much pent up frustration and energy poring out of these 20-30 something's....I love it.  Nothing better than standing in line at the Starbucks (onsite) at 10am and hearing all of the stories: "i could have totally banged that one chick if her friend didn't interfere!"  It is a basic bitch shit show.Stayed here a couple nights last week while visiting Nashville. It was reasonably priced in comparison to other downtown hotels, but we didn't mind the few walk block down to Broadway to save about $50 per night.Everyone working was really kind to us.. definitely went out of their way to say hi and smile, which I really appreciate. Clean rooms, and in a great location. Not much more I'd want!A four block walk to Broadway and they also have a shuttle to take you and pick you up.A television that never came on, a shower without a shelf/tray to hold your shampoo, soap, etc. and a no option, high dollar valet fee. Add these highlights to a pretty healthy room charge for an outdated hotel, you get the idea that there are better options when staying in downtown Nashville.Susie Hughes behind the bar literally saved my hangover.  The woman is amazing. Transfer her to the Chicago location and I will visit weekly !terrible service. failed to inform us of $30+ valet service. we just drove up and they were all "we'll take it!" with NO explanation. $3.50 sodas. maid knocked on our door at 8:50 am which pissed me off. upon checkout, person at desk was curt and rude. sat down in lobby to read a book from their bookshelf, books were glued together. TERRIBLE. oh, and $17 breakfast. don't give this hotel your money.This is a story of two rooms. One was at first appearance to be in good order. Then found out the phone was not working and one wash cloth for two people to share. The caulking around the tub was a bit moldy and looked messy.  Otherwise a good room. However, the second room was a bit stale and smelled very moldy. They said only one room with a Murphy bed was available or they could spray the current room with Lysol. For my friends with asthma...not a good option. Parking was a little pricey at $30 a night. On the bright side, close to downtown and they have a shuttle that runs from 7am to midnight.Hectic entrance area with tiny turnaround driveway and loads of people standing around waiting for their cars.  Not the best first impression.  But one of the valet guys is really cute...that bumps it up half a star...he was on duty when I left, so if he was there at the beginning that may have been a better first impression.  Thanks for finding my car which was hidden behind the entrance so I could leave.Rooms are definitely functional and not fancy, a bit tired looking and in need of renovation.  The bathroom is tiny, with the sink vanity outside the bathroom with the shower and toilet.  And no room safe...what gives? In this day and age, with all the electronics that people carry around, there should be a room safe.  I had to hide my iPad and computer, put up the do not disturb doorknob sign and hope for the best. The last day we were there, the do not disturb sign on the door disappeared, luckily, we were checking out.Security is lax, with all the people coming and going.  Our first morning, a homeless was riding in the elevator with us as we headed out...smelled horrible...not sure which floor he came from but he got off on the floor with the pool.Definite plus for this hotel is the location...very close to everything in downtown Nashville.  I easily found many restaurants only a block or two away and many touristy places to visit also within walking distance.Really not happy at all. Made arrangements last night for shuttle. Was told to be in lobby at 550pm for ride to airport. Was told they would call out my nane. Noone came. When I asked evening desk staff about the shuttle he didn't know anything about shuttle. Finally had to beg him to call for me since doubletree staff made arrangements and I didn't know who to call. He called and told me they were closed. No assistance with other arrangements. I could tell I was bothering him. Sour note to leave Nashville.Paper thin walls..neither you can talk at normal voice without disturbing others not you can help hear others talk in their room!!! Bathrooms poorly lit... Not worth the $$180+ per night!!!!Help was friendly. Room was clean. Bathroom needs maintenance ASAP. I addressed the shower not draining water they sent a man to room he was in and out in 3-5 mins. The next morning I had to shower while standing in filthy water with black stuff floating around. (Not an exaggeration at all) complained again while checking out and got a "thank you for telling us" even after I showed a picture of the disgust. For the price I would try something else.The location of this hotel was great and the valet people/shuttle driver were extremely pleasant but that was about all.  We went to Nashville for a party and we were suppose to have 4 rooms next to each other and they were not.  The biggest problem we came across was when looking for a lost shoe under the bed I came across POOP!  Yes it was extremely disturbing to know our room was not cleaned thoroughly before we entered.  2 managers came up and picked up the poop and just said sorry and walked out.  That was it.  We felt that they didn't treat us fairly because we were young females who came for a Bachelorette party.  We felt we should have been assured someone was coming in to clean our room.  Not to mention the bartender who was working downstairs was extremely rude.  Good thing Nashville has lots to do and places to go because being in that hotel was not enjoyable at all.  I gave it 2 stars because the bell hops, and shuttle drivers deserve a raise and made our horrible experience bearable.I stayed here a full week for a conference and it was alright. Not as fancy as I thought it would be considering it's the double tree, but it wasn't bad either! The staff was friendly and the food at their restaurant was phenomenal. We had most of our meals in the hotel because everything on the menu was so great. I honestly think that was the best part about the place! Rooms were clean but the maids always came to clean really late in the day. They also left a nasty body oder smell when they were finished with the room. It was gross, a hotel so fancy should at least provide deodorant for the staff lol Anyway, it was ok. Perfect for a business trip.Overall, a really nice stay. Started out a bit rocky. Pulled in around 11 pm Friday night and the valet guy was on his own.  ONE guy on long holiday weekend. Seriously? That wasn't cool for him. Finally got the car valeted the tandem bike in storage and the dirt bike we brought all situated.  Hit the bar for a drink and she calls "last call" at 1158 pm on a Friday night with what looked like a wedding party of 12 still in the bar...we got one round and she didn't turn another couple who came in a minute after us.  Still odd. Before bed we put a hanger notice on our door for breakfast @ 9 am via room service.  930 we called and they answered asking, " oh that was your card?"  It didn't look promising we were going to get our ordered meal from the night before.  They offered us a free breakfast available downstairs which we passed on as they are already complimentary.  Enough said.  From there it got better.  The staff at the desk came to know us rather well and this was both am and pm staff. Very welcoming with greetings as we came and went and we felt it to be genuine. The bed rocked.  The shower pressure even better. Housekeeping was great. The location was perfect. Minutes from a short walk to Broadway. Would totally stay again.  The front desk staff secured this recommendation.
review_content_40: This hotel is beyond inept when it comes to the front desk!! Do not stay here if you can help it! Three reserved -in-advanced rooms, all on one credit card, has resulted in six different guests being harassed, overcharged ( a $50 holding fee was charged to one persons bank as $850 for one example: thanks to Kelly at the front desk!) some guests were told they couldn't have keys even though they were on the list to get keys. One room was told they had to pay again. A Fiasco beyond what this space can hold! Every time we think it's resolved, someone different calls from the front desk saying the room already charged needs to be paid for again. Great Bachelorette party weekend, but feeling VERY regretful about the poor hotel choice ! Unlike any hotel stay any of the twelve of us have ever endured.The location for this hotel is amazing.  Sadly, the it stops there.  My husband and I are Hilton Honors diamond status, so he had booked a room for two nights for a girls weekend with my friends.  Upon checking in, my name wasn't on the reservation, so Tiffany, at the front desk, gave me an incredibly hard time checking in.  While I appreciate her concern for security, my ID address matched my husbands account, as well as the credit card that was used to hold the reservation.  My husband was currently in flight, traveling for work, so I was unable to get a hold of him for him to "clarify" that I was indeed allowed to check in to the hotel.  I showed her emails forwarded from my husband with the reservation and also offered my husband's HH number, but she was truly awful to work with.  She offered for me to speak to a supervisor, which I accepted, and of course he allowed me to check in.  I was humiliated, and her snarky comments throughout the remainder of the check in process were  totally uncalled for.  She didn't give me breakfast coupons, so I had to make another trip to the front desk to get them.  I will never stay here again and I intend to call Hilton and let them know.This hotel is convenient to downtown and within walking distance to lots of stuff.  The price is lower than the rest of the downtown hotels, so was not expecting the quality to be as high.  The lobby is a little confusing, as the entry level is not the check in, but you need to go up the stairs to get to the main level and the elevators to the rooms.  There is an elevator that will take you up to the checkin area, but it is not really clearly marked or located.The lobby and restaurant look nice and are typical of Hilton, however the breakfast buffet is cheap and appears to be of low quality, closer to what I would expect at a holiday inn or similar line, not a Hilton brand.  We opted to go out for breakfast and I left a review of the 417 Union where we went for breakfast.  A Plus for having a Starbucks in the lobby!The hotel smelled slightly like disinfectant when we first arrived, and then when I got to my room, the room had a very strong smell of bleach.  The smell was so strong that after a few minutes in room, my asthma started to act up and I was forced to go ask for a room change.  They quickly moved me up to the sixth floor and apologized for the inconvenience.  The new room didn't smell of bleach, but had a slightly musty odor, that I assume was moisture related.  Overall the room was average, but nothing special.  A little cramped with the two beds and the bathroom was quite small for two people.  The paint was peeling on the bathroom ceiling, and the overall feeling was that the hotel had seen better days.  Noticed that when I checked in, there was a dirty plate in the hall, and about 3 hours later, it was still there when I went to move my stuff to a new room after dinner.  I even saw at least on of the hotel staff walk by the plate and leave it there, so not impressed with the cleanliness of the hotel.I would not choose this hotel as my first choice, but a reasonable price for a good location.  Service was good and the people were all polite.Pretty disappointing. In room dining-don't even bother. They delivered our food to the wrong room, threw it away and it was 45min before we got restless and called down curious.  They gave us $25 worth of vouchers to use the next day. We ordered breakfast, two American breakfasts and a waffle, the balance was $29. Food was sub par. They didn't even bring ketchup and Tabasco or water with the meal. Explore other options. The rooms are average. Kind of dated.****EDIT: The manager called me after I posted this and was very apologetic. He said the hotel is due for a renovation soon and the kitchen staff was being trained. He promised to credit my Hilton Honors account with extra points. It's a week later and no points. I'm not calling him back about it. It is consistent with the rest of my stay though and I'm leaving it a 1 star rating.****Original Review:A very disappointing stay. I was there three nights. I'll not stay at this hotel again.The Good: The front desk staff were helpful and friendly. The bell boys were also helpful and friendly.The Bad: The room was really dated. The "free" internet was SLOW. I had a room with 2 beds and that was a good thing. The first one was very uncomfortable. I changed beds in the night. The 2nd bed was not much better but enough I could sleep. The AC unit appeared to have a mind of its own. At one point I just turned it off so the room temp would remain stable. The food from the kitchen isn't bad but it's not really good either. I ate 2 meals downstairs and ordered 4 for the room (1 of which never arrived).The Ugly: I ordered breakfast in-room three times. The last two times I ordered the night before because the first time I ordered it took 45 min to arrive. The first breakfast eggs were cold and they put the butter packs on a hot plate. The aluminum packs were completely empty when I opened them. The butter had melted and drained out. The 2nd breakfast was ordered the night before for 7:30AM delivery. It arrived at almost 8. They had subbed the cereal without asking me first and the yogurt was HORRIBLE. I can't comment on the quality of the 3rd breakfast. It never arrived. I also ordered it the night before for a 7:20 delivery time. At 7:45 I called and was told they did not have the order. The person was not even apologetic. The dinner I ordered in room took over an hour to arrive and was not bad but not really good either. Also one of the elevators had door opening issues. Twice it took me to my floor, opened the doors about 6 inches several times, closed and promptly returned me to the lobby. This happened on two different days and it was reported to maintenence the first time.Ok, not great. Good value for the price though. Clean (enough) rooms and friendly staff. I was really disappointed in the food. I had the breakfast buffet and a few catered meals (was here for a conference) and every meal tasted the same. I would stay again, but eat somewhere else for sure.The lobby is clean and elegant, which is what a hotel should be. At first, it may seem odd that the main lobby floor is actually on the second floor, but you get used to it. There is a concierge and a door greeter, which I like. There also a couple of shops and a Starbucks on the main lobby floor.As a diamond member, I get free breakfast, which was good. I actually sat in the wrong area for free breakfast, but I decided to seat myself because I didn't know where the host/hostess was. I waited 5 minutes at the host's stand, but chose a table with an outlet. The host initially tried to move me, but I declined, explaining I already had my luggage and everything else settled at the table. He finally gave up and understood.Valet parking, taxes, and the room were a total of $191.85, but this is a beautiful hotel. There are also places to eat within walking distance. I am definitely staying here again!Rooms are clean but dated showing signs of wear. Front desk staff are polite and friendly. They do not however have a Hilton Honors desk at reception so check in can be long at busy times. My rate had breakfast included and supported the usual fare in buffet form. The servers at breakfast are hit and miss. Some care, others clearly do not. During my stay the person cooking at the omelet station certainly was not a morning person. Overall reasonable valueFor starters it's under construction. Failed to mention that anywhere. They checked strangers into our room and were rude to us about it. The front desk says they'll do something and then they won't do it. They lost my package and continued to say different lies-- it's in your room, it's in the mailroom, it's in the mailbox, it didn't get delivered, and finally it got delivered to the hotel next door". They found it after I left and now Eli the manager won't return my calls about it. At least reimburse me for your mistake!  Breakfast was another fiasco. We, along with 10 other guests waited to be seated for way too long. Staff walked by and didn't even acknowledge us. It was beyond frustrating. We went to starbucks. Save yourself a headache and don't stay here!!! NOT a vacation spotA great center hotel. Wonderful staff and a top notch room. Everyone was incredibly helpful during a crazy business visit. A great Chicken Salad and solid wine list too. The windows are big and give you a cool view of the city and other buildings. One of my favorite Hiltons on this book tour this summer by far and will be back again!Seeing as I did not pay for my stay at the Doubletree, I say it's magnificent!! But my loyal and superawesomebetterthanyours bridesmaids DID pay for my room, and they had mucho problemos. Checking in: 45 minutes. Lady behind the counter, do you not see the case of Coors Light with blue bottle labels as cold as the Rockies slowing fading to white? They're fading because you're taking so long to eventually tell my posse you won't split the bill between them. You're literally turning blue labels to white with your frustrating explanation as to why your hotel isn't very accommodating. Your hotel also managed to lose our request for a joining suit. How do you have our reservation but not our request? Is that very hospitable? No. I have a hideously ugly rhinestoned cowboy hat with veil and Elton John-inspired Bride-To-Be sunglasses to strap on and you are WASTING PRECIOUS TIME! Adjoined double-bed rooms later and we're ready to get our party on, in front of the pool with floor to ceiling glass windows, where a bachelor party is taking place. Perfect. They won't mind seeing us waive around our phallical goodies, will they? In addition to prime peepshow quality windowing, we had our take of lustrous bathrooms. My room featured water-stained ceilings with paint chipping, while our adjoining bathroom looked like monkeys with a lot of frustration to vent had stayed there. For a week. Kudos for having a pool, in-house Starbucks (that closes WAY early), and prompt service staff, but the check-in was a no-go and the bathrooms were sick. I expected better from a Doubletree.When we went there on the first night the only parking at  the hotel was valet and at 1:00 am they called us and said there was a upgrade for suite so we packed used and went and then when we went to our new room there was someone sleeping in there. Not a good hotel but if you go keep the room you get and also the valet person was the only nice person.Doubletree sits in the heart of downtown nashville it's convenient to everything and walking distance as well I love the professionals at guest services and always enjoy a quiet place to stay and enjoy life downtown as well. The Breakfest bar is great they have a chef and will cook to order.parking is a little steep @28.21 per night but there are other garages down the street.The guy who checked us in was great, but other than that the staff here is awful.  I am a long time Hilton rewards member and I tried to add my card, but the lazy employee was "too busy" to look me up to have my account added.  The hotel is overpriced at $200+ a night and is somewhat of a brothel.  We were on a floor full of bachelor parties and there was constant noise.  There was also an elevator down for most of the weekend and it took close to 15 minutes once to get an elevator.  You would think that the hotel would get someone out within 24 hours to fix an elevator.  It was down almost the entire time during our 3 day stay.  If you want a nice peaceful Nashville hotel then look elsewhere.My husband and I were road tripping Tennessee and Kentucky. We decided to stay at the hotel because of the location, unfortunately that is all it offers. When we requested a refrigerator to be brought to the room, because we were traveling with perishables, we were told all refrigerators were given out already.( it was 3:30pm, a half hour after check in on a Wednesday, questionable) Plus, my husband and I felt like there was actually a caste system about the hotel. We suspect if we had a platinum or gold standing with them, there would have been better service. They obviously cater to business people and not the worn out traveler. We ask for a higher floor room, we were given a floor 2 room. This is the same floor for the pool. I expressed a sensitivity to chlorine, and was brushed off. Told to let them know if it really does bother me. Overall, not happy with the stay for only one day ... Ps- if you stay and need to park a car; drop your luggage off then park your car yourself , save yourself the $30 a day charge. There are numerous lots that charge $10 a day in the area.All in all... A great hotel! Excellent location and staff was friendly and very helpful! I visited the front desk daily for something or another and was always assisted quickly and with a smile. The decor in the rooms could definitely be better (hence the 4 and not 5 stars) and the bathroom was seriously small but since we really just used the room to Sleep and get ready it wasn't bad at all! Definitely would recommend and/or visit again!We stayed here 4th of July weekend so the whole city was slammed and hectic, but everyone at the hotel was super nice. And they were able to accommodate us checking in three hours early. Rooms were nice and clean. Very short walk to Broadway where all the bars are, I think three blocks, and there are actually bars and restaurants on all the streets as you're making your way to Broadway. I knocked off one star because the elevators are extremely slow.. We always had to wait forever. I could have walked up the stairs much quicker, but I didn't know where the stairs were. The lobby is a little confusing.Late night post concert food!!  Awesome!!  So inexpensive!!  Biggest salad eeevvvveeeerrrrrrrrr!!!    Like 11 bucks!!  Can't beat the price!!   Fries were superb!!  Fish and chips about the same price!The bathroom ruins the entire stay; pealing paint, mold and rust on the ceiling.  Plus when you take a shower you are standing in six inches of water.  Definitely not worth the money.The main benefit of this hotel is the close proximity to Broadway and the cheaper (if you want to call $400 a night cheaper!) rates than the other downtown hotels.  Stayed three nights with some girlfriends.  Beds are comfortable but double size is very small for two people.  The AC was horrible and we woke up very uncomfortable and sweaty two mornings in a row.  The bathroom was very outdated and not cleaned properly when we arrived, nor throughout our stay.  The final straw was when a manager knocked on our door at 11:45 pm saying there had been a noise complaint about us.  We are all mature upper 30s-40 year olds and we were only watching TV and talking at the time.  If the walls are that thin, then there is a problem.  Tiffani at the front desk was beyond helpful with our problems and super sweet.  We did think most of the staff was very friendly.  Downtown Nashville is fun for one or two nights especially if you love live music.  Definitely try the Pedal Tour (be warned it's a bit of a work-out but fun!) and for the BEST chicken ever go to Hattie B's!! Fun trip but unfortunately we would never stay here again.
review_content_60: I'm surpised by some of the negative reviews left about this hotel. Ok it's not a Four Seasons or a W hotel, it's a doubletree hilton and does exactly as it says on the tin and more. We stayed two nights over the weekend and got a great rate on Hotwire, it was our secret hotel. The only negative was that our bed was v small, I think it was a queen and for someone who rolls over a lot in the bed my bf was not thrilled about the size of the bed, but apart from that I found it to be super clean, staff were v welcoming and accommodating and they came right up to the room when needed (they had forgotten to give us our warm cookies when we arrived so they came up to deliver them!) all in all I'd give it 4/5 stars for what it was!Small rooms.  Room literature says pool open at 6:00 a.m., but actually opens at 7:00 a.m. which is simply too late if you are here on business.Staff is friendly and helpful (this has greatly improved since I have been staying here)Required valet parking of $25!Excellent for business at the State Capital, a little far for walking to downtown areas.  They do have an excellent shuttle.Great location and very friendly staff. Room was comfortable and good breakfast. Good place to be for cma fest as it is centrally located to downtown and the stadium, a walkable distance to all venues. I would avoid eating other than breakfast here as the service was very slow and nothing too impressive. I was astonished at how cheap the food was though, so if you have time to spare, it won't hurt you to dine here. We stayed here for CMA fest 2013 with the hotel at completely full occupancy and all has gone smoothly. There was a small wait for the elevators after the concert one night, but that is to be expected. Hilton Gold, so I stay at a number of doubletrees and this is one of the best.The staff at the hotel was competent and friendly.  Couldn't have asked for more in terms of customer service.  The food served for our meetings was very good.  The breadsticks were as hard as rocks, but all of the other food was quite good.  In spite of the renovation, rooms smell musty (my room and 2 of my co-workers experienced the same odor issue), tubs don't drain well (prepare to be standing in inches of water by the time you finish a short shower) and the exterior of the windows are filthy.  My room, even though recently renovated, wasn't exceptionally clean either.  It's obviously been a long time since someone thoroughly vacuumed (lots of dirt on the floor near the back of the desk area), and my room wasn't vacuumed at all during my 3-day stay.  Internet connectivity is horrible throughout the hotel (guest rooms and common areas) and drops on a regular basis.  There was no working ventilation system in my bathroom which turned into a steam room after a shower.  The a/c system won't cool the rooms to anything near the low end of the thermostat range.  (I found the room warm, humid, and mostly uncomfortable most of the time.)Can't believe the low average rating of this place; we just stayed a few days ago and had a fantastic experience. My new go-to hotel! PRICE- The cheapest you're going to find downtown is ~ $140/night (pre-tax). We got the "Ultimate Package" in the junior king suite for $170/night (pre-tax). This included valet parking (even self park at other nearby hotels runs about $20), breakfast, and late checkout. And the room was enormous!!! COMPLIMENTARY- Delicious, warm cookies at check-in. Wifi! A shuttle around downtown (however, we didn't use it so I can't really speak to that). SERVICE- Everyone--the valet, front desk, room service, housekeeping staff--was friendly, courteous, and smiling. Service over the phone was also lovely; I called prior to making a reservation with questions and once during our stay when we couldn't figure out the wifi. Both of the women I spoke to were patient and informative. And, for the record, the wifi is really simple!OTHER- Very clean. Room service came with a free bottle of water, which was nice and unexpected. Contrary to other reviews I skimmed, elevators always arrived promptly, though I guess it depends on when you're staying.
