It was in the middle of everything.. The rooms look OK until you take a closer look, underneath my bed had an empty grocery bag, gummy bears, gold fish crackers and a lot of dust. Their were no bed bug covers on the mattress which was strange and a little uneasy. I conveyed all these issues to the front desk... My concerns seemed to inconvenience them as they were trying to rush me off of the phone.. Needless to say, i do not recommend this  hotel property! And I will bypass this brand!Stayed here for 3 nights and left feeling disappointed and with an extremely sore back (not great when driving 8 hours back to Chicago).My negative experience started at the front desk when checking in. There were two women working, and neither wanted to be there. The woman who checked me in was cold, rude, and gave me attitude and started helping another person check in as I read over the agreement before signing it. I mean, excuse me for taking the time to read something before agreeing to it. Didn't realize those extra 30 seconds were such a big deal. Bottom line: if you can't be friendly and welcoming, don't be in the hotel industry.The hotel's lobby was fine. Relatively small, but at least somewhat nice looking. But as soon as you get past the lobby, you see that this hotel is old and dirty. Our room was really small, but that didn't matter too much. The bed, however, was a nightmare. It was old, uncomfortable, and left me with a sore back for a week after I checked out of the hotel. I can deal with a small room, a grainy tv, a dirty bathroom, a sink and shower with low water pressure, outdated decor, paper thin walls where you can hear every noise from other hotel patrons (all of these things were present in my hotel room), but not having at least a moderately comfortable bed is inexcusable for a hotel that charges $100+/night. Parking was also an interesting situation. This hotel has a HUGE parking lot, though on any given night, a majority of parking spots will be taken by people who are attending a party, conference, or some other event at the hotel. On the first night of my stay, two separate parties were happening at the hotel. We weren't able to find parking so we left the hotel property and drove around for hours until a spot became available. So be aware of that if you're driving or will have a car.I did not use the internet at the hotel because I read that it was $9/day for wireless and $5/hour for wired connection. That's ridiculous. Again, if you're charging $100+/night for an outdated hotel, at least give your guests free wifi.As for the pros, I liked being super close to downtown Nashville without paying the super high prices to stay downtown. I also saw that the hotel had a shuttle that went downtown, but since we had a car we didn't use it.Bottom line: the hotel is outdated, the beds are extremely uncomfortable, the rooms are overpriced, the staff is rude, and there's virtually nothing within walking distance of the hotel. After staying here, if I go back to Nashville, I'll be sure to pay the slightly higher price to stay downtown.I'm giving them 2 because we ordered room service and it was good and not cold and came around the time they said they would be there. I wish I could say the same for the rollaway we had to get because my boyfriend got the room thinking it was a 2 bed (because that's what the description said) and it wasn't. So we had to pay for a rollaway which took almost 2 hours and after a few phone calls to get. The hotel has potential if they hired a whole new staff. It lives up to it's bad review reputation and I'm sure will continue to.Well to start, I booked my room two weeks before my reservation date and I received a call the day before I left, saying that they did not have a room for me because they overbooked, but that they were going to move me to another hotel which was on the other side of town. Note: I had actually chosen this hotel because it was close to the venue where I was attending an event. They also said I would receive a full refund as well as a complementary stay at this other hotel. When I arrived at the other hotel, they proceeded to tell me that they had no reservation for me. So I went back out to my car and called the Millennium Maxwell House Hotel to clear up the confusion. Then I was put on hold for about 20 minutes before they told me that they did actually have a room for me. While I was on the phone, I asked if we could check-in early because we had been on the road for 17 hours. They said, and I quote, "Your room is ready. Come on over." When we arrived, I went to check-in and they still could not find my reservation. After about 15 minutes of searching, they finally found my reservation and told me that my room was not ready and that they would "call me as soon as it was." After sitting in the parking lot for over an hour and a half, I walked back in to check on the status of my room. Again, it took them about 15 minutes to find my reservation, but when they found it, they told me my room had been ready. Then I asked them about the rate because 1) the second hotel was going to be free and 2) it had been such a hassle between the extreme lack of communication. They told me that I would be charged the original full price because I "ended up staying there after all." So then after finally receiving my room key, we headed up to the room where the first thing we saw was the top right corner of the door covered in something that looked like black mold. We walked in and when we turned to close the door, we discovered that the only way to close the door was to slam it shut using your full body weight. As we went to set our bags down, we noticed a fist-sized hole in the wall and that one of the lamps had been broken and was showing exposed wires. We were very disappointed in the quality of the room, regardless of all these issues with the door, the lamp, and the wall. For a $400 room, it looked very cheap and small. I have actually stayed in nicer motels than this very expensive hotel. When I got back from my event that night, I asked the front desk if I could have a late checkout because we got in late and the staff member was very rude and did not seem to want to help. I can assure you that I will never again stay at this hotel or recommend it to anyone. Note: All the words in quotation marks were actually said to me by the hotel staff.So the listing is noted as being a downtown hotel. Really it's a view of downtown. We asked the receptionist about it and she said "Anything 5 miles from downtown is still considered downtown. So we hear about the shuttle but it only runs until 10:30 so we decide to drive ourselves around. Each of the three nights that we were there we would see people in the lobby and the elevators slamming drinks pregamming. Apparently this is the low class riff raff party hotel. There was even a club like atmosphere going on in the bar on Saturday night where locals show up, so we had to park about a 4 minute walk from the front door of our hotel. They could not provide a king bed although there were only two of us so we slept on a full. The hotel is so outdated and has only an outdoor pool. We could hear all of our neighbors talking in the rooms next to us and outside our room. Really killed the mood. The sink is outside of the bathroom so you have to get ready in the room under fluorescent lighting. There was rust all over the bathroom which was so small the door nearly hit the toilet when you open the door. The door didn't lock. The main door to the room also doesn't lock except for the side bar. The ac/heat was not temperature controlled so if we didn't get up out of bed we would end up sweating or freezing until the point of waking up to go shut it off. Housekeeping came by at like 8 am and kept coming by every hour until we left. They partially tidy up but I found it odd that they just threw a pile of toiletries on the corner of sink. For whatever reason, wi-fi was an extra charge as was the business center. Luckily where we went for a concert was able to accept the ticket on our phone. It was $5 min charge for the internet and the charges to print. Everything felt grungy and dilapidated. I would rather have stayed at motel 6 for half the price.I was flown into Nashville with my band to play a private event.  Everything was arranged and booked well in advance...3 rooms booked at the Millennium Maxwell House...one night.  We were shuttled to the hotel after the event at 12:30.  We were greeted with "yeeeeah about those 3 rooms....we don't have those"  They did not honor the reservation.  After reading some other reviews I've seen we're not alone in this experience there.  They have even stiffed a bride and groom on their wedding night!!  The inept woman at the front desk then arranged for 3 rooms at the Opryland hotel on the other side of the city and said they would be paid for.  It's 1am by now...we have to be at the airport at 8am.  We stand around for a long time while nothing happens....she then comes out and tells me we'll have to pay for taxis to go to the other hotel.  I told her that would not happen.  The hotel should be responsible.  She then relents and calls a "taxi" service which was really just her girlfriend who had a minivan.  We waited about 20 more minutes for the ride. While waiting out front a bum approaches our band and starts asking for money...it wasn't that hard to notice he even had a gun in his back waist band.  I report it at the front desk...she says she'll call security.  Did they ever show?  NO   Our sax player just gave him $5 and then he just hung around while we waited.  The "taxi" shows up and we just piled in....7 guys, bags, guitar, bass, sax, trumpet....not enough seats.  Our drummer sat on the floor board.  Not enough seat belts.  Reminded me of when I was travelling in Nicaragua.  Pretty sure this hotel broke the law in lying to us about this "taxi" service.  Unmarked minivan...no meter...trash and clutter inside, a west African driver going 85 mph across the city.  We arrive at the Gaylord Opryland Hotel around 1:45.  The very professional staff there were taken aback by the BS we had just been through.  They asked if we had any paperwork for the rooms or vouchers for taxis or shuttles....Apparently the Maxwell House failed on that too.  The Opryland girl called Maxwell House herself and bullied them into providing us a shuttle to the airport in the morning.  This hotel is run by total scum.  Stay far, far away.  Maybe you'll get lucky and not get screwed over, but we'll never risk it there again.  Also, if you peruse some photos online....many people have posted pictures of grime and mold in the bathrooms, stray pubic hairs, and used soap bars laying out....so apparently the maids suck too.I feel like I'm sharing a room with both of the neighboring guests. The walls are paper thin! WiFi is so slow... Don't even bother. Housekeepers are super friendly and that is about the nicest thing I can comment on.Not impressed.  We booked this room for two nights while making a college visit to Vanderbilt for my daughter.  Right away I could tell while getting off the elevator to our room, the hotel is definitely outdated.  The room was somewhat small for what we are accustomed to. The bathroom is a sliver, with the sink being outside in the common area.  Not a good set up.We had some of the same issues that other yelpers have had. The middle of the night very very loud noises, fighting, screaming matches which felt like was right outside of our door.  I got up to see what was going on and felt the people screaming three or four rooms down but still felt like it was right next to me.  I did call the front desk like an old man, they wanted us to move rooms but I was not about to uproot the whole family with all of our luggage at 2 AM.They do have complimentary shuttle service downtown Nashville. But it is a bit cumbersome because you have to wait.  But still pretty cool so I gave it two stars for this reason.If you are looking for utility and not aesthetics, then this place could work for you. Very run down for the price. Odd smell in the lobby. There were issues with the elevators every day. An incredibly drunk individual tried to get into our room at 4am multiple times and when he realized he couldn't, took two steps down the hall and passed out right in the middle of the floor. I realize this could happen anywhere, however, when I, personally, forgot my room key in my room and went to the front desk to get a new key card, the receptionist NEVER EVEN ASKED FOR MY NAME OR ID. So that drunk man from the night before could have received a key card to the room he was trying to get into (MINE) at any time. He just had to stay sober enough to ask for the correct room number downstairs.ODH!!Old, Dirty and Haunted. Stay somewhere else. . . Anywhere else.Rooms are old , place is haunted, parking is plentiful but not covered and no valet and this hotel is in the hood. Do not get fooled. Restaurant food is also disgusting.Horrible attitude and shuttle service. I stayed here 4 nights and nothing but attitude from all staff members. You must call and pre arrange a shuttle I did that and waited 1.5 hrs and no shuttle. I toke another shuttle and made hotel pay for it. Also it is located far from downtown. Would not recommend this hotel.Disclaimer: I haven't been here yet... I've only dealt with the front desk people over the phone. My friends and I randomly decided to head to Nashville for a weekend next month. The Millennium Maxwell House looked nice, was priced well & was (allegedly) haunted, which was cool. I am in charge of booking the hotel so I called them to get some information about the location. I am young, but I'm old school. I like to talk to an actual person and not ONLY rely on reviews. The first lady I spoke with picked up and sounded stressed, which is fine. I figured it was busy and didn't mind waiting a few minutes. But when she got back on the phone, I felt rushed with my questions, so I forgot to ask a couple of minor questions. They transferred me to reservations to ask about pricing and THAT guy was awesome. Super friendly, I wish he worked at the front desk, because he didn't rush me at ALL with my dumb questions ("is the hotel actually haunted??", etc.). I called back again today because of some confusion on my bank statement about the charges. This time, a guy answered and I told him I had a question about my reservation for next month. There was odd silence and then he said, "hold on" and put me on hold... for 6.5 minutes. He got back on the phone and was was really short. I told him what was going on and he said that it looked like my reservations were still on and I asked him if he could think of a reason why I was having these weird credits from them on my account. his response was, "I don't know, you're still on for these dates, is that everything?" Not even in a rude tone, though. I said, "umm yeah I guess so..." and he said, "Ok, bye". But by the time he said by he was mid hanging up the phone, so I could barely hear him... I'm confused. Is this place ALWAYS busy, or what? I guess I'll find out next month! The reviews I read are great, so we're all excited, but MAN! Nothing I hate more than snooty front desk people...So I didn't experience the staff as my friend did all the payment and reservation.  Huge parking lot. HOtel lobby was super clean but had a strange aroma floating around. I'm not sure if it was mildew smell or sewer.  It seemed to fade as you made your way to the elevators.  The room was ok for two people. Not to big. Pretty basic. The beds were ok for the purpose they served. Passing out after a big night on the town. The bathroom was super small.   The pool area was nice and there was a bar that was accessible.  The pool could have been a little cleaner. There were a lot of leaves floating around.   You had to pay for WiFi in your room but not in the lobby-kinda stupid if you ask me.The shuttle driver was super nice and friendly.   Came back at 3 am and grabbed drinks from our room and found our friends on the patio that we had met earlier poolside and while waiting on the shuttle to recap our nights.  We were loud...and the staff didn't seem to mind. People in our patio party managed to climb the fence around the pool and get in and the staff didn't care what was going on outside.  I managed to make my way back to our room around 530 am and slept with the door open and I was still intact and we didn't get robbed.  All in all it served its purpose.  But there are better accomidations in Nashville.   The TN Titans happened to be in house and were welcome to signing autographs for people if they asked.Don't stay here. The lobby smelled bad, there were several issues with the elevator, the housekeeping walked into our room 2 days in a row early in the morning when we were still sleeping, our key wasn't working twice, and they ended up charging us extra for late checkout when it was entirely there fault that we were late (room key not working and elevator broken). Also they charge for coffee and wifi.... This place should go ahead and shut down because there are too many better hotels out there.Though the reviews were mixed, we took a chance and booked this hotel.  We called ahead of time (1:45pm) to ensure we would be able to make a reservation downtown at 3:30pm with check in at 3pm and the shuttle running every 15-20 mins and were pleasantly surprised to be told rooms were already available and on a first come first serve basis so we headed over and were checked in by 2:15pm and on the shuttle by 2:45pm. The staff was very welcoming, friendly and helpful. Our view of the downtown skyline from our 4th floor room was beautiful and the hotel itself was definitely worth the value in our book. We will definitely be staying here again!Stayed here for work since it was close to the location, but so not worth it. Should have stayed downtown. Employees were OK, but not overly friendly/helpful. Walls are paper thin, prepare to not get much sleep. They disabled wired internet access in rooms, and you have to pay for wireless. The free wireless in the lobby is slower than dialup if you can believe it.Couple good fast food style places to eat nearby (McDonalds, Jersey Mike's, Starbucks) but otherwise is completely away from all of the downtown Nashville activities. They do offer a free shuttle, but you have to compete with everyone else at the hotel, and there's no real order in terms of when they come, where you might be in line, etc.Room wasn't dirty, but wasn't modern/overly clean. Stay elsewhere.I was incredibly surprised by how rude the gentleman at the front desk was when checking me in. I attempted to ask a few questions about the hotel and area and he walked off. Absolutely no eye contact from anyone at the front desk. I took my grandson to the airport the next day and asked when the shuttle was leaving, the women at the front desk replied "I have no idea I just got to back from lunch" and offered no help. We waited 30 minutes and took a cab. I bought a few items in the gift shop and asked the clerk for one of the plastic spoons behind the counter and he said rudely NO that is for people that buy ice cream. wow.We went out for the day and came back at 5:30 and our room was still not cleaned. I tried logging in with the hotel wi-fi (charge) and got a error message guest not found.I called the front desk to ask for help and without reply connected me to a help desk in India.  After 20 long min I find out they spelled my last name wrong when checking in. The hotel could be so nice if not for incredibly rude staff.I have to admit, after booking on Priceline then reading the Yelp reviews, I panicked a little, but ultimately this was a solid OK effort in my opinion.  Not quite a "fan" yet, but no real complaints that aren't nitpicky.  Let's talk about them (since they seem popular here):The sheets are a little on the thin side, it's true.  As are the walls. Sound does travel and you can hear noises in the other rooms and the hallway.  Neither of these is the end of the world for me.  It was pretty quiet in the hotel, so noise wasn't an issue for us.  Duvets, and possibly the pillows, were made of down.The public spaces, particularly the upstairs hallways and elevators, are a little dated and show some wear.  One spot had clearly been patched but not yet painted by maintenance, as it still had blue tape on it.  It looked like it had been there awhile.  Again, not a huge issue.No free wi-fi in the rooms sucks.  Period.  Paying ten bucks is silly.  So what there's no coffee in the lobby--that's why they have a restaurant.  You have free coffee in your room.  What do you expect?  Not ever hotel offers a free breakfast, folks. The room was clean, with a few little things the vacuum missed but so what?  There was some wear on the furniture and the walls, but they were both relatively new and it was more like inattentiveness than just plain deferred maintenance.  A little attention to detail would help resolve this.  One of us took a shower and said, "The shower leaked all over the floor," but really it was just the shower head was aimed funny and if you tweaked it a bit, it wouldn't get water on the floor.  There was no vent or fan.Despite their claims to the contrary, the hotel is not downtown.  It is near downtown, but not within walking distance.  Yes, they have a shuttle; yes, it stops running at 10:30 p.m.  Food options nearby are fast food.  The clerk gave us an extensive list of restaurants though and would have been able to guide us to those that deliver or shine.We were lucky to catch the bar right before they stopped serving food.  My reuben was actually quite good, and the fries were hot and fresh.  A friend got the fish tacos which she said were better than she expected for the location.  My partner didn't complain about his Philly steak, but our other dining companion said the BBQ sliders were "gross, but I'll eat them."  I did like the fried pickles they came with.  Our server was quick and friendly.The front desk staff were friendly and helpful at check-in and check-out, although in this day it is a bit dumb to make us manually check out at the front desk--I worked in a very similar hotel twenty years ago and we provided guests with their check-out bills overnight under their door.  We also had in-room check-out.  Twenty years ago.  So I don't think this hotel deserves the nasty reviews, personally.  It was fine for us, no real complaints.  Especially considering the price we paid.I was weary of staying here after booking on Hotwire, and then reading others' reviews. After my family's stay, I wonder what the other reviewers were so bent about.This hotel isn't the swankiest I've been to, and Hotwire's rating may be inflated, but overall it was comfortable, spacious, and the staff was friendly and professional.Yes, it isn't downtown and the pool hours are inconvenient, but I would stay here again.
review_content_80: My wife and I stayed at the Millennium Maxwell House this past weekend. Much like Mickey, I booked on Priceline and panicked a little when I read the Yelp Reviews, but I think the place is pretty decent. Sure, it's not the newest hotel in the city, but the rooms were clean, the linens were nice, and the staff was courteous. I know the beds are a little stiff, but I tend to prefer a firmer mattress anyway. What really made my review go from 3 stars to 4 stars was the staff. We had a severe weather outbreak Thursday morning at about 3am. Instead of letting us all deal with the weather in our rooms (there were multiple tornadoes in the region and wind gusts up to 100 mph) they evacuated everyone into the hotel lobby and into a interior hallway. What happened next was a great testament to how great the staff was. Charles, the head of security kept everyone up to date on the situation and tried to keep everyone as comfortable as possible. After the threat was over, they opened up elevators and helped the crowds get back to their rooms. My wife and I were looking for a soda machine, and the staff member that was working the front desk informed us that unfortunately, there wasn't one on the floor we were on. She disappeared into the back office and came back with two sodas for my wife and I...on the house!It was a small gesture, but it brought us both great comfort as it was an extremely uncomfortable ordeal for everyone involved. Even though it's not the newest or shiniest place out there, the staff made up for everything through their professionalism and courtesy. I'll definitely look at this hotel again if I"m going to Nashville, it's close to downtown and a fantastic price compared to things right on the strip.I stayed at the Millenium Maxwell House for 3 nights this past week while visiting some clients in Nashville. Overall, an A-OK experience.The Great:+ Huge room.+ Friendly staff.+ Free shuttle with uber friendly drivers - be sure to tip them out!+ Clean - from the desk to the bed to the bathroom.The Average:o $9.99 for 24 hours of Internet, meh.o Typical check-in/check-out process.o Average beds and linens.The Poor:- SLOW elevators. I had to wait nearly 5 minutes for one to come up to the 9th floor.It's definitely an older hotel, and feels a bit worn, but in the homey kind of way. It was a bit too far away from downtown for my taste, but for the price, I can't complain. A solid 3-stars.Pros:Complimentary shuttle into downtown. Large parking lot and no need to pay for valet. MEPS lounge with lots of video game counsels and sofas, etc. (good for military)Cons:Absolutely horrible receptionist with an attitude. She asked if I had an ID so I handed her the first ID in my wallet. She then looked at me as if I was stupid and asked, "Do you have a DRIVER'S LICENSE?" ....If you needed a driver's license just ask for one. Usually a military ID works well as, a you know, ID....Her attitude was also just awful in general. The hotel is quite dirty. Now don't get me wrong, its not disgustingly dirty. It just seems to fall apart in the small details. The moment we parked, for example, we noticed a large blue tarp hanging from a tree limb. Homeless people, perhaps? The metal hinges on the door in our bathroom were rusting and the wall paper was coming off on the edges. The fitness center was also very old and not well maintained. Pay for internet. If it wasn't for the complimentary shuttle I would give this place one star on account of the crappy service at the front desk and just lack of appeal. The name sounds nice and fancy but the hotel really fails to impress.I booked this hotel on Hotwire for a recent visit to Nashville. We were in Town for the Colts Titans Thursday night game. Hotwire considers this hotel downtown however it's a 10 minute car ride from the main strip. It was ok though since they had a free shuttle. The hotel def shows it's age but it wasn't all that bad. We were out in a handicap room for some reason but I didn't complain. This hotel was cheaper than other hotels downtown. I would recommend it only because they have the free shuttle.We won our hotel room on priceline. $65/night + tax. Not a bad deal for a last minute trip to NashVegas for some partying.The rooms were clean and comfortable. I wasn't crazy about the bathroom setup, but overall, the situation w/the hotel is pretty good.+ they offer r/t airport pick-up for free!+ they will shuttle you within 5 mi of the hotel for free!+ they have free on-site parking as I understand it... this is a deal in itself in Nashville+ staff members were fantastic; especially the shuttle drivers- not a 4 star hotel by a mile- didn't offer free internet- common areas needed a major overhaulI really, really don't know what everyone is complaining about. I had a great time staying here. The price was right, the staff was really friendly, it was a very convenient location, and it was a clean place to rest my head. What else could you ask for??1. I never had to wait more than 10 minutes for a shuttle.2. the person that checked us in and out (Edward) was super nice3. they always brought us everything we needed (extra towels)4. free parking5. great price6. lots of Tennessee Titans players :)7. clean pool8. lots of mirrors for three girls to get ready at the same time (yes!)The only problem we had was on Sunday--we left the room around 12 and it wasn't cleaned after that. But it wasn't that huge of a deal, we just called down for more towels. Problem solved.I would definitely stay here again!One of the worst hotel experiences I've ever had. First, we were told we could check in at 3 but the rooms were not ready until 4:30. Not sure what took so long since I could not tell that the rooms had been cleaned. Our room stank and was very dingy. The towels in the bathroom had brown spots on them, the bathroom itself was disgusting, and the linens looked (and smelled) like they had not been washed. The wifi was out during our entire stay, and when we complained about this we were ignored by the rude concierge. Seriously, I could not wait to check out, except when I did check out they overcharged us and I had to fight with them to charge us the already absurdly high rate I had booked ($159, which is ridiculous given that I've stayed in roadside motels nicer than this dive). I have never enjoyed staying at Millennium hotels, which usually need major renovations, but this place is atrocious, even for Millennium. Never again.Never really cared much for this hotel...the decor seems outdated, and the staff isn't that great. I always get so nervous riding on their elevators, because they seem old and shaky. However, my only good memory of this hotel is that I got engaged here. :)The only pros for this hotel was the location, decent price through Hotwire, and the complimentary shuttle. Everything else was kind of a nightmare. The bathroom was very dirty and had a clogged drain so I asked the to fix it, ended up having to ask them once again to fix it before they ever did. Even when they supposedly fixed it, I didn't notice much of a difference. Was charged a $50 fee out of the blue and had to go ask the front desk what is was for. Elevator door wouldn't open at one point, had to go up a floor and get on another elevator. Ordered a movie one night, I had fallen asleep but my boyfriend said that after a while the TV picture was all messed up and couldn't watch it anymore. My boyfriend and I also both had an allergic reaction to whatever they were using on the sheets or whatever kind of mold or dust that was in the room. Would definitely never stay here again.This place is not a bad hotel. I have no ideawhy the reviews are so bad. The rooms are clean and nice, the staff is very friendly and it's located in a good location. It's just not walking distance to downtown but it's a very short car ride there. This hotel isn't the ritz Carlton but it's comparable to Marriott. I would stay here again.My hunny and I decided to stay in downtown Nashville after a little too much fun at all of the cool downtown bars (we were 3 sheets to the wind, basically) ;)Being the ever so thrifty girl that I am... I whipped out my iPhone and headed for priceline.com (my go to for all things travel booking related). I was able to procure an alleged 4 star hotel in "downtown Nashville" for just $35 bucks (on a Friday night, no less). I'd never heard of Millennium Maxwell House... so I yelped it (became a bit nervous), then google mapped it and realized it really isn't anywhere near downtown, it's off Rosa Parks... BOO, we can't walk! We took a cab (about $15 from 2nd & Broadway) and arrived to discover a seemingly decent looking hotel... with a bar in full karaoke-swing (score). We checked in, tried to head to our room to freshen up but the elevator was broken, and it took us & the now 10 or other guests who'd piled up, about 15 minutes to actually get a working elevator.... no good. Upon arriving in our room, it was pretty basic. Nothing fancy, no frills, but decent bedding, good sized and clean. The bathroom was impossibly tiny and the soundproofing between the hallway and the room was non-existent. None the less... we dropped off our bags and headed down to the bar. The bar is where the experience gets weird... really weird. It's a restaurant/bar and to our delight they had the oh so delicious Sam Adams Octoberfest, we were distracted however by the pretty good karaoke singer... and then horrified to realize that it was a 10 year old girl (see my pic). In a bar. On a Friday night. Not exactly ideal... but ok. I inquired about it and apparently kids are allowed in the bar because it's a hotel and the laws are different... I'd never heard of that. I thought that she must be with her parents in town and perhaps she's here to get a record deal (she was pretty good)... how cute, right? Well... not so much... she's a regular. A REGULAR! AT A BAR!!! It gets even better... so I went up, and I must say, I'm a pretty decent karaoke singer... I chose Miranda Lambert's Kerosene... I sing it.... people seem to enjoy it and low and behold this little snot tells the KJ that I'm singing her songs & the KJ tells me I can't sing anymore Miranda Lambert! This place was like the twilight zone! The moral of my story is this... The Millennium Maxwell house is certainly a good value, if you book on Priceline.com and get the same deal I got... but if you're wanting to actually stay near downtown... this hotel doesn't fit the bill. I recommend the Hilton Downtown Nashville (see my review) or really any of the other hotels that are actually in the mix and whatever you do... avoid this strange hotel bar, unless of course you're looking to be harassed by a wanna-be-diva 10 year old. I'm seriously still scratching my head.Booked this hotel on Hotwire listed as a 3 1/2 star hotel downtown! Wrong! Wrong! No way! Sorry- call a spade a spade! This was no 3 or 3 1/2 star! it would be lucky to listed as a 2 star!2 miles from downtown, in a questionable area old and smelly should be listed as a 2 star! The hotel lobby smells like a sewer EVERY time you enter the old outdated lobby - and the outdated and cheaply decorated rooms- with hair clogging the shower and NO working internet service (although promised in listing - and charged for per device!) Needless to say - it was dirty and not a great feeling coming home to at night- ( on the shuttle that is 15 minutes away from downtown - and you have to wait for along time for it to pick you up! ) we were forced to check out the very next morning as one more night would have totally ruined our stay in Nashville!!The staff becomes irate when you ask them if the hotel is haunted. 5/5For the price this was a great hotel. Shouldn't be labeled as downtown and it shouldn't be at a 3.5 stars. The staff was nice. There is a free shuttle that will take you anywhere downtown for free. The shuttle runs all day. This hotel is definitely past its prime. It has that old hotel smell. We ate in the restaurant on site - considering there is nothing else around - was almost to the quality of bad fast food. And then seeing the 87 Health Card Score scared me. Would I recommend this hotel? No. Would I stay here again? Maybe. The main advantage of the hotel was the price: paid $60 a night through Hotwire compared with other hotels in the area charging $180 a night. But given the choice - and the funds - I would go stay somewhere else. Isn't this review decidedly undecided?The ENTIRE staff is really unhelpful. Restaurant food is below average, lobby smells like a toilet.Stayed here during our trip to Nashville for the Roger Waters concert, the hotel isnt anything to write home over. The beds are full size and the room doesnt even have a fridge in it. The decor is a little dated, and you just dont get that "feel"......you know, the one that you get when you walk into a hotel room and go "WOW".... If you have reason to be up the hill, then maybe the Maxwell House will work for you, but if youre gonna be downtown for a show or whatever, there are better places within walking distance. Last year for the Rush concert, we stayed at the Hampton Inn. We walked to and from the show with no issues. The room was about the same I think, and much nicer.Absolutely the most overpriced hotel I've ever stayed. On top of that, there was a $9.95 charge for wireless for EACH device. With two children with multiple devices, this was just asking too much. In addition, the wireless was too slow to do much of anything. Would NOT recommend.Clean rooms, welcoming and knowledgeable staff and a Free shuttle to downtown! I have no idea why people would give such low stars.The service at the bar was slow - but when the restaurant is feeding the entire hotel, OK I get that.William and Sam were our shuttle drivers. They had the best ideas into where to make sure we visited.I picked up a few things for my niece and nephew at the gift shop and the staff there was also very nice and helpful.I would definitely consider staying here again.I was a little worried when I did Priceline's name your own price and got this hotel. I had nothing to worry about though. I stayed for 2 nights to attend a concert with some friends. The hotel was clean and comfortable. The staff was pleasant, and they allowed me to check in early. No, it's not actually downtown, but the shuttle was very convenient, although I did have to wait 20+ minutes for it twice. I slept great, although the beds weren't that great. There was no fitted sheet (WHICH I HATE), and the mattresses at Best Western Downtown (where my friends stayed) were much thicker and nicer. All in all, it was a good hotel for a good price.More like a 2 star hotel than a 3 star hotel. Wifi costs an extra $9.90 in the rooms and the decor is dated and dingy. Not worth the discounted price. Splurge and spend the extra $20-$30 per night for better comfort

review_content: The old Union  Station was converted to this gem of a hotel.The lobby is breathtaking. The wrought-iron railing and stain glass  rotunda is magnificent.  The staff is informative and friendly.  Charming facility. Convenient  to walk to Honky Tonk Row, Ryman, Convention Center etc.  No mini fridge  in the room,but at this price  you are not cooking or bringing back a doggie bag. Charming touch having coffee and a scone in the morning and tea and cookies in the afternoon  in the lobby. This facility  is for grownups. Yea!I stayed at Union Station in Nashville the week of the CMA awards. I was not impressed. The rooms were big and the lobby was pretty, but that is about the best i can say. My room only had a closet in the bathroom! There was PLENTY of space to have a closet in the bedroom. It was so odd, it had a shower curtain rod as a door and it was totally inconvenient for 2 of us to shower and dress when the closet was next to the shower! It was CMA week and the hotel was a ghost town, we went down to the restaurant and waited 10 minutes at the hostess station and nobody even showed up. The lobby was deserted and the atmosphere was not what i would expect for one of the biggest weeks of the year. It was definitely not worth the higher price. The service was ok, but not what i would expect based on the price. We decided to rent a car, so i called the front desk, assuming they would assist... they gave me a phone number and told me if that didn't work out to look on the internet. It was 5 blocks from downtown - close but for half the price you could literally stay within a stones throw to all the action town, in a room just as nice with more amenities in the hotel. I would not recommend staying here if you are interested in good service and the fun Nashville experience.Incredible views and perfectly preserved late Romanesque architecture in the interior of this hotel. The top of both spiral staircases are so breathtakingly beautiful. Go here if you stay in Nashville. The hotel prices start in the $275.00 per night and up range. Restaurant has stunning decor as well.Beautiful hotel.  Located within walking distance of a lot of things, but not right in the middle of things.  The rooms were beautifully appointed, tall ceilings. Since it's an hold converted building, things like closets are secondary but that was fine for us.   Our only complaint would be the HVAC in our room - it was SO loud.Beautiful hotel and the bartender Deborah makes the best Bloody Mary ever!  Go there and ask for Deborah.I wanted to love this beautiful, historic hotel...but it was a little lackluster. For starters, $32 for valet?! What? Why? The guys are nice and maybe since my car was parked right in front that was really just a convenience fee...but it seems excessively high. The lady at the front desk? A total doll. Sweetheart even. But then I got to my room...and I'm not a fan of bathroom humor so it literally pains me to even write this...but the toilet was running (like wouldn't stop) and there was a ginormous brown smear at the bottom. Needless to say I wanted to vomit and called the front desk immediately. Someone came up right away and he informed me that I should jiggle the handle to flush...well, I'm sorry, but it wasn't me...which brings me to the question who was it? The housekeeper? Or did they just not clean from the guest before? It was WEIRD and not something I expected from a hotel of this caliber. And now I'm gagging because I can't believe I am even writing this...I like to think I have class and now I'm wondering if I do because who writes a sentence like that?!!?!?Then I was getting dressed to prepare for my evening and turn on the TV...not working. I don't even have a TV in my house so it wasn't a big deal and I just turned on my itunes but they charge A LOT for these rooms...I shouldn't be having these issues.Stayed here for a work retreat. The hotel is an old train station and has been kept in tact for the most part with very high ceilings and stained glass. The room I stayed in had a sloping roof so I felt a little cramped (on the 7th floor) but many others said their rooms were spacious so maybe I just got a smaller once. They have a bar and restaurant that is very nice inside the hotel and there are many bars and restaurants in walking distance as well. I had breakfast in the hotel restaurant which was pretty great and the waiter even applied a voucher that he had to my breakfast so I ended up paying only like $4! I was pretty happy about that lol. I can't speak for price of the hotel room because my company covered that, but I am sure it's on the high end. Definitely worth considering staying here though or having a work retreat also.beautiful decor.  the lobby is a treat to see. Marriott  truly did a great  renovation.   wonderful stayOur stay at Union Station was mediocre. I didn't have any major complaints - the rooms were nice, the beds were comfortable, the service was hospitable, the location couldn't have been better, and the hotel lobby was gorgeous. BUT was it anything special? Not really. Was it worth the higher price? Probably not. Most of the rooms don't have a great view, since the first two floors are street level, and our room on floor 3 (of 5) was obstructed by the valet cover. And although the noise in the lobby didn't bother us, it was definitely noticeable.Also, not ALL the rooms have high ceilings. As a rewards member, I requested a high floor and the best they could do was a room the third floor. It was your typical hotel room.It's cool idea, but in reality, downtown Nashville has better hotel options.The lobby is truly the best part of this hotel. All the infrastructure you take for granted in a nice hotel is in bad shape. I write this review as a maintenance worker repairs the faucet on my shower. The irony is, they knew exactly what the problem was before entering the room. This makes me think it is a common issue. I am a huge fan of Marriott but this hotel reminds me of the old saying about putting lipstick on a pig.Deborah was the best bartender ever! She was personable and friendly! Made me an orange dream which I had never had and it was awesome!5-stars for the attentive, personable valet staff and the hostess in the restaurant who fetched me a bagel and cream cheese at 9:45pm and didn't charge me. 4 stars for location (close enough to downtown but removed enough to where it isn't rowdy on weekends), and 2 stars for the rooms. You would think that a AAA 4-diamond rated hotel would have better beds and pillows, but alas. They need to take a cue from even the Hampton Inn as to how to create a comfy bed. We could hear someone snoring in the room next to us! Hotel has been beautifully renovated in the main area, but overall, not worth the money. Especially for the really uncomfortable bed. I was disappointed.Paperthin walls and very small corridors. That means that with our hotelroom directly across (almost in) the elevator we we're confronted with a lot of noise. During all hours of the day. Not acceptable for this price. Together with the high prices for valetparking (almost 33 including tax) and the very expensive WIFI just a mediocre experience. The room itself (I think 615) was spacious and nicely decorated and maintained. The same goes for the bathroom. Only remarks here are that the bathroom has almost no space to put your stuff on and the bed is not very big. If you're both tall Europeans you might be dissapointed.And please excuse any spelling or grammar mistakes. English is not my first language. And if that isn't bad enough I have an Apple device that keeps trying to change English into 'proper Dutch'. Yes, you've guessed right, my first language.Very cool old train station converted to a hotel. Isis not stat just came to take pictures. The staff was so kind and helpful! If I were in Nashville again I'd opt to stay here. There was coffee and scones in the lobby. Beautiful hotelBeautiful, spacious, Autograph collection property. The lobby is gorgeous, clean, with plenty of seating. Check in was easy, the staff was accommodating and courteous. Thank you for the upgrade. The rooms are very nice and clean with tall ceilings and big windows. It's decorated with soft colors. The beds are comfortable and plenty of pillows. The bathrooms are a decent size, plenty of linens, and a great shower. They have a small workout space, but I still managed to get there. Cool bar and nice restaurant. Only little complaint you can hear some of the trains at night. Nothing outrageous...I would definitely stay at this property again. Priced very well too!Beautiful, historic building.  We went to sightsee historic train station turned hotel.   While we were there, a train was going by that was super long and carrying coal, and who knows what!  Fun to watch. The lobby is phenomenal.  We stopped in the bar for a few specialty drinks.  It was dark and loungy - just the right feel for this hotel.  I would like to stay here, but it is a fair walk from downtown, and I worry about the age of the hotel.  Sometimes historic hotels are a little musty. I would recommend looking at the reviews in detail.  Most of the 5 stars are from visitors commenting on the building and history.  Several (like Jennifer S) have better comments on staying at the hotel (like the train noise etc).This is a great hotel. While the re-do of Denver's Union Station is something Denver should be proud of; this version of a station-turned-hotel is spectacular. The rooms are spacious, the fixtures and setting are very nice and the staff is unbelievably helpful. The dining room is NOT your average hotel dining room, I had a great dinner here one night, and did not feel like I was missing out by not visiting one of the many great restaurants in town. The hotel is also right next to a great art museum, located in the old Post Office. Nashville has a lot going on, and this hotel represents!Okay, I have not stayed the night here but I have visited the building several times.  On Wednesday July 2nd, Tony, Noel and I went walking around the town of Nashville. My daughter is new to the area. So, we are taking her around the city to enjoy all the sites and sounds of this wonderful musical city. Now, myself..I am a history buff..Anything historical..anything old..I love old buildings and I want to hear and see all the sites looking for anything to feel a connection to it. I would love to have been here in its busy "Hey Day"..This building is Great..The lovely interior and lovely decor of the inside of the building. I love to see and hear about all photos of the hotel and its past. if you ever get a chance to go to this lovely hotel you should go. You should walk around and enjoy all of the beautiful decor and history it has to offer. You don't have to be a history buff to enjoy and see the awesome decor.We stayed on Sept 25th - 28th. Check in was at 3 PM and we waited until almost 4:15 to get a room and we arrived there at noon. Like others have said. The suites were $550 a night and at best they were standard business class rooms you could get at any other hotel for $149 a night. When I reserve a suite I expect it to be a suite, not a standard Holiday Inn room with a sitting area! Our A/C did not work the last 2 nights! The hotel lobby is very nice, but that is where is stops. Beds, towels, linens were old and the TV's are advertised as 42" and both were 32". Some channels we could not get because of bad reception. The banisters, light switches and door knobs were all filthy and we did not want to touch them.Bottom line is, I think they owe us about $1,000 refund. Stay somewhere else and just stop in and take pictures of the lobby and move on to your next adventure. It's too bad, really. We planned this weekend for my wife and her twin sister's 40th birthday only to get ripped off by the accommodations. Ruined the whole trip!Top notch!  Luxury and character combined.  It's hard to tease out service over location, but honestly this place could have less than great service and I'd still probably love it because the building and history of it are so incredible.  Wait staff in the restaurant (Prime 108) are some of the best I've had.  The food was good but not great sadly (had dinner twice and breakfast once).  The hotel does have a little fitness center, which is put to shame by some of the elite workout areas in modern hotels, but it does have free weights and treadmills, a tv and it's clean!  Highs -- sooo much character, super romantic, down right coool.  great customer service.  gorgeous decor and rooms.  high quality toiletries provided.  free coffee and scones in the morning and a tasty little praline at night.  within walking distance of broadway and an art museum right next door! Lows -- with so many other places to eat nearby - try somewhere else.  Prime 108 is fine, but with the mark up in price I'm certain something better can be found for the same price point.
review_content_20: I love old trains and train stations. The exterior of the majestic Union Station Hotel stands strong. We gave ourselves a tour of the place.The lobby ceiling is so tall and beautiful, you can't help but look up and stare at it. The front desk holds the train schedule, which shows you which cities people traveled to from Nashville. Oh the adventures they must have had. I love the design of the building and the details. I'm glad we got to stop off and see another historical Nashville landmark.I have had such an irritating experience with the Union Station Hotel, that I am writing my first ever Yelp review to express my anger. Simply, after paying for a "King" room at the Union Station Hotel my fiance and I were given a "Full" room instead. Not a big deal, I called the front desk and was told that the difference in cost between the rooms would be credited back onto my card. The irritating part is that now more than a month later the credit still hasn't happened. I called at least 5 times, and was directed to the accounting lady. After leaving messages, I was never called back. On my final call I spoke to a manager who said it was all taken care of, but clearly it was not true. I am giving up trying to get my refund out of pure frustration.Paid $500 A NIGHT (yes, that's FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS A NIGHT) for a room at this place on a busy weekend in downtown Nashville. By comparison, I paid less for an oceanfront room at the Grand Hyatt Kawaii 15 months earlier. Was it worth it? Short answer: No, not even a little bit.THE GOODThe lobby. Unquestionably the main (only?) draw to this place. It is truly amazing: a fully restored 19th century rail station lobby. Every bit as spectacular as The Piedmont in Memphis, minus the ducks of course. They actually hosted a wedding ceremony and reception there while we were there which was amazing.Location. The hotel is located halfway between the tourist attractions on Broadway and the newer development in The Gulch. Easy 6 minute walk to either location from the hotel.Rooms. Are spacious with nice 12-foot ceilings. Well-lit by original full-height windows. We did get free Wi-Fi, but I think it's only because of my Marriott status. Otherwise, I think it's $10 a day or so.THE BADCost. $500 a night?! Are you freaking kidding me?!Location. It being a former train station, it is located immediately next to a still-very-active rail yard. Which means surprisingly loud freight trains rumbling past your window roughly every hour or so. I come from a place where this happens every night, so I found it rather soothing. But if you're from the other 99.9% of the population, maybe think twice.Rooms. For $500 a night, you will be treated to exactly 2 (TWO) bath towels. Oh, and 0 (ZERO) bars of soap. Rather, you'll luxuriate in a combo shampoo/conditioner/body wash combo bolted to the shower wall. You know, the kind you had at the last $72/night Holiday Inn Express you got stuck in when your connecting flight got cancelled. I was frankly embarrassed for the hotel for this.Staff. To be fair, they're unfailingly friendly. But for this price point, I expect a dedicated concierge, not a desk attendant pulling double duty. And yet a desk attendant is what you get when it comes time for a reservation. As best I can tell she has no more pull with local restaurants than you would by just calling yourself. Shock: they're not much use when push comes to shove. And that's assuming they pick up within 27 rings when you call down to the desk. Perhaps on a related note, the bar didn't have at least 1 of the wines listed on the menu. First night I figured, Okay, maybe they're sold out. Second night I realized No, they just don't care.Housekeeping. We had the Do Not Disturb sign out when they came around the first time (ridiculously early IMHO), and they never bothered to check back. Imagine our surprise when we returned at 4:30 PM to discover our room untouched by human hands. (Including the dead roach in the bathroom, btw.) Completely ridiculous for FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS A NIGHT.TIPSSpend 15 minutes (and $0) walking through the lobby, then head on down the street and book a room at the Hilton. If push comes to shove, go to airbnb.com and for $100 less book a 2-bedroom condo just off Broadway downtown. Wish I'd done the same.I love the architecture and decor of this hotel and the beds are SOOOOO comfortable. I like the location and the staff was very helpful. The location was perfect for us and did I mention the beds?Here for a business meeting. The Conf was two days. Lots of charter at this place and lot of history. You could just set in the lobby and look around for a while. Lots to see. Its really a cool Hotel. Close to downtown, so you could walk if you like. Nashville is a lot of fun. This is a great place to stay if you want to be close. Good food from caterningSuper cool spot. Location is great- just a five minute walk to downtown Nashville (touristy area) but five mins the other way is the super cool Gulch area.Very clean. Gorgeous inside (old train station) beautiful high ceilings, super nice staff who are there to help with anything you need. Pricy.I truly appreciate the building's architecture and history but this place should have been turned into a museum and not a hotel. I travel quite a bit and have stayed in a few of Marriott's Autograph collection hotels and this hotel did not meet the standards that I come to expect from a Marriott Autograph property. My wife and I stayed in a king suite, a beautiful room but not suitable for a good nights sleep. The interior wall faced the lobby so the lights from the lobby illuminated our room throughout the night. Although there were shades, the light was impossible to keep out. The exterior wall faced Broadway so without any white noise you heard sounds from this busy street all night long. The bathroom looked like it was last updated in 1995 with a paisley print curtain for a bathroom door and a similar curtain for the shower door. The room was equipped with no feather pillows, something I've come to expect with Autograph level hotels. The bottom line is if you're planning a trip to Nashville and want to stay at a Marriott property, save your money and choose the Courtyard.The hotel is pretty much as beautiful as the pictures except for our room. It wasn't large enough to have a queen or king bed and there was no closet. I guess I expect too much being from New York. It was very disappointing especially for the prices we paid. The people working there however, were the best. True Marriott Customer Service. We were in town for the CMA's and the location was also perfect, close enough without having to listen the the craziness once we went back to the room.Union Station is the most exquisite hotel in Nashville. The decor is breathtaking and I haven't had a more pleasant experience as a hotel guest in Nashville, well--ever. The rooms are gorgeous with unbelievably high ceilings and the bed is basically the most comfortable thing I've ever slept on. The bathrooms are lovely and come loaded with luxurious bath products. The showers are incredible with amazing water pressure. When I stay here I never want to leave. The only thing I would change is the ease of connecting--and staying connected to the hotel's WIFI network.Not a bad hotel per say. It has a charming lobby, but you spend far more time in a room. The location is good for walking. But overall, this is a $30 parking, rooms with no view, cheap bed & decor, thin wall hotel sitting next to 5 train tracks which run through the night (and we were on the opposite side of the hotel from the tracks). We travel a lot. I would say the hotel deserves a 3 star but because the price is so high, it gets a 2. Some pay upwards of $400 a night here. It should be going for $100 night for what it is.I recently stayed here for a business trip and loved the hotel. Built from the old rail station, the built appearance has the most grand and stunning lobby. Behind the front counter is a sign with the old train routes that used to run through there. The staff were extremely hospitable and made the visit very welcoming. I was very luck and had one of the rooms facing the lobby. With the massive ceilings and arcade type windows that over look the lobby, the room took my breath away when I walked in. The room was kept perfectly and the bed was extremely comfortable. I couldn't have asked for a better nights sleep (which i desperately needed from the cold I had come down with). Without out a doubt I would recommend this hotel and stay here again in the future.It's a historic building that they did a marvelous job renovating. Beautiful room with very high ceilings. The lobby makes you feel like you stepped back in time, and the decor reminds you of a time when trains were the way to travel.This is my favorite hotel in Nashville and I frequently travel to Nashville.It's a beautiful and historical building conveniently located close to downtown, midtown, and the Flying Saucer. Hospitality was on point--everyone from front desk to valet would make an effort to remember my name.The restaurant was mediocre, but who would eat there with so many great restaurants in such close proximity?5 Stars for the history and architecture, but 1 star for the train noise that woke me up at 3:30am and 4:45am as well as little insulation between rooms and the hallway. I could hear my neighbor coughing and 2 separate people's entire phone conversations taking place in the hallway outside my door. I really wanted to like this place more since it is so very charming, but couldn't get over the lack of sleep I experienced while staying here due to noise inside and out!The old train station converted into a beautiful hotel. They did a great job preserving this historic place and keeping it's charm. Rooms are very nice with very high ceilings which make the room feel even more spacious. Lots of countertop space in the bathrooms. Lots of coffee awaits you in the lobby each morning with delicious baby blueberry scones. They also have coffee makers in your room for people like me who have to have coffee to even get to the coffee. I really liked the bar. Great specialty cocktails and a friendly staff. Hotel is walking distance to the pedestrian bridge, Country Music Hall of Fame, right next to the Frisk and all the live music you came here to hear.My sister had to go to Nashville for some company training and she wanted me to tag-along. So i did since I didn't have to pay for anything. =PThis place is nice. Right when you walk in you automatically notice the beautiful decor and architecture.The people that worked the front desk were very pleasant and helpful. I had a nice conversation with one of the girls about how she went to Saint Marys college in the Bay Area (which is where i'm from). And they also faxed my homework for me to one of my instructors about 3 different times because i kept sending it to the wrong fax # (oops! hehe). That alone gets 5 stars!Now for the room. At first we were given a pretty big room. I loved it because of the size, but after a few minutes my sister and I started to smell a sewer-like smell. We call the front desk to let them know and they gave us a new room with no hesitation. The new room was smaller, but still nice. I will take away one star for the bathroom though. Although clean, the grout and tiling could have been done a bit better as well as the paint. Those factors sort of made it look like the bathroom was kind of dirty at first. There was also a man that would greet you as you walked in the hotel. He was the sweetest! Wore buttons and pins from all over the world on his vest and hat. Not sure if he's still there, but if he is try to start up a conversation with him. He's an interesting guy.Wow! Our room is wonderful. Cozy and spacious. Bathroom is big tub shower and great for two people. Desk clerk was great. Funny and so helpful. 7th floor is great !!!I stayed at the hotel for two nights October 3 &4. I WILL NEVER STAY THERE AGAIN. Here are the problems-The entire staff is unfriendly and not helpful. MANAGEMENT what message are you sending? We walked into check in and not one person at the front desk smiled. The girl helping us was over it. The bartender with long hair could not have been ruder to us. The hostess at the restaurant acted like we we aliens.-THE ROOMS ARE BAD. My first room 710 I think, smelled like fried foods and has scuff marks all over the walls. I tried to turn the radio on, didn't work, and a bug ran across the bed. I then looked into the sheets and a long black hair was on them. I went down to the front desk and they said they could move me. I went back up to get my purse and bag and a woman from housekeeping was inside my room with my door closed. I came in and she was sitting at the desk with her iPhone and on the landline phone.. never seen that before.So they move to to another room, 208, WHICH SHOULD NEVER BE RENTED OUT! Its under the kitchen and right at the railroad tracks. So don't plan on sleeping. Unbelievable bad at any price. -the price.. well it is crazy how much they charge. The carpets thru out the hotel are filty, the rooms need serious help and the staff needs to friggin smile once in a while.Stayed here once and loved it. The rooms aren't the biggest but they are clean and nicely finished. Location is great, right in downtown and in close proximity to the Flying Saucer which is a huge bonus. You can make a short walk to the Broadway strip and the bridge stone is nearby. Valet service so you aren't scrounging for a spot. Have yet to be to their restaurant but definitely a great hotel experience.Gorgeous, and a great lobby to hang out in. I came in after checking out the art museum gift shop next door. The building is an old train station depot and gives the grand hotel feel right when you step inside...stained glass windows, wood moldings, beautiful light fixtures, big fireplace, and giant clock overlooking the lobby. The front desk has the old train schedule routes behind it, to keep the look and feel of the original train depot building. After perusing the hotel gift shop (bought myself a chocolate guitar souvenir), I went up to the balcony level. Along the stairwells and walls are great pop/deco art (kind of like the national park style) featuring places around Nashville. There's also a steakhouse and bar on the lobby level that I didn't try, buy they looked really nice. I love old style grand hotels like this one.
review_content_40: 4 Stars  ~ for the wow factor alone.   But 2 Stars for the overall experience. The lobby is amazing and worth a quick walk through to admire the wonderful architecture. But a visit is enough. If you want a comfy, warm, bigger than a match box room ~ go elsewhere. The guest rooms are tiny, bare, and ~ in December ~ cold. My room was a cute cozy space that looked like a child's play room in the attic ~ dormer like windows and all. But it was teeny tiny. So much so it could only accommodate a full size bed. As for the  bathroom, it  was minuscule ~ pedestal sink, basic tub shower ~ that sort of thing. I cools touch from one wall to the other by extending my arms! I'm a big fan of historic buildings~ truly ~ and I love some hotels... The West Baden Resort in French Lick comes to mind. The other disappointment was the food. One word "cafeteria". Yep. Bland. Unimaginative.  Three days and the only edible thing was the crab soup.  The service is nice. We were hosting a meeting and Isaiah took care of our meals ~ nice. Accommodating. There was a lovely little woman who went to great strides to ensure I didn't get anything with onion (allergic). Last ~ the Internet connection is horrible!!!! Soooooo I'd say if you're only staying one night. You don't care about space and can get by in a mini bathroom this is a fab place!This is what Southern Hospitality is all about. From the moment I arrived by shuttle someone rushed over to open my door and greeted me. The outside of the building is only second to the inside. Stained glass ceilings, wood moldings, ornate light fixtures and an abundance of great furniture, and that is just the lobby. The public bathrooms are private and the cleanest I have encountered. Lunch was wonderful and catered for nearly eighty. The rooms are all breathtaking with stone work, arched windows and sunken rooms.I just loved the southern charm and cozy feel without any of the stuffiness. Love. Love. Love.my first floor room was between the train tracks on one side and the hotel's lovely "L & N" dining hall (serving breakfast) on the other. also nestled below a section of staircase. if that isn't being stuck in the armpit of the hotel, I don't know what is. a real missed opportunity for a nice relaxing couple of days in Nashville.This is a beautiful historical property! Valet was great, check in was friendly and efficient, and my room was perfect. I travel a lot and this was the perfect location to walk to 'downtown' and soak up the history. Breakfast was good but I found the restaurant a bit foo foo for me :-) As others have said Flying Saucer next door is a plus.Hotel is beautiful and convenient to most of the areas one needs to see. close to many fine restaurants. the lobby has coffee and small pastries until 10 am and then iced tea, cucumber infused water and cookies at about 3pm. in the main lobby. the bar is very nice and the restaurant served a great dinner and breakfast. my only issue was that  one has to pay extra for internet service in the room.  for me, that means you lose a star. a nice experience overall.The hotel is a very cool space with lots of memorabilia from the old train station days.  The checkin staff was friendly, the valet was $!5 per day with unlimited in and out, and they were super efficient with the car and hailing taxis as needed.  Valet is open 24 hours which is nice when you have an early flight.The lobby is historical, with a groovy bar, plenty of seating.  Only complaint was that the Prime restaurant is expensive and not very cozy.The rooms were high ceilings, comfy beds, flat screen tv.  Nice but not large bathroom.  Only half a mile from the hot zone of Nashville, I'd stay here again.  The trains do blow their whistles pretty early in the AM, but we pretty much slept through it.This was our first time to the city of Nashville. We chose the Union Station on recommendation of our Travel Agent. The hotel was beautiful! The history architecture of the building was wonderful. From the moment you walked in you were greeted by the valet and bell staff. They were friendly and we laughed with them daily!!! The front staff was wonderful. The concierge recommended things to see and do and a great place for our anniversary dinner. The hotel is convenient to the tourist attractions, fine dining, and the bar scene.The food at the hotel was good. Our room was comfortable, spacious, and gorgeous! Top Notch!!!!Spectacular!!!  Beautiful Castle-like former Train Station transformed into a Hotel!Incredible Lobby! !! !!! Stunning is right!!!  The original Architecture and the new Decor is Awesome!  I have seen very few hotels this nice in person!  The lobby looks and feels like a great place for a meet or to relax on your own!  Two story's down from the Lobby are two addition floor of room which are above ground, though two floors below street level!Fantastic Furniture!  The Furniture in the Entrance to the Hotel and the Decor and Furniture in the Lobby is really cool!  Extremely Comfortable too!The Staff from the Doormen to the Front Desk are very friendly, personable and eager to share information about the Hotel and its former identity as a Train Station!I really like this hotel.  This is my second or third time here and every time has been great.  This last time we had a room on the fifth floor.  It was a corner suite.  This room had high ceilings and it was very clean.  Cleaning crew did a great job. The room was small tho.  The bed was super comfortable.  They have a pretty solid bar in the hotel with a decent wine selection.  Small store for snacks and beverages.  They also have Prime 108 for room service and a restaurant.  My only complaint was no fan in the bathroom.  Imagine---drinking all night and then eating some fast food.  Hit the can in the am and no fan.  It didnt bother me but the wife was not too happy.Oh, my ...this is a beautiful hotel with its cathedral and stained glass ceiling that screamed opulence and grandeur in all the four corners.  The hotel used to be a grand central station that has been converted into a hotel. The art deco-themed design has yellow as the dominant color with splashes of gold and orange.  I love this hotel and its beautiful design/decor. The lobby is huge with a massive fireplace on one end and a lot of comfortable seating areas. The front desk features a blackboard that shows train schedules which are probably similar to the time when the structure was still being used as a train station.The spiral, wooden stairs that leads to the upper floors is also a beauty and adds to the charm of the hotel.  The hotel rooms are located to the sides which leaves the middle of the hotel open from the lobby all the way up to the ceiling.  This creates an airy and open space that makes the lobby more majestic and grand. The open space provides visitors with an awesome view of the lobby from any of the upper floors.  The hallways are lined with intricate iron grills that provides a barrier between the hallway and the open space. The rooms are well-appointed and elegantly furnished. The outside of the building features a gray/off-white bricks and a watch tower which, for some reason, reminds me of a castle.I did not stay at this hotel, but the review is for the quality.A rehearsal dinner at the restaurant one night was exceptional. Food was great but the service was stellar. Attentive servers that truly honed their craft.Multiple experiences with the valet service were great. They were extremely gracious.The wedding ceremony and reception were held here and again the staff did an awesome job putting everything together. The whole design of the lobby and front desk area is phenomenal as well.We were here for 4 nights and stayed in a suite. We didn't utilize the living area just because there was NO tv in the living room $ the tele in the bedroom was super tiny and outdated. That's not important though.Nothing beats this beautiful lobby of this preserved train station. Absolutely gorgeous. Could not avoid the 4-6pm cheese offering in the lobby. Like really?Anyway it was a beautiful choice for a friends wedding reception & as for the room... My bf and I did sex everywhere and in a banquet room. Haha. Ftw.This is an absolutely stunning hotel.I stayed on the 5th floor with its 18 foot tall ceilings.  The lobby is magnificent.  The am coffee service was great too.There's no pool, but still I would highly recommend especially for a fan of the days of American grandeur.This place looks cool online but in person it is PHENOMENAL. This place has presence! The building itself was opened Oct. 9, 1900 as a grand train station, construction beginning August of the prior year. Some of the more fascinating facts that I have read about this historical location is that Al Capone passed through here on his way to a Georgia penitentiary. As well as many Presidents and Celebrities. When seeing the structure in photographs, it takes on a strange resemblance to a church rather than a train station- and even more so in person. When train travel was on the decline, the station closed for about 10 years and eventually it was turned into a hotel in 1986. $11 million in renovations, a new boutique style and a rededication on Oct. 9th, 2007 brings you to what you see today. We stayed here for a night in the first week of January 2010. We arrived in Nashville sometime after dark, freezing cold and snowing. The valet warmly greeted us and had a bellhop help us with our bags. Walking into the lobby, looking up 5 stories or 65' at 128 stained glass windows(apparently it took 3-4 workers a month to clean,) barrel vaulted ceilings  and an enormous fireplace is more impressive then you can imagine. The place was silent! I swear it felt like we were the only ones in the building...so a little eery but truly amazing. The views of the exposed staircase is also pretty amazing(I attached a photo.) I didn't know at the time that the hotel is noted as a haunted place but if you dont get the vibe when you walk in, you dont believe in that sort of crap anyways. I totally believe in that crap. Our room was huge, great view of outside train tracks and the West side of Nashville. Very beautifully decorated room and especially nice bathroom. The large windows and extremely tall ceilings are the only evidence that you are in an older building while in your room. Everything else looked completely contemporary.Before venturing out, we got a few drinks at the bar downstairs. Really nice, great drinks and a must if you are staying here. When we got back to the hotel, we were pretty rip roaring drunk(I was secretly freaked out...the hotel is creepy regardless of it's pretty exterior.) I do remember sneaking out to have a cigarette- there was no one in the lobby or the hotel itself, again I felt like I was the only one there. I tried to find out where I could smoke but there was no one around so I smoked infront of the huge fireplace. No harm, no foul?We traveled to Memphis the next day, sad we only stayed here one night. While in Memphis, I found a book listing the Union Station hotel as a haunted place. The station was obviously very active during WWII and they say one spirit is that of a soldier waiting next to what used to be a track. The second is a woman who supposedly fell on the tracks, ran over and killed by a train. There is also a rumor that a woman killed herself in room 711, shooting herself with a revolver. This and the surrounding rooms are apparently where the most activity is. I have also heard that floors 5 and 6 are extremely active because this is where workers used to work and sleep? There was also a terrible collision in 1918 killing 101 people here. Sooooo...you be the judge! If you are in Nashville, I recommend coming here at least for a drink and to wander the halls if you can't stay here. If not for the beauty of the structure itself, then to get the creepy vibe I got.This is a most wonderful and charming hotel. Staff is more than gracious. Every aspect of our experience was just fantastic. Would recommend to any and everyone.On drive across the country, rolled into Nashville with no reservation and no plan. Looked online and found great rate at this historic location.Lobby is amazing, staff smart and friendly, vintage American charm throughout the building.Room was spacious and well appointed. Writing area, comfortable bed and a large bathroom.  Easy to walk to hip spots or the touristy downtown area.Consider the Union Station for sure when visiting Nashville.Stayed here in July 2012 for the Music City Brewer's Festival. Walked from hotel to the festival, not too bad of a walk. A little far from Broadway/Printer's Alley, but walkable if you're cheap enough to not pay for a cab. The lobby and common areas were awesome, very nice finishes and detail. The room was just ok, a normal hotel room. Bonus having the Flying Saucer pub attached!So incredibly beautiful.  Not sure what people are talking about when they say the rooms are small - ours was perfect with huge ceilings and enormous windows looking out over the city...  Can't say much about the food - we ordered room service once and it was fine.  Then again, I don't know who sits around in a hotel eating hotel food in downtown Nashville...  duh!  (to the one reviewer who commented that the food wasn't good - get out, woman!)  The art nouveau stylings of the building transform you to another time...  The service was fantastic.  Can't say enough - I wouldn't stay anywhere else in Nashville!Amazing hotel. Beautiful architectural details. Happy and attentive staff. We couldn't have been more pleased. We read a lot of reviews beforehand that complained about the train noise; but the hotel IS an old train station, and we found it to be part of the charm.The staff is absolutely wonderful. Restaurant and bar are great along with the service.This building should NOT be a hotel. Whoever decided to do this was a lunatic.I was put in an interior room on the "lobby." For starters, one entire wall of the room is windows that open onto the "lobby" or atrium, which used to be the interior of the train station. The windows go up two storeys. There are curtains for privacy. However, other than the room's light, that's the only light you're going to get in those interior rooms.
