Rumor has it, that's how former politicians would get ladies of the night to visit them discreetly. Secondly, the bathroom is famous for it's 1970 art deco. There's even a little plaque explaining all this. It's not abnormal to find a group of girls wandering in to see both of these aspects. Be careful though, my friends and I totally confused some foreign gentleman.One of the most beautiful places I've ever stayed. Exquisite. True Southern gentility. Breakfast in the grille was truly one of the best I've ever eaten. Superlative.Stayed here in December '10. Highly recommend The Hermitage Hotel! They do everything right...including the little thing. If you are planning a trip to Nashville, The Hermitage is the place to stay!Stunning and I mean STUNNING stay here over the holidays/new years. We stayed in a suite that was absolutely gorgeous. The service was IMPECCABLE from the moment I stepped out of the car. They valeted our car, escorted us up the stairs and the front desk greeted us with champagne and already knew the name of the reservation (from mentioning it at the front door). We were checked in and our baggage arrived shortly after we arrived to our beautiful suite (a present from the boyfriend for our first New Years together). We had reservations downstairs at the restaurant and took us (even though we were late). The new years dinner was absolutely to die for too (their duck confit is infamous and rightfully so). When we got back upstairs to get ready to go my boyfriend asked if I always arranged my makeup so neatly. What? Never. I walked into the bathroom and while we were gone they had come in, hung up our stuff and had neatly arranged my makeup on the counter on a towel in the bathroom that I'm sure might be larger than my bedroom at home. (Actually I'm sure it is.) We had some champagne and chocolate dipped strawberries that we had ordered waiting for us and took a bubble bath in the jet tub large enough for the brady bunch to fit in. Unfortunately we were watching TV while the jets were going and blew a fuse. Luckily they fixed it after we called.We were beat by the time we came back and slipped into bed. I unfortunately lost my boyfriend to the west wing of the bed (HUGE bed) in his drunken stuper of tossing and turning but it was fine. I was exhausted. The beds were the only mediocre thing (they were large but not the softest). The next morning we ordered room service (after leaving our orders on the knob outside) and everything was correct and they were prompt in bringing things we forgot to make note of to ask for on the form.I could live like that...but I'd become overweight, spoiled and overly pampered. I could actually be okay with that if a proposition was made by The Hermitage. That place is BEAUTIFUL. Highly recommended if you want a great stay in Nashville (also close to Broadway and the Ryman/Opry to honky tonk it up!)Fantastic for a special occassion restaurant.  portions are perfect, flavorful.  Very tasty.AND CHECK OUT THE DECO BATHROOMS- they are a must-see.This hotel is part of history.  The lobby is beautiful old world.  The restaurant  (capital grill )is like you wan't to believe the old south was.  The rooms are good sized and very comfortable.  Service is as good as you would wan't it.  Don't miss visiting the men's room on the ground floor and read the plaque outside. In fact the restaurant hostess will give you a tour,Been here several times over the past years. The food has gotten progressively worse. Very disappointing. The setting is beautiful, too bad the menu is weak and the preparation lacks creativity.I can't say enough about how great the experience here was!  Had a wedding here and things couldn't have been better from the valet services to the food!   Great location, great service all around, and a great venue!  If you are in need of a high end place to stay or place to host a large party this is it!  Rooms are very nice too, pricey but worth it with the service you get here!I had a chance to eat at the Hermitage while visiting our legislators in Nashville and I was really impressed!  For one thing, the restaurant is gorgeous and has some spectacular architecture-don't know how old the building is but really nice.  I had the grilled pimento and fried green tomato sandwich with the slaw and yummy!  Everyone I ate with enjoyed their meal-the only negative was they have one fishy smelly dish that whenever the waiters walked by with it, we were all thinking "phew, I'm glad I didn't order that!"  Very nice for lunch, will definitely return when in town.

review_content: I've heard great things about the Aloft chain but they're part of the Starwood Brand and I'm usually a Marriott or Hilton customer. This time, however, the Aloft was in the place I wanted to be, they were at a competitive price point and I also needed to have at least one night so that now I am earning free Starpoints after I linked my Uber account to Starwood. It's green lights all around.Check-in was solid with a friendly valet and a great check-in clerk. I was on the elevator to my room in just moments. Excellent, aside from the $28 charge for both self-park and valet park.The room was very nice. Quite massive. Like enough space that you could put a small two bedroom apartment in here. Long, wide and very roomy with the usual furniture and a window out to the street.Hallway and neighbor noise was minimal. Street noise was significant with loud engines and sirens and other random nonsense. I was only on the 4th floor. Maybe it would have been better higher up.The bathroom was similarly large and spacy with a lot of wasted space. I do need someone to explain the "let's not have a door on the shower so the floor gets all wet and slippery" thing. As well, it gets mighty cold without a shower door or curtain to close.The room was cleaned nicely during the day but when I went to make a cup of coffee in the morning from the Keurig, both pods were decaf. Fail!Nice hotel. Good room though noisy. Coffee issue. Spending parking. It was A-OK.Being a SPG member I've stayed at numerous Alofts around the country for business and pleasure. Seeing that this Aloft was in a great central location I thought I couldn't go wrong. Arrival was pretty cool as they had open mike night and the bar was very happening. The interior of this Aloft is pretty much the same as all of the other ones I have stayed at - bar and snack bar on the first floor, ample seating with charging jacks, and rooms in the upper floors. I was told that I had a handicap room and was initially excited. However the girl at the front said to let them know the next day if I wanted to change rooms since the shower was "weird".The room looked similar to what I was used to - studio style. However it smelled very moldy. The water stains on the ceiling confirmed my suspicions. The shower indeed was very strange as the head was only tall enough for a hobbit to shower in. I changed rooms the next day.My second room also smelled funny although I was able to use the shower. Overall I would say that this property is not as well maintained as the other ones I have stayed at with the rooms a little run down. I will say that the staff here are extremely friendly though. The bartender at WXYZ lounge Lisa was awesome. Be sure to ask her about her WWE past, she's a trip,The most frustrating thing about this hotel was the absurdly expensive parking. The location is pretty amazing though. I loved being close enough to walk around music row, but you can't truly experience all that Nashville has to over without having a car. Having to pay so much for parking every day was really frustrating. Valet and self-park are the same price which makes no sense to me. In fact, it makes more sense to self-park because you get to park closer to your room. The phone didn't work and I didn't see anything indicating that they had room service. I'm lazy on vacation and I would have appreciated that. I'm also cheap so I would have preferred having shampoo and body wash I could take home when I was done instead of the locker room style dispensers. It's true....the bathroom door is weird and slotted so anyone outside the door can hear anything. In fact the walls are super thin and we had the joy of hearing when our neighbors flushed or showered. I'm sure they were annoyed that they had to hear our ridiculous conversations.The Keuring was clutch! That thing ended up being a lifesaver for me. And the free WiFi was pretty great. I also really enjoyed that they had live music near the bar in the lobby. I liked that I didn't have to leave the hotel to hear good music (again, I get lazy on vacation).Overall, I'd stay here again....I'd just skip bringing a car and stick to using ZipCar to avoid the parking fees.Really debated whether 3 or 4 stars, but ultimately decided on 3. Pros: trendy, chic, young clientele, central location to downtown, Broadway, the gulch, etc., comfortable bed, and friendly helpful staffCons: I know it's been said before, but dim lighting. As my wife and I were getting ready, we wished we could see what we were doing. My wife had to move the iron right beside the door because that's the one direct spot in the whole room that had enough light to see the wrinkles in the clothes. Also, no complimentary breakfast, and expensive parking. We paid $30 for parking for one night. Verdict: if it had breakfast or cheaper parking, it would've easily been a 4 star. But it wasn't. I'd stay again, especially on someone else's dollar.Nice hotel. In a great location. I have a King suite that is very spacious. It has wrap around windows. Bed is very comfortable and I love the bathroom.My company put me up here for a conference. I didn't mind it but I would not choose to stay in this type of hotel. The workers were very polite and had great customer service. The room was a decent size. The only issue I had was the lighting. I had to turn on every single light in the room for me to see anything. That was definitely a con. I love the Green Choice program and I love that they reward you for it. If you choose not to get the sheets or towers changed out you get a $5 voucher for food or the bar. Overall I had a pretty positive experience but just not my type of hotel. Hotel is right near Broadway and there are a lot of decent restaurants down there.Not been there as a hotel guest but we went for the Sunday open Mic and it was fantastic! Parked the kids at the pool table in the lobby (free!) and we hung out at the bar enjoying the performances. Great performances and waaay better than those touristy honkytonks downtown, especially with kids. The bar food selection was plenty, nicely priced and actually pretty good. Try it!!I stayed here with some family that were visiting - the room they got was HUGE. Loved the layout and loved the modern look of the hotel and the room that we had. There was a Keurig, pretty paintings, cool lighting, and cozy beds. Really loved staying here - for some reason, it reminded me of a trendy Euro hotel. The staff was accommodating and friendly. It's close to downtown and Centennial Park (which is great for those who are visiting). Overall, great hotel and great location!Nice location. Friendly employees.The bathroom doors are slatted, so there's not really privacy if you're sharing the room with friends and need to use the bathroom. The towels look and feel old. Our friends were put in a room where there was a huge brown stain on the mattress. They were moved to a new room but then the next day, the hotel put another set of our friends in the mattress stain room. And guess what? The huge brown stain was still on the mattress.Overpriced.The rooms are LARGE. I think anyone can appreciate that. The fixtures, furniture and overall vibe are very "aLoft" -- to which, if you've ever stayed in an aLoft, you know what I mean. I loved Randy B's feedback, they're totally on point. You're either going to like the aesthetic or not. I know my parents would really not appreciate this place at all... "community areas" are not their thing. A pool table in the lobby, not for them. I, on the other hand, like the youthfulness of it all. It's different from my everyday hotel routine and I appreciate that. It isn't drab and it isn't old-fashioned and you know that the comforter hasn't been in service for the past 20 years. The aLoft offers valet, don't bother self-parking. You could avoid the parking fees if you found some street parking, but with the construction around the hotel that would likely be more trouble than it's worth. There's a great brunch spot right across the street -- hit them up for chicken and waffles on Sunday. Hattie B's and Chuy's are within walking distance as well -- nice!If you need to head across the highway and want to hit up Acme, snag an Uber. It'll run you about $5-6, which is cheaper than a cab.Extremely horrible service (super rude lady welcoming you). We had a king room reserved but, they told us the "gave the room to someone who needed it" upon our arrival and we never got an alert or phone call to tell us. Then, we could not get a refund to go somewhere else. Tried to speak to the manager but, they didn't not have one on the site. We get into our room to find a horrible view overlooking a rusty roof.. I advise staying anywhere but, here!!!It's a cave! Not a fan, at all. - room is way too dark. Aloft, buy some lamps.- the nightstand has a clock from 1950... Aloft, how about a RADIO in the rooms in "Music City"?!? Or at least a clock with a smartphone dock for audio speaker hook-up? - half the room is a "nothing space" without furnishings. - the showers are "locker room like" with soap and shampoo dispensers on the wall. I don't want to share my toiletries with the last dozen guests and how do I know someone didn't tamper with these products?- the audio on the TV in my room didn't match the visual. Either a bad TV or bad cable/satellite service. And TV screen too small. Aloft, make a friend at BestBuy. - my room's view sucked. See photo. I checked out one day earlier. This is one of the worst hotels I've ever stayed at.Great hotel. Their lobby is similar to the W Hotel but without the hipster feel and house music. Free pool table, poker set, Pop art on walls, modern furniture, free wifi and a large work space desk with room 8 and plenty of electrical outlets for all your gadgets, well stocked snack bar, free lemonade(nice on a hot day), small but nice bar. Staff was insanely friendly. Location was a 30 minute walk from downtown(my dad is 2 years removed from double knee replacement surgery so you should be able to beat or match that time). Hotel is near music row and numerous restaurants and bars in West End(Hattie B's for lunch is a must for any fried chicken lover), and Vanderbilt University. Suite 816 was MASSIVE by ant standards. May have lacked luxury but made up for it in comfortability. Balcony had two tables and decent views of Downtown. Two queen beds were super comfy and pillows were heavenly. Bathroom was void of a tub but had the ever popular spacious, walk in shower. Large work area, couch, 42 tv, small walk in closet, and original art on the walls. Only minor complaints: under powered, slightly noisy AC, hate how when you check out your hit with like 3 hidden taxes(increasingly common at many a hotel), and a what seems pricey charge for valet parking in budget friendly Nashville. From other reviews I was skeptical of this hotel but I'd recommend it to all but the pickiest of travelers.tripadvisor.com/ShowUser...PET FRIENDLY! Treated my doggies like rock stars whenever we came through the lobby.They even got little doggie gift bags upon check in.Comfy beds, hip decor, good location. Only complaint: could use a bit more lighting in the room. Was kinda surprised at having to pay for parking ($28/day) but I guess there's no cheap parking in Nashville. Even so, good location - close to a lot of cool things to do. It's a 5 buck Uber trip to the heart of Music CityOk so the hotel was fine, but the parking was weird. They have self parking and valet parking. Both were $30. Seemed exorbitant for what you get. I self parked and its difficult to get to your room. If you valet thats fine as well, but I like to come and go as I please and it seems they have one valet guy on duty. And I didnt see a guy really late at night. Anyways it was weird. The hotel is about a mile from all the bars in the downtown district and about the same to the gulch. So its walkable if you want to spend 20 minutes. The hotel was kind of expensive as well for being off the main strip. No shower door so water got all over the floor. Hotel was clean and nice, and of course alofts are a tad quirky, so I may stay here again if I get a good rate, but that parking fee was ridiculous, so may stay away.This place is a solid three for the accommodations but definitely a 5 for staff friendliness. They are so kind and sweet. And so willing to help you figure your way out around Midtown Nashville. This area is growing and there is a cute area walking distance. Rooms are spacious. No real complaints other than my Keurig not working in the room but there is free coffee in the lobby every morning!My partner and I attempted to attend an event hosted here in the Penthouse. There is only one way to get up to the Penthouse -- a single elevator -- and for the hundred or so people going to the film premier after party this caused quite a problem. When it was finally our turn to get on, the elevator stopped working, trapping us inside a full elevator of people. Our phones had no service inside, and despite numerous calls using the phone in the elevator, the receptionist did not manage to convince us that we were safe or that help was on the way. We were told after our second or third call to push the firetruck button. The fire department arrived sometime after 1 a.m. and pulled us one by one to safety, through the crack in the elevator shaft. We missed the entire after party, and everyone who had been trapped inside was pouring with sweat and could barely breathe from the lack of air. At least one person in the elevator had gone into shock. However, no hotel staff was there to greet us after this emergency, with water, an apology or any other type of aid. It was as if they completely did not care. When my partner complained and asked the front desk for some water, he was told that they were busy attending to their receptionist who had answered our calls and who "was crying" as a result of the situation. She clearly had not been trained on how to handle an emergency and it was presented as if her inability to handle the problem took precedent over the 9 people to had actually been a victim of the emergency. My partner, a veteran and former firefighter, has attempted to contact the management about their lack of customer service, and the need for better training and emergency protocol, but was told that they would not communicate with him on this matter because they "do not consider him to be directly affected by the situation." A quick search of other online reviews for this hotel will confirm that safety is just one of many areas where Aloft displays their complete lack of regard for the customer's experience. Choose any other hotel if you want to have a nice stay or event.We stayed at Aloft after the Sheraton overbooked the night of the George Jones tribute concert. I'm not sure of the price for the night because Sheraton took care of our bill since we had already paid for our original reservation.Overall, we had a good experience. Staff was friendly and check in/ out went smoothly. The decor is "hip" and "edgy" but it was still cute. The room was very nice, I loved the floors! The bean bag made little sense to me but it wasn't that much of an eyesore. Bathroom was nice and I could see why other reviews were unhappy with no shower door. Also, they had a decent selection of snacks and drinks to purchase or you could go to the restaurant attached to the hotel. We didn't partake in breakfast but it seemed the selection was decent.Valet was confusing at first because GPS brings you to the front of the building on West End and you need to go down 18th and turn around to get in the valet line. Parking, valet and self park, are the same price so it's just easier to valet. The valet guys were quick and also helped us get a cab fairly quickly.So overall this hotel is nice and aesthetically pleasing. It seems like it's probably a bit pricey since you are paying more so for the ambiance and the area. We enjoyed our one night stay and the service was awesome.Stayed here because it's a dog friendly hotel. The room is nice but the phone is broken. The girl at the desk is straight up rude and needs a course in manners. Good thing I'm only staying one night. Not exactly the southern hospitality one would hope for.I really wanted to like the Aloft, but the best thing about it was the staff and I don't stay at a hotel to room with them lol. Many of the reviews are sadly very true, the floors in the rooms are laminate and peeling up, the shower had no door and the water went everywhere all in front of the toilet, the curtains had to be fiddled with several times to block out the light. The toilet seat did not fit on top of the toilet correctly so you would be sitting on the seat and touching the porcelain bowl at the same time. Design flaw or just gross?I guess when you stay at a hotel you really crave simple creature comforts and I didn't really feel like I had those at this particular location. I understand the conceptual design of the Aloft and gave it a shot, and sad to say, I would rather stay at a Holiday Inn Express. I did in fact pack my bags and I am moving to Union Station mainly for location, but also because I know the hotel very well and a room became available.Pluses: The bed was comfy and the sheets were clean, bathroom counter was clean and Bliss products are always nice. The room was VERY spacious (almost too spacious) with two beanbags. Decent view of downtown and there is a pantry in the hotel lobby where you can buy snacks and drinks.
review_content_20: Have you ever went for a drink of water in the middle of the night, only to spit it out because it turned out to be Sprite? The taste isn't bad; it's just that you weren't expecting it.That's how I feel about this property - it's much different than other Aloft properties, but that's also a-okay. Until very recently, this hotel was a Hotel Indigo and though it may pass as all Aloft in the lobby, once you get to your room you might find yourself scratching your head, 'did I check into the wrong hotel?'. The room is very nicely-appointed - in fact, it's a much more sophisticated design scheme than the typical Aloft style. Better linens, hardwood floors, Keurig coffeemaker, chic lamp... and, the water pressure is strong enough to get your hair squeaky clean and the bathroom comes equipped with a freakishly-strong hairdryer. I approve!Despite all the niceties, something is still lacking... part of the reason why I really enjoy staying at Starwood properties is their employee culture positively impacts every one of my stays. I realize the transition just happened several months ago, but there's still some lingering customer service issues (there was a mix-up on their part in which they only booked me 1 night instead of 2, though I had the email confirmation) and a certain warmth is missing. For just a few bucks more, you could stay at the Hutton across the street and get an A+ boutique hotel experience. Though I love my SPG points, the savings aren't deep enough to justify a ho-hum stay.Sorry guys - I generally adore Aloft properties but this one is just a little off.I booked here for my boyfriend and I. The valet at the side of the building was a little weird and pretty pricy however so is self park. Check-in was great. Really nice lobby. Cool vibe and decor. Perhaps a bit on the dark side though. We had a king room and were disappointed. Small, not a great view, dirty windows, not super clean bathroom. Plus the air vent rattled a lot and the room smelled very chemical. The front desk was kind enough to immediately show us something else which unfortunately was also not great. The king rooms were disappointing. The double rooms had a view and were much larger. We would have been happy with this except the beds were a bit small to share. We ended up getting our prepaid reservation refunded and stayed at the Sheraton downtown instead. A+ to aloft on customer service! Unfortunately the rooms just didn't suffice for our needs.Way over priced at $279, tax and fees $354. Not what I am accustomed to for the price point. Printers in costumer office space didn't work, staff did allow us to use printer at front desk. The whole place is in need of an update, looking weathered and wore. A price of $129 a night would be close to acceptable.Don't do it!I booked a trip with aloft for 12 girls on a bachelorette. We booked two rooms and a suite. A week before I arrived I filled out a credit card authorization. We requested our rooms early because of our flights and we wanted to do some decorating. They were able to get us in early but not really. When we got in the first room the fridge needed replacing so they sent someone up to do that. Then in our suite they had to fix the patio panels (?) and a light. That same light went out 10 minutes after we were in the room. So after being delayed a couple hours for that we found out the phone was broken also. They were very accommodating and polite but there were so many issues! With just the lights being on the room blew a fuse at one point during our big bachelorette gathering and games. Too top it off we specifically checked to make sure my card was on file and they still charged the girl who booked the rooms! When I called to explain the issues they offered nothing but to recharge my card. It's a cool hotel but the hip parts of it don't make up for the issues.Unlike the ALOFT 18mls south on 65 in Franklin, TN this one time INDIGO Hotel does not compare. Not clean, trashy, pool table in lobby.....H E L L O !! Give me a break.Location too far from restaurants, bars nightlife also a little 'OFF' when the sun goes down. So, to cut to the chase. Do Not Stay here way too much money for hotel class & or location. Quite a shame as it used to be rather EDGY.Ending on a good note. HANNAH, at reception an absolute delight. Way too classy & professional to be employed by this hotel.I was in Nashville for work and my client booked this hotel for us. Hotel: ok, this hotel has its flaws, but all in all it was an awsome stay. The pros: Easy business centerOutside of all the downtown traffic.Convenient snack bar in the lobby. This came in handy multiple times, and if you forgo house keeping you get $5 buck in credit that you can use towards snackies!Shipping Packages: We had pelican cases and other gear shipped to the hotel, even a huge package that was freighted there and they not only held it for us but helped me load it all to our van. After our work event they took care of our cases after we left to be picked up by UPS. GREAT SERVICE! Also, there is a 24hr FedEx down the street.Location: This hotel is right next to Music row. I'm not sure why other yelpers say that it's far from restaurants. There are plenty of restaurants and bars in the area that you can easily walk too.Parking: If you have a car it's $25 overnight, If you have a large van that doesn't fit in the parking garage talk to concierge and they'll help you out.This is not my favorite Aloft hotel that I have ever stayed in (and I have stayed in a few). The walls are thin (which we discovered thanks to the guys next door who talked loudly and for an hour after getting in at 3am - yawn!). It seemed a little dirty to me. The location was a little funky. We were just staying one night as a stopover on our drive home from summer vacation, so we didn't care that much, though. We did love the bean bag and I thought the shower had awesome water pressure!Anyway all of that aside, I should only give it 3 stars at best but I'm giving it more because of the valet when we left - Goose was his name. We were up early, ready to hit the road for a 7 hour drive home with our three young kids when Goose pulled our car around and it had a FLAT TIRE. Ugh! Goose was beyond helpful. He quickly found an air pump to get it inflated enough to drive down the street to Firestone. He was cheerful and energetic, especially with our kids who were obviously getting antsy. He helped us get through a frustrating experience and he was just awesome. Thank you Goose and best of luck to you!Have you ever wanted to stay in a Real World house circa 1998? Nostalgic for your NYU dorm room? Curious about living in an outdated IKEA catalogue? Then by all means, book this hotel! But if you are mentally over the age of 21, stay far, far away.There were two good things about this place: the location, and the water pressure in our prison-style open shower. The valet guys are also up to snuff. Other than that, I can think of nothing redeeming about this stay except for the moment we pulled away in the car.First and foremost, know that this is a glorified hostel. I'm not sure what the W brand of hotels is trying to pull over on people, but it is not a similar product. I've noticed that in the customer service responses to reviews, they seem to be pushing the "trendy, modern, urban" angle, but this place is none of those things. A crazy color scheme, laminate flooring, terrible art, and a pool table populated by frat boys doesn't equal trendy or urban. It just equals cheap. We're in the 20-30 target demographic for "trendy, urban" and we didn't even like it. If I were an older business traveler staying on points, I'd be out for blood.The rooms themselves are completely baffling. Why would you ever put a weird bean bag in a room and expect anyone who isn't in high school to use it as a chair? Why wouldn't you put a solid door on the bathroom? Why the paper thin walls so that you can hear every utterance from people in the next room or the hallway? Was this place designed by a high schooler who won a contest? I'd be willing to overlook everything if the customer service staff stepped up to the plate, but surprise - they didn't. It began when we arrived and were ignored promptly so that the one employee could google something for her friend. The cleaning man left trash on the floor and didn't even touch the bathroom sink or counters. And the kicker: at 11:00 on New Years Eve, our toilet stopped working after a #1 flush. When we asked someone to come up, he handed us a plunger in a plastic bag and walked away. Happy New Year to you, too!We will never be coming back to another Aloft hotel, and plan to tell everyone we possibly can how weird and awful this glorified summer camp bunk is. If you want to stay in a real hotel, go elsewhere. Anywhere. At the very least, this company should make it clear to customers what they're getting into. Either market only to college students, or warn everyone else.LOVE THIS HOTEL!Stayed here for my Mom's 58th Birthday and I could not have been happier with my choice. Super convenient to Broadway, just a quick drive down the road.The rooms are HUGE, clean, and everything is very hip. My fiance and I are both 26 years old. We loved it. We played pool in the lobby, and grabbed snacks at the 24hr snack ready place in the lobby. Our bed was comfy. All in all - great stay and I would definitely recommend this hotel!This is the worst hotel I have ever stayed in. Sister to the W hotel? I don't think so... Motel 6 would be better than this place! First of all, none of the rooms have closets! Yep, that's right. The windows are so dirty you can't see out of them. The mirror in the bathroom is not over the sink. It's like 6 inches away so when you are brushing your teeth, or my husband is shaving, you can't see yourself! There is a "restaurant" down stairs (yeah right). The waiter didn't even come to our table. He yelled at us from behind the bar "what do you Two want?" But tonight was the final straw. I went down to get a glass of wine. The bar didn't open for another 45 minutes so I asked if I could bring a glass up to my room. Not a glass of wine, just a glass. And they don't have glasses! Only cardboard coffee cups! Sorry! Wish I could give this place ZERO stars... Lesson learned here. Don't let hubbies secretary book hotel reservations in the future!Usually I really like the Aloft hotels...this location is aight but not exactly the cat's pajamas. This one seems a bit older than the others, which is definitely not a bad thing. Our room was like an actual loft space, something that the airport Alofts have not been able to capture in my opinion. The GOOD: Location is great, we had a spacious room, and there was a Fatboy bean bag in the room for loungin'! The BAD: Our room was right next to the stairway door and it was LOUD for sure. Power lines ran right in front of the window view. The parking situation is grim unless you want to pay approx $25 a day for valet. The UGLY: No pool = sad face.Keep in mind we booked on Hotels.com so I'm pretty sure they stuck us in the worst room possible. I'd hate to see what they do to the hotwire customers! Cheers!Place looks a lot better online than it actually is. If you're wanting downtown downtown this ain't it, expect to take a cab about everywhere, not much around this place, slightly ghetto location but not terrible, I just thought we'd be downtown a couple blocks from Broadway. ALoft use to be a corporate office building and it explains why the building is so confusing to navigate and awkward, not sure how the other rooms are but we had 1 tiny window and the view of downtown wasn't great, they need to wash the windows, woulda been cool to have a clear view. The staff was great and very nice and helpful. Our room came out to $200 for 1 night (Memorial Day Weekend) with 2 Queen beds and parking with tax. The room was huge and very comfortable, modern styling and super quiet, we didn't hear anyone the whole time we were there, beds were very comfortable and everything was clean. Not bad but not great either, when I visit Nashville again I won't stay here based solely on the location, was just kinda annoyed to be sold a "Downtown Hotel" and it not really be one.This was my first time staying in an Aloft hotel. I was super excited, as they are supposed to be really fun and hip, right? Well.....that doesn't mean you can skimp on service and quality. I'm going to list some pros and cons here....CONS- The parking was confusing, no clear signs that only the valet could park on the first 4 decks. We ended up having to move our car. Twice. - The parking is really expensive ($24 a day). And the SAME price if you valet or self park. That seems really ridiculous. - The stairs from the parking garages to the hotel were gross and smelled like trash. I almost threw up....not a great first impression. - The bathroom doors in the rooms are not private - you can hear what is going on through the plantation shutter door. Thank goodness I have been married for a few years and my husband and I are not that embarrassed of each other. - The sheets were really itchy. Not good quality. PROS- Nice funky art all around the lobby, halls and rooms- Keurig machine with coffee/tea in room- Cheap and yummy breakfast menu downstairs with a full barNot sure out of all of the hotels in Nashville I would try this one again. I'm really only giving it 3 stars because they had a lot of pretty cool art to look at. Take that away and it would have been a 2 star for sure.My husband and I stayed here for 6 nights recently when visiting Nashville. I really liked this hotel. The location is great, not far from downtown (I walked in one day!). The rooms are spacious with LOTS of places to put your stuff. The bed was super comfortable and the bathroom has lots of room, too. The shower is neat and it has good water pressure. There is a refrigerator and safe in the room. There is also a Keurig coffee maker. There is free Wi-Fi. The elevators are fairly quick. There is a cafe if you need to eat breakfast, we did one day and it was fine. We skipped room service and used our $5 vouchers to get breakfast and other things. The valet was very quick to get our car. $25/day is not really that expensive. They were always very polite and eager to help. There were always taxis available if you needed one. The staff at the front desk are friendly and make you feel comfortable. There is a bar with live music. I would love to give this hotel 5 stars, but cannot because of noisy housekeepers on more than one morning when we wanted to sleep after being out late at the honkey-tonks the previous night. Never the less, I would not hesitate going back to the Aloft when we return to Nashville.Aloft Nashville West End was not as bad as I expected based on the reviews. I ended up getting this hotel through Priceline's "name your own price". Based on other hotels in the price range I fill it is above standards (hence 4 stars). Yes you can hear people in the halls and doors closing, like many hotels. The hotel must have been in a shabby state when Aloft purchased it. While the decor is fun you can tell some things are cheap/ Ikea like. While I dislike fake hard wood floors, I would rather have that then the nasty carpet in other hotels. I didn't like how the bathroom doors were slatted but the shower and its high pressure shower head was amazing! They have a nice lobby set up to entertain with a nice bar. I just parked my car on the 3rd level (room level) and skipped out on valet parking even though I believe they are the same price. The staff was nice and helpful with great attitudes. Overall its a fun environment within walking distance of shops, restaurants and Vanderbilt but a little way from the main part of downtown. I would definitely stay again!This hotel is a serious work in progress. The staff lacks attention to detail. The room was mostly clean, aside from the prior occupants' folded socks and used soap bar. In the same vein, the in room coffee looks inviting but without cups to hold it....well, you get the drift. Not the end of the world but also not what I was expecting. Makes me wonder if one of their staff is trying to sabotage the place.....What an awesome hotel!The rooms are spacious and cool. It was fun, stylish and comfortable. I would take this over hundreds of other dull hotel clones any day. The staff was incredibly friendly. Every need was met. I will ABSOLUTELY stay here the next time we come back to Nashville.I was excited to stay at an Aloft and had high expectations. Right from the start I had a feeling of gloom when I enquired about parking options - $25 daily, not counting tips every time the valet gets your car. I was falsly told the less expensive lot across the street wouldn't allow overnight parking. *Hugo clued me in to parking on the street in front of the hotel which was free after 6pm Friday and thru the weekend. The hotel is chic and modern - designed for the young urbanite. The lobby was well lit and decorated with neon lights and plenty of cool (uncomfortable) seating. There was a food gallery with overpriced treats that led into the workout gym. Sweaty patrons has to walk through a food area, yuk! The lobby music was very loud.The RoomWhoever designed the room/bathroom have no idea what they were doing. They focused on 'cool' and bypassed function and common sense. What adult ever sits in a beanbag chair unless the HAVE TO? None. Too uncomfortable to sit in and way too hard to get out of. How stupid can they get?Bathroom with a louvered door is as equally stupid. No privacy from sound and smells and the light shines through at night. Next is the, How F__ing Dumb can you get. NO SHOWER DOOR! Water on the floor everywhere including the bathroom. Add water + No exhaust fan and you get mold on the bathroom floor and warped wood in the room. Add on paper thin walls, cheap fluorescents everywhere (haven't heard of LED?), weak internet and slow elevators and you have the Aloft in Nashville.On the + side, the employees were extremely nice and understanding and did their best.I'd have to go with Lotionistic and give it 3.5 stars. Would I stay there again? Maybe, maybe not. It's expensive because of the location, parking, and its hip urban feel. I think I would recommend it for girls night out, wedding parties and adult family reunions. For the price, I may have preferred a downtown place with complimentary breakfast. (Especially if you're expecting a hangover.)They do allow pets. We brought our 40lb dog with no problem, except no green area nearby to walk the dog. We booked this hotel through hotwire, because a previous hotel booking went awry. It was my daughter's 21st birthday (which was cut way too short because of our other hotel's screw up and hotwire's long time to resolve the problem), we had five girls and a dog on the 9th floor. The room with two beds and the bean bag chair was definitely big enough for all of us. Pros: Very clean, allows pets, nice sized bathroom counter space, roomy, shampoo and body wash dispensers, lots of towels, hair dryer, iron, ironing board, coffee maker, floors with thin carpet overlay (I prefer floors), comfy beds and lots of comfy pillows, big mirrors, drawer space, hangers, charger, big bean bag chair for extra person to sleep on, desk area, alarm clock. Very modern, loved the artwork and chic feel. I remember the same lamp being on an HGTV episode. I took pictures, but I don't think they do the room justice. (Better in person.) Lobby looked fun. Front desk clerk was friendly, busy and efficient. We didn't use valet or bellhop, but saw him assisting others and he was very friendly and helpful. I loved the shower. It's very roomy, and a big showerhead with a great flow. I take notoriously long showers, and temperature was great, and didn't get water on the floor like others stated (and I normally do at home). Was surprised no fan. Lots of lighting. I can't believe people complained about the shower because that was one of my favorite parts of the room. We thought the beanbag chair was great and definitely added to the experience/value/feel.According to my 20-something girls the location was good for night-life. I saw some outside seating that I would have enjoyed if we were staying longer. They have room service, we didn't use. I have no idea if we had neighbors or not, but no problem with noise. Wifi was reliable. You need a passcode. Checkout time is noon, which is nicer than 11 a.m.Cons:Parking sucks. We arrived at 1 a.m. because of hotwire and other hotel problems. Didn't see the sign on the bell stand parking $24 until we pulled out. Getting in and out of garage was a pain. (Especially with one ticket and two cars.) The parking was added on to our hotel bill. (So from 1 a.m. to Noon the next day, we paid $48 just to park. Total bill was $272 for one room, double beds. I would never pay that much for this, but hotwire is comping us for some of it. We stayed on a Friday.) No complimentary breakfast. (We called the front desk and asked.)I didn't see a comment card in the room. The strip of wood between the bathroom sleeping room was loose and I would have left a note for engineering. They accept pets, but not convenient for walking pets. Coffee provided was "light" I would have preferred dark. And more of it. Thankfully, I bring my own instant to add. There is construction outside - didn't bother me, I couldn't hear it, but might bother others. I guess I didn't feel there was a cost-to-value ratio. I think a hotel with better parking and free breakfast can provide a similar experience for less money, albiet possibly not as modern. I was pleased, and I'd stay here again if the price was right. But I'd probably check out the other downtown hotels first if you're money/value conscious. But if money is no object, you have a big party, or you're looking for an urban chic feel - then go for this place first.A Loft is an attempt at "edgy" and ultra cool for somebody. Who that somebody is, I'm not really sure.While the rooms are big, it's not really useful space. The bean bag chair is not relaxing or functional. Done up with IKEA furnishing and soap dispensers on the wall, not sure if this is the "hip" that I'm looking for.Although the reviews say property was refurbished our room showed considerable wear, especially the laminate floors and a very loud heater/AC unit. Positives, the mattress were comfortable and reasonable access to downtown.Pay for parking at $24 per nite always frosts my cake but I guess this is par for the area. This is not a budget hotel by any definition so be ready for $200+ + per nite without anything happening in town. Our group had a great time in Nashville, but this hotel was not really compelling for a return visit. I think there are better values and venues.
review_content_40: We stayed here for my bachelorette party and I must say that the website is deceiving.  We had a room booked that said "King Bed + Queen and seating area." False.  The room was nice, but not for 5 people.  They first tried saying that the fold out couch was actually the queen bed when we checked in. False again.  It is a tiny twin bed that folds out.  Management really wasn't helpful unless they gave us a not as good room.  We ended up keeping the room we had due to lack of options, having 3 people sleep on the bed, 1 on the fold out couch, and another person making a pallet on the floor.  It gets three stars for the location.  Walking distance to a lot of great places and a very quick and cheap cab ride to downtown.  Just be warned it is pulling teeth to get good customer service thereMy partner and I stayed here for two nights. I have mixed feelings on the place. Overall it was ok and I'm hoping the things we experienced were exceptions to the norm. As this was our first experience at an Aloft I had no expectations set. Since Nashville doesn't have a W this was the next best thing we thought. Our flight was 2 hours late getting to Nashville and we arrived at the hotel at 10:30PM. Upon arriving we learned that half of the hotel was without hot water and it would be repaired the following day. To compensate for this they comped the room for the night without hot water as well as valet for the entire weekend. They were nice and very apologetic and focused on making sure we were taken care of. The only thing they could have done outside of this would have been to try and contact us in advance of our arrival to let us know the situation and give us options. As it stood, the rooms on the half of the hotel with hot water were taken and other hotels in the area were booked. Aside from that, the room was nice. Decor was great - modern and minimal. The louvred bathroom door was odd as was the lack of any decent place to sit aside from the bed, a single desk chair and two oversized bean bags. The room was, and I'm not kidding, at least 800 sq. ft. so there was plenty of room to have seating. Cabs are easy to get outside the hotel. A few places to eat along Broadway that are within walking distance. A few nice gay bars within walking distance that were great to check out too.I'm not sure where to begin.I've heard GREAT things about A Loft and W hotels but this place was an absolute bummer.While choosing where to stay, I read many reviews about it being "under construction" and "Cant wait to see when it's finished", so I was hoping that we would get there when the renovations were done.  I asked multiple times while we were there and they said "oh, yes were done"  Me'thinks not.- The room we stayed in had scuffed and chipped furniture, the molding and general carpentry work from the floor to the ceiling looked cheap and something you would expect from a inexperienced and rushed "do it yourself-er"- The bathroom door was slotted so you could hear "EVERYTHING" going on in there.  Me and my girlfriend took turns kicking each other out the room each time major business needed to be conducted.- The shower, (granted was handicapped) had no curtain or door and was built in a way that was impossible NOT to soak the bathroom floor and required us to use ALL of our towels to keep it from seeping out into the hallway which the wood floor was already water damage as it buckled and separated throughout the unit.- We also had to ask on a couple occasions for our towels, water, coffee to be replaced as "the talent" forgot to get them to us.  This had to be done in person as the phone in our room was busted.- Windows looked like they haven't been cleaned in years and the room as a whole felt dirty especially with mold and mildew around the bathroom grout and caulk lines.-  Initially, I thought it was a neat idea to place FATBOYs in the rooms, but upon further inspections there were a few lovely white spots all over (Gross).Seriously, Do yourself a favor and stay somewhere else.  For the price we were paying Id wished I spend a little more and just stayed downtown.  I had to go outside a few times and make sure we were staying at the right hotel!This hotel was called Hotel Indigo when we booked it so I was a little bit nervous when we showed up and it was called Aloft Nashville, but i was pleasantly surprised.  It's a nice hotel, better than the hampton inns in the area.  Nice hotel and a short cab ride out of the main downtown area.  The rooms were really nice and unique, which I loved.  The only strange thing was that the bathroom door was slatted wood, so there's no, um, privacy.  Otherwise, I loved the room, the bed was super comfy and the coffee machines are mini kuerigs, which was cool.They have life music in the lounge area and a bar.  The restaurant attached looked good too, but I did not have a chance to try it.  NOTE:  Parking is $17.48 not $16, as they tax it. Maybe that's a Nashville thing?  Anyway, I highly recommend this hotel for your stay in Nashville.I don't quite understand the negative reviews.  It's Aloft so it's lofty.  I think the room was well laid out and quite unique compared to most chains in the business and personal traveler market.  The location is A-OK - not much walkable in the immediate area but it's close to downtown and the university.  I think when they're done with the new condos and other development in the next few years it will be a better and more central location.  The check-in process was a little strange (and I've stayed in Aloft properties many times before) but I'll chalk that up to the individual and not the properties.  The rooms are funky with cool art, interesting bathrooms and spaces, and giant pillows.I might be back. :)This was my first stay at an Aloft, and I traveled with a friend who stays here often. We did not use the valet/ parking lot, so I cannot comment there.Pros-- Clean-  A LOT of food/beverage options for breakfast and snacks- City bus across the street, so you can easily get up and down broadway on the city bus. PS the city bus DOES accept dollar bills. Can you walk to downtown Nashville? Eh..if you want, but not that close (probably 30 min walk?). Cons-- On Labor Day weekend/ Univ of Kentucky playing in Nashville, there was ONE poor soul working the front desk alone and answering the phones alone. She was a GEM, never lost her cool. But there was easily a line 5-6 people deep and she had no help. Shame on management for not staffing better (who cares if there is a sick call, then a manager needs to come in and help on a weekend like this).- NO ONE that works at this place has any idea of what to do/eat/see while in town. No one had heard of the famous "Station Inn", no one could recommend a breakfast place that was open on Labor Day Monday within walking distance of the hotel (I told them "Yelp says.." ). One employee even mentioned three CHAIN restaurants as the BEST restaurants in town; that's so insulting it isn't even funny.Visually, this place is adorable - but like a 22 year old girl adorable who doesn't know how to be a lady when she opens her mouth. Paper thin walls, lack of eye contact from desk staff, and oh, don't get romantic here because you can hear EVERYTHING whether you're in the next room or bathroom. I have to say this too - it attracts college students trying to be hip. I can't blame them, I would have done the same. As I watch them drop water balloons from the rooftop on to passing runners - I realize they are sooooo uncool to be roomies next door. Being all grown up with money - I'll be staying somewhere else during my next visit to Nashville.3.5 stars actually. If you're not a picky person, you'll be pleased. I booked a rm on hot wire . com, so didn't know what hotel until after the fact. VERY concerned b/c all of the bad rvws, but it was fine. CONS: 3 employees looking busy at the front desk, but it took a loooong time to check in; furnishings starting to look tired - chips/scratches on most wood furniture; shower fixture worked, but had missing pcs/very loose; can hear neighbor if they have sex loudly at 2am (connecting doors in rooms). PROS: location; good rate on site mentioned above; friendly staff; cool vibe; clean and comfortable. Some ppl mentioned wood floors. Our king rm had carpet, so no issues there. I would say "So what?" to other rvws re: beanbag chairs in the rms; no shower door; louvred bathroom doors, etc. Pay a hundred bucks more / nt elsewhere if you want a traditional hotel/room. Can't comment on pkg rate - we parked for free on the street during a wknd stay.OK hotel. JUST OK. The lobby smells like fruity pebbles all the time (a plus) and it seemed to be bug free.. There were a couple weird things tho. One night our room smelled terribly like cigarette smoke. It was blowing in from the air conditioner. It was doing it all night. I got really sick. Turning it off wasnt an option because it was 90 degrees out. A security person came up to check, smelled it, and wrote it in a log. It was a terrible night because of it. I really think compensation should have been given for this..like a night free or something. I couldnt sleep because of it. Also, someone in our group swears money was stolen from her suitcase.  I dont know if I would stay again as it doesnt have room service, the bar is odd to order a drink at, there isnt a spa or pool and its kind of far from all the fun of broadway. The front desk staff was very friendly and helpful tho.The people were great. Awesome personal service. The hotel rooms are noisy. Paper thin walls and the person in the next room had a barking dog. Valet service was ok, not great. Beds are comfortable. Will not stay here again simply because of the noise and "pet friendly" hotel policy.Booked a king/queen suite, got a queen, full pullout. Dirty floors.  Took over a half an hour to get sheets for pull out. Would not stay here again!Great place to stay! Easy to walk every where (great location), spacious rooms and fun lobby. Best of all- the staff! I'm in the hotel biz and wish I could take the amazing gal that works the front desk and take her with me- wish I could remember her name!! I will be back because of her! Great hotel!My buddies and I came to Nashville for our annual Mancation this weekend and stayed at the Aloft.  This hotel has a fun atmosphere and a great, central location for people who are looking to explore the city and have some late night fun.  A special thanks to Nick and Christie for your personal touch and hospitality.  You made our stay in Nashville memorable.It's cute. The room is decorated very nicely. Parking at atrocious with very small spots and people parking sideways. Staff here are not typical Aloft staff (this is an independently owned Aloft that has recently transitioned from Hotel Indigo) and you can tell that they are not going to go out of their way to make you feel overly welcome.  But it does have free wifi (I love that in a hotel!).The bathroom - as one person put it earlier, the door is a slanted wood door that allows little "privacy" as one is in the bathroom (you can hear EVERYTHING that anyone is doing in the bathroom). While showering last night, the water suddenly became SO hot that I had to step aside in order to adjust it. Then, this morning, the water never became hot after 5 minutes. Then there's the nightstand beside my half of the bed. It's so gross behind it that I decided against taking a picture of it once I had my camera in hand. I don't know what it is all over the wall, but it looks like someone splashed something all over it (or sneezed all over the wall) and it and it has never been taken care of. Simply disgusting.Would I stay here again? No. Maybe they are just trying to work out the kinks that anyone would go thru during a transition, but it is not impressive.The Aloft is one of those hotels you know has potential, it's just a bummer I was staying there during construction! I think that the location is really perfect, right in the middle of everywhere you want to be. The room was a fairly good size, and the hotel staff couldn't be nicer. It did seem like the walls were a little thin, but thats what cocktails are for, right?Best service everWhat to stay here vs the other hotels in the areaBest trained staffNo hot water. I let the shower run for 10 minutes and no change in temp. If you have a car and self park, it is a hassle. The two treadmills were out of order.Don't look any further for a hotel in Nashville.  This is the best!  Although it's about a mile walk to downtown and HontyTonk Row, etc, you also have some fantastic bars, restaurants and music venues a few blocks away (Winners, Losers, Blue Bar, etc). This hotel bed and shower are superb!  We booked it when it was called Hotel Indigo and we've heard one too many times "we're in transition" but no matter, still great place. Let's hope it stays that way once the 'transition' has been completed.What would you do if a bomb exploded, shaking the entire hotel and woke you at 6:30am? Would you be scared? Would you want to know what was happening? Would you try to call the front desk? I was traveling with a friend to Nashville and was happy to see that we had bid and "Named Our Own Price" at the Aloft Nashville West End on Priceline. Though parking was expensive ($22), our check in at around 7:30pm was pleasant. We went into our room and it was ok. However, two incidents occurred which were greatly upsetting and reflect very poorly on this hotel and Starwood.At 6:30am, we were awakened by an explosion that shook the entire hotel. It was so violent, that we felt that it HAD to be in the hotel or very close. I immediately picked up the phone to call the front desk to find that there was no ring tone! My friend ran to the door and said that he didn't see any smoke or fire but we should get dressed and leave the hotel.I had the sense to use my cell phone and call the hotel's main number. It was immediately answered by a female who sounded very calm. I told her that we had heard an explosion and were very concerned. She asked if we hadn't noticed all of the construction (ummm no, we were supposed to?) going on down the street and stated that a new hotel was being built down the street. The builders/city used explosives two or three times a week at 6:30am to clear the grounds. She further stated that the hotel was not given notice when these explosions would occur and it wasn't their responsibility. I asked that since the hotel knew these explosions happen, shouldn't the hotel notify guests that this *might* occur? She then brusquely reiterated that it was not the responsibility of the hotel to inform their guests because they are not given prior warning from the city, so it was out of their hands. I was shocked.We are from Washington, DC. We both had had experiences in our lives with terrorism, bombs etc during 9/11 and other incidents since then. Clearly our lives were/are affected differently than someone from Nashville. The Boston Marathon bombing was only a few weeks ago. So when the explosion occurred, my first immediate thought was of the Oklahoma City bombing in the 80's and terrorist attacks.I was too upset to sleep so I took a very long shower, packed and went downstairs to the front desk and told the person there, Hugo, that I wanted to speak to a manager about what had occurred that morning. Knowing I was so upset, I made sure I was speaking in a low, calm, carefully modulated voice. I realized there were other guest behind me and didn't want to create a scene as they didn't seem upset at all. Hugo was immediately defensive and angry. He said that general manager wasn't there and when I asked if there a manager on duty, he said no. Rather than addressing my concern, he asked if I wanted someone to look at the phone and see why it wasn't working. When I said no, he asked if I wanted to close out the room and have my car brought around from the valet.I told him my friend was still in the room and would be down shortly. Instead, I wanted to find out how to contact a manager. He went to the other side of the desk and brought back a business card for the general manager. As he handed it to me, it stated once again that the manager wasn't there. At that point I asked what his name was and wrote it down on the card. He asked once again if I wanted to check out. Since it was clear that he wouldn't help, I said yesAs I waited in the lobby for my friend, I overheard two employees behind me talking in the breakfast nook area and got up to speak to them. One employee had already walked away by the time I reached them but I managed to flag down the remaining employee and asked him if there was a manager on duty. He pointed to Hugo and said, "It's the guy at the front desk". I was puzzled, and asked again. He stated that Hugo was the front desk manager and in charge until the general manager came in around 10 or 10:30am. When he asked what was wrong, I told him what had happened starting from the explosion, to the call, to what Hugo had told me. I was SHOCKED when he said that the explosions don't happen two or three times a week. THEY HAPPEN EVERY DAY! He said he'd have the GM call me when she got in.The second my friend came down, we left immediately. As we walked out the door, Hugo said "I'm sorry about YOUR problem." MY PROBLEM?!?!?! REALLY?!??!?!?When I got home, I sent an email to Starwood. No response. No surprise that the GM at the Aloft never called, even though I called and left a message too.I'm sure the hotel didn't want to lose business but they should have explained about the explosions. How greedy Aloft Nashville West End and Starwood Properties! You might have gotten my business for one night but how many potential customers reading this will you lose now?STAY AWAY!!!!!!!Although this may look like an Aloft, this location is a disgrace to the Aloft brand. Never experienced a hotel team that is so unattentive to guests and to keep up what needs to be done in the hotel.  Terrible experience the first stay and then tried them again to give them the benefit of the doubt that it was a fluke--but no...this place has some real staff problems. Not staying here anymore.
review_content_60: Place looks better online, I expected more from a W affiliate. The room was just ok, ceiling was dirty but it was decent. It was overpriced for the quality that's for sure. Next time I'm in Nashville I will try the Hutton across the street or stay mainstream with a Hilton. This property needs major improvement to compete. On the positive side every single person on the staff was more than excellent. All of them went above and beyond and made we feel very welcome . The staff deserves a better property. Location was excellent. I hope they make some improvements with the property, if so I would consider returning just because the staff was great. I love Hannah, she was excellent and I wish her the best!The hotel is under remodel and the anticipated completion date is April 1st.  I found the rooms to be disappointing and nothing special.  There are far better values.  The room was clean and the staff friendly enough.  IMO the remodel isn't going far enough.  The bathrooms aren't very nice and the furniture was worn.  I can only hope these will be addresses with the remodel.The hotel & the hotel staff were good but, during a recent stay of 5 nights our 2013 Lexus was keyed in the parking garage on both sides of the car. While I know there is little they can do to prevent this from happening, I expected a call from management. It never came:(Had an absolutely wonderful stay here. Staff was very friendly and attentive to our needs. We had two issues w can drivers which was out of their control. They were nice enough to recommend a specific can company and drivers they knew so we wouldn't have the issue again.they even ordered a pizza for us late night. All we said was we want pizza and they took  care of finding the pizza place for us and calling them. Pizza showed up at our door ! We didn't even have to go down to the lobby and pick it up! They had it sent directly to our room.  The hotel was very chic and modern our room was huge and the decor in the hotel was beautiful . One of our walls in the room had music notes and a trumpet drawn on it! Perfect for music city Nashville! When we checked out we had questions about the bill and the were courteous and patient while we had questions! The room was even cheaper than we thought!!! Very pleased and will definitely be staying here again when we visit NashvilleThis hotel is under major construction - do not stay there unless you like smelling paint, having the floors and lobby covered in plastic and construction dust everywhere. As well the entire block across the street has been leveled and construction is beginging there as well.   I spent the entire day listening to a jackhammer from 7am till 5:30pm as I tried to work in the room.  My room was remodeled but the floor was not so it was weird walking around the work being done in other rooms.  As well the work done in my room was sloppy.  Paint chips were on the floor the new bathroom had a mirror with a broken frame.  The window curtins were horrible and clearly left over from the hotel purchased by this chain.  So why they are keeping the hotel open as opposed to closing it and remodeling it is beyond me.  Another tip...do not pay for their parking it is a rip off.  You can park a block away using meters on the street which go off in the evening.  Just check the no parking times.  I parked across the street at a meter all night for free.Best of all when I called the front desk to have a conversation with customer service to find out when the jack hammering would end for the day it went as follows:"Hi can you tell me when the jack hammering at the construction across the street will end for the day.  When do they stop for the day"?Agent:What construction:  Me:The one across the street.Agent:I am not aware of any construction.Me:How could you not be aware of the construction across the street?  They have flattened an entire city block and the noise is intense.Agent:Oh that construction.  Well maybe 5pm or 6pm.Me:So you really have no clue when they stop do you.  Click.I can't express how pleased we were with the Nashville Aloft hotel during our stay the last weekend in July.  Although the hotel is a little loud in both music and decorations (it gives off a semi-awkward hipster vibe), the staff could not have been nicer - big shout out to Jamie, one of the front desk attendants who was new to this location and had traveled all over for Aloft's parent company Westin - I have never met someone who truly embodied customer service like she did!  My boyfriend had lost his ID the first part of the trip, so when we arrived we were not feeling our level best.  However, we were checked in quickly, booked a second room in no time at all, were given good suggestions of places to visit, and on our second night were given some waters when we came back from having a couple (too many) drinks at the bars downtown.  Not only were the front desk people pleasant, the housekeepers (although very loud @ 930 in the morning after a night out) gave us extras towels and soap when we asked with a smile. For those looking to be within a 5 minute cab ride of the bars on Broadway (the main bar district in Nashville) but near some more local bars and restaurants with way more atmosphere, stay here!  We will definitely return on our next trip to Nashville which will be in the near future - we want to move here :-)First off, I'd like to state that we DID NOT stay here. Several friends and I along with my girlfriend decided at the last minute to travel to Nashville TN for the night from Louisville KY (06/15/2013). We all hopped on our Harleys and headed south. After a nice trip down we had planned on staying at the Holiday Inn Express in downtown Nashville. When we got there, they had no rooms available but, were more than happy to call around and find us a room. They called several hotels with no luck but, then called Aloft. The person there said "They weren't supposed to quote prices over the phone but, let's just say it's right at $199 and they had twenty rooms available" We were fine with that and jumped on the bikes and headed over there. When we got there we were told that they did not have any rooms available. They lady (and I use that term loosly with regards to her) said "Even if we had rooms available, they certainly wouldn't be $199, we are a four star hotel." We were absolutely appalled to be trated like this. Me being me decided to jump on my trusty smart phone and check for myself. What do you know? They had plenty of rooms left and were actually only $189 a night according to their own website. I'm not sure if it was our biker gear or what but, I cannot believe we were treated this way. Rather than cause a scene we decided to call around and find something else. At this point, we really didn't want to give them our business anyway. We ended up findin the Hilton downtown for $292 a night (which we had no problem paying) and it was a very nice hotel. It also ended up being much closer to where we wanted to hang out for the night. All in all, I will never stay in a hotel owned by this group.I came to this hotel with an open mind, even after reading the reviews. My conference hotel was full so Sheraton sent me here. Okay so the lobby looks like a Pinkberry...a different vibe I get that. My room has 3 bean bag chairs...not my demographic I get that. However it began to go South when there was no light anywhere near the desk. Not on it, not over it, nowhere. In fact that side of the room is kind of a black hole. There are only two inconveniently placed outlets available (one is to be crawled under the dark desk to find) in order to power my electronics. There is a cool light in the corner that is not plugged in because there is no outlet anywhere near it. I have one trash can and it says it is only for recyclables. Why are the only cups in the room the paper ones by the coffee machine? The topper however is that my room did not get made up. No one had come near it since I left at 7:30 this morning. I was willing to overlook some stuff but really? I was told that this has been a regular occurrence as of late. What am I paying for? And the front desks answer was "Sorry what would you like us to get you, towels?" If I were to come back to Nashville I would choose a different hotel.

review_content: Hyatt Place Nashville Downtown was hands-down the best place to stay for my bachelorette party weekend. Though I originally wanted to book at a nearby, higher end hotel, the room rates were outrageous. I remembered the Hyatt Place from a previous Nashville visit and knew: the location is ideal, it's a relatively new property, and the rates were in line with what we were looking to spend.  The rooms are large and perfect for sharing - the couch has a fold out single bed. The bathrooms are large and there is plenty of counter space. I also enjoyed the full length mirror in the room, just outside of the bathroom, which is located near an outlet. Even with three girls in my room, we had no problems getting ready at the same time. Like other reviewers, I did not care for the frosted glass sliding door on the bathroom. Privacy is not overrated! A hot breakfast with tons of options is served every morning in the lobby. I was stunned to receive a plate of breakfast sandwiches, scrambled eggs and biscuits and gravy from my friends who were up early enough to take advantage of this perk. The lobby also features a bar and a small menu that is perfect for late night snacks. All of the staff we encountered were friendly and helpful, but we were disappointed that our room was not cleaned after night one. We had placed the do not disturb sign on our door, which was there until around noon. When we left the room we noticed a bag of fresh towels, but we really wanted our room serviced since we had a bunch of plates and drinks scattered around. I called to request a housekeeping visit and was assured we would receive one. Two hours later when my sister went back to the room to pick something up, she called down with same request. Unfortunately, our room was never cleaned so by the time we left it was a bit of a mess. That said, I can't dock any stars from Hyatt Place, and here's why: after being home for three days, I went to switch my purses around and realized with a pit in my stomach that the last time I had my other bag I was in my hotel room. That's when I also realized I had left another bag (yes, I brought three handbags on a weekend vacation), plus a pair of shorts and a tank top. On the day of our check-out, I was running late for a brunch reservation and was scrambling to get everything together - I must have forgotten to check the closet! I called the hotel, thinking there would be no way that my stuff was still around. I was STUNNED when the manager confirmed that they had everything! I gave him my credit card number so that the hotel could ship everything back. The next day, I received a voicemail from the head of housekeeping confirming the shipment. Today, my items arrived, along with two additional shirts my future sister-in-law also left in the room. I've left pricey items in hotel rooms before and it has always been a lost cause (RIP, Joe's Jeans). I cannot believe my stuff has been returned and I am so very grateful to the housekeeping staff. Next time I take a trip to Nashville, I know exactly where I want to stay!This is a pretty large Hyatt Place in the heart of Nashville.  It's a great location, located right next to the Country Music Hall of Fame, and therefore close to Broadway Ave, thec convention center, the arena, the amphitheater, and lots of tourist attractions.  They have a pool and workout room, but no hot tub as far as I can tell (which would have been nice even though it is crazy hot outside, since I got sick with a cold during my stay...).  Some positives of the hotel are the "happening" vibe it gives off.  Just about every night during our stay they had live music in the lounge, and it seemed like every day there were troves of people checking in or out.  It always seemed lively and busy in the lobby, which could be good or bad I guess depending on your perspective.  The rooms aren't huge, but they're nice and cozy.  The windows have a nice black out feature so you can sleep as long as you like into the day without having the sunlight cause an annoyance.A major downside of the hotel is noise isolation.  People in the hall sound as if they're inside your room.  There was a very loud room across the hall from us having a party the other night, and I could have sworn it had to be an adjacent room given how "in your face" the sound was (I didn't figure out it was the room across until I went outside).The room doors are very heavy, causing them to slam shut behind anyone who opens them and isn't careful (so basically everyone).  When this happens in any direction 1 - 2 doors away from  you, your entire room rattles and the bed shakes.  It definitely woke me up every morning as people started evacuating their rooms for breakfast downstairs, so plan to be woken up by this noise pretty much daily.Speaking of breakfast, it's a pretty amazing one.  Lots of options, very delicious...though it would be nice if it lasted a little longer.  I barely made it down in time 3 of the nights, and the other 2 neither of us were able to make it.We were in town for about 4 football games during our stay.  I was excited about this when we booked, but now having stayed I wish we hadn't.  The whole town, including this hotel, becomes full of drunk, partying sports fans...which made the stay for people like us just trying to enjoy the city somewhat unpleasant.The 3 elevators work pretty well and are efficient in most cases, though when the hotel filled up over the weekend there was noticeably increased waiting and fullness.All in all, I recommend this hotel--especially if the "scene" I've described above sounds like your cup of tea.Amazing view and proximity to everything. We had a riverview corner room on the 12th floor and the toilet made noise all night. Almost asleep? Lemme help you with that... "Gurgle gurgle, p-toosh!".  Construction on the building next door starts bright and early at 5:30, so be sure to bring your hard hat, and blueprints, because then it'll be just like being a part of the construction crew. I understand progress, but hotels usually make note on their websites when there is construction going on in close proximity. I was given runaround at check in, even though I had the reservation in my Passbook app, as well as the card it was booked with. When asked for ID, none of these things were good enough, nor was my wife's ID. I had to backtrack to a car, that had been valeted, to pick up my ID before we could check in. This, after I checked in with a tap of my watch at a Marriott a month earlier. Ladies, my wife pointed out to me that the bathroom vanity is rather oddly deep and would cause you to do your makeup at an arm's length from the mirror.  From what I understand, that complicates eye makeup big time. The bar staff was outstanding, as we came in late and got snacks and drinks before bed. It's a shame their best staff works late night. Recapping, 1 star for location, and another for the bar staff. There are too many options in the area to return here for a second try.4.5...because I was looking forward to using the indoor pool instead of the gym (laziness during vacation issues) but unfortunately, it was closed during the 3 days I stayed here.  Other than that, this is a great downtown Nashville hotel. The rooms, ammenities, dining area, lobby, elevators, and even the hallways are clean, well-kept and the customer service was exceptional. The location is very convinient and perfect for anyone who wants to explore downtown Nashville or be anywhere near almost everything. Their breakfast buffet had always something new to offer, replenished even before the containers got empty, a wide variety of options, the tables were cleaned constantly, and the dining area was comfortable and clean.  I highly recommend this Hyatt Place for a great Nashville experience.People and service is GREAT, bar tenders are GREAT.  This review is sure to change AFTER all of the construction next door is complete.  Until then, ask for a room away from the construction side.I felt bad being so hungs while enjoying the hot breakfast filled with amazing eggs , sausage , biscuits and all the gravy one could want.
